Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 10th instant #128-1-5 with reference to the proposed workshop and store at the Mackay Indian Residential School. I would ask the Department if they are aware of the fact that part of this building is to be used as a store for the purpose of trading with the Indians, and if the Department have given official consent for such an enterprise. I have never yet heard of the Government putting up buildings to allow private concerns to operate a store, and that is what the Principal of the Mackay Boarding School wishes to do.

In submitting this plan to me, Mr. Waddy makes the following comment:-

"The cost will be proportionately less if the workshop alone is built; I recommend that this be allowed. I do not recommend the store part be built by the Department. The Church Authorities will no doubt make a profit if they run a store and can pay the cost of it. However, as the Principal thinks he is within his rights in asking for it I have put it on the plan."

My own opinion is that Mr. Waddy could have told the Principal very emphatically that it was against the law, and even if it were not against the law it would have been wrong to allow him to trade with Indians.

J. D. McLean, Esq.,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa
I bring this matter to your attention because I do not know what took place between the Department and the school authorities before the matter was brought to my attention.

I have discussed this matter with Mr. Inspector Christianson and he is of the opinion that a workshop is not very badly needed at that point, and in any case there is sufficient material in an old hospital building quite close to the school to build a workshop if the school authorities wish to use it for that purpose. I will, therefore, not proceed with this until I hear further from you.

The plan as submitted to you showed clearly the store part mentioned, with counter, private passage, etc., and you have made no comment on this.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
Ottawa, October 19, 1925.

Sir:

I have your 205-11A of the 13th instant, with reference to the workshop and storeroom at the Mackay Indian Residential School. I note that the storeroom is not for the regular purposes of an Indian residential school and, of course, the Department cannot authorize its erection. Please arrange to build a workshop, however, without delay. Use the materials in the old hospital building as far as possible and incur no unnecessary expense. Arrange for the school management to supply as much labour as possible in this connection.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

I have your letter of the 18th instant, and in reply beg to inform you that Mr. Inspector Bunn is being requested to arrange for the purchase of a 5 H.P. Sir:

I have the honor to report that the Principal of the McKay Indian Residential School reports that the storage batteries of the electric light plant of the school are not giving any service; that it is necessary to keep the dynamo running continually. During the summer, 1925, the batteries partly filled up with sediment. The Principal thinks it will be necessary to supply new batteries.

This plant has at times jumped from positive to the negative without any cause, thus reversing the electric current. When this occurs a few of the wires are changed on the switch board, and the plant runs for a short time, when it will again jump from the positive to the negative.

I beg to recommend that an electrician be supplied for the purpose of thoroughly examining this plant, and if necessary to obtain batteries that instructions be given me where to obtain the same.

The plant was supplied by the Star Electric Company, Winnipeg.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent

Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, Jan. 13, 1926.

Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 5th instant, with reference to the electric lighting plant in the Nishkay Indian Residential School, I beg to say that this plant was installed by the Star Electric Co., of Winnipeg in 1924, and there is no reason why the equipment if properly looked after and operated, should not be in perfect condition. You may make arrangements to have a competent electrician examine the plant, and put same in proper working order. The electrician should submit a report to you stating whether the trouble with the generating outfit was caused by neglect. If the trouble is due to improper operating of the system, the Department will expect the school to pay for the necessary overhauling and repairs.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Holman,
Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Sir:-

Yesterday acting on your instructions I visited The McKay School, and herewith is submitted my report following my inspection.

The general health of the pupils is excellent. There has been considerable number of cases of colds and influenza during the past winter season but these have been very efficiently handled by the staff. There are some half dozen pupils with defective vision and I would advise that these be fitted with suitable lenses at the earliest opportunity.

Inspected food and clothing of pupils and have no criticism to offer in regard to these.

Inspection of building showed that Dormitories, classrooms, playrooms, washrooms etc in the building were clean and in the case of the former, being well ventilated during the time that the children were excluded from them. The staff complain that it is difficult to keep the sleeping quarters well aired at night as the pupils close the windows left open as soon as the members of the staff have retired. In their own homes there is a notorious want of ventilation even the key hole in the doors being plugged. It would seem advisable to devise some system of obtaining fresh air in these rooms by some contrivance which the pupils could not manipulate themselves.

I have previously reported on the outside water closets at this Institution. As seen yesterday at inspection it is impossible to describe the filth of these two out buildings. Even the floors are piled with excreta in the girls' W.C.' and from the looks of the floor in the Boys' it would appear that the floor there had just recently been relieved of a similar load. By his report it is not intended to cast any reflection on the staff for this condition of affairs. The closets in the building off the Dormitories are closed during the day and pupils must use the outside closets. Owing to the nature of the soil it is said to be impossible to dig latrines of sufficient depth. Latrine pails that could be emptied in an incinerator every morning would answer for the summer months but would be impracticable in the cold weather. The only solution I can see is to either build an outhouse that would be connected with the water system of the institution and be heated from it or to fix up W.C.s in the building. I went over the ground with Mr. Hill the plumber and he states that at least three seats could be put in off the boys' play room, together with a urinal. These could be fitted with an automatic flush which would do away with the main objection to the inside W.C. system, viz: that the pupils forget to flush them after using. There are two closets now in the boys' section that only need to be connected...

Dear Sir:

I regret to have to inform you that about noon on Friday Jan. 22nd, the pigpen at the Mackay School, The Pas, Manitoba, was destroyed by fire and with it two sows and two pigs. Immediately after receiving this information I wrote to the Principal, Rev. E.V.Bird, requesting him to furnish me with a full report in this connection and in his report, dated Feb. 2nd, he writes, in part, as follows:

"It is very difficult to be able to make any definite statement, the only thing I can suggest, was that the fire started from the stove which heated the building and had to stand between two pens. This space was very narrow, and yet was the only position in which the stove could be placed. The sides of the pen were covered with tin, and I think that possibly there must have been some dust behind the tin. This ignited from the heat of the tin, and probably ran up the post, until it burst out into flame. Of course one can only surmise this. The pipes which I examined after the fire were in good condition, and as for the stove it was impossible for any spark to escape from it.

The only other way, is that possibly a boy went into the pigpen and put more wood on the fire, and that by some means a spark dropped out and started the fire. However, as the floor was of cement, and always kept free of litter, I do not think the fire started this way."
As the building was 16 ft. by 24 ft. and stood near to the stock barn, it was with considerable difficulty that the latter building was saved from destruction also. The temperature at the time was 40 degrees below zero, and the Principal and the farm instructor were both frost bitten while working to prevent the fire from reaching the neighboring building. As the sum of $200.00 for the extension of the pigery, was included in the list of requirements forwarded to your Department to be supplied this year, I trust that this sum may be sufficiently augmented to provide this School with a larger and fully modern building to take the place of the one which has been destroyed.

I am Sir,

Your obedient servant.

Dear Sir,

With reference to the Pump trouble at The McKay Boarding School at the Big Eddy, I beg to report as follows:

The Pump is in a worn condition, and needs some replacements. As far as I can ascertain it has been doing steady service for 14 years.

The plunger and foot valves are worn, especially the moving parts and their guides. Also the pump rods, which are of oak are soggy worn thin and peel off.

These should be renewed at an early date, as they are liable to break at any time, and it is somewhat serious if they break in the well 40 or 50 ft. down, which causes considerable trouble to get them out again, also delay in getting the water service in action again.

The water pumped is not as much as it was originally for the following reasons:
1. The worn condition of the valves.
2. The present pump head is smaller than the original, both in the area of discharge, and the length of stroke.

The pump is capable of throwing more water than the present Head or Jack can handle.

Until the valves are renewed it is impossible to tell if the well casing leaks, but by its appearance, this is still in good condition.

The engine power is adequate.

There does not appear to be any shortage of water, as the pump plunger is submerged about 15ft.

I trust the above will enable you to form a correct estimate of the present condition of the plant.

Yours truly,

Chas. W. Hill

Dear Sir:

With reference to the Department Letter No. 5865/I35 dated March 17th, re the pump here,

After consultation with Mr. Turner, we cannot make any definite statement as to what would be the best plan to follow.

While if new Spool Valves and new Pump Rods were installed, this might be satisfactory, yet we would not like to say that it would, though we have every reason to feel that it may remedy the defect.

Again it is a question as to whether a new pump fitted inside the casing would be satisfactory, allowing for the thickness for the sockets on the pipe; this would reduce the pipe down to 2 inches, and this probably would be too small a flow of water, and again the rods in such a pump would have to be Steel, and the vibration would shake them, as also the pump pipes, as they could only be slipped inside the casing and hang from the top.

Somehow I feel that it would be worth while to have new rods and new Spool Valves installed, for if they prove to be the remedy, then the pump would give more satisfaction than a new pump installed inside the casing.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

In reference to letter #128-1-5 of the 17th ultimo regarding pump for the Mackay School, I beg to say that I have delayed answering this letter until I investigated the matter fully.

I went to the school and tried to find out why the pump could not be pulled up as is usual when repairs are being made. I asked all sorts of questions and at last found that the trouble there is that the lining for the well was only put down one length from the top, then the pump was installed in the well. In the years which have passed since then dirt and rocks have fallen in and jammed the pipe of the pump so it cannot be withdrawn. In other words if they cannot fix the pump they will need a new well. Mr. Turner who was Inspector of Construction at time the school was erected told me the truth when I asked him, after I found out that the casing was not put into the well. He said that when the well was dug they did not put in casing after the rock formation was reached. I then tried to get them to consent to using the old well pipe as a casing and insert a smaller pump, but they state this would not be satisfactory. All we can do now is fix the pump the best way we can and when it plays out dig a new well and go to all the expense of a new pump.

A letter from the Principal is enclosed.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Re: The MacKay School.

Dear Sir,

During an interview with the Superintendent of Indian Education on the 1st inst. I directed his attention to the urgent need of an engine for the freight canoe at the MacKay School The Pas., Man., and was advised to address a written communication to you in this connexion.

As you are no doubt aware, this School is located about seven miles from the town of The Pas. and during the summer months all transportation is by means of canoe. As there is no telephone communication between the school and the town frequent journeys have to be made for mail as well as for supplies and other purposes and consequently a motor-driven canoe is an indispensable necessity. Our Society can secure a Johnson Light Twin Outboard Motor which is guaranteed to drive an 18 ft. freight canoe against a 4 mile an hour current, and even with another canoe at the same time, for $175 and it will be a great help to our Society if your Department will authorize this expenditure. During my interview with the Superintendent of Indian Education I agreed that the building of the pigery might be postponed this year, if your Department would undertake to purchase the engine required, in addition to the painting of the interior of the main school building, and I trust that this agreement may be approved and the purchase of the engine sanctioned.

Believe me Sir,

Yours very truly,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your circular re fire escapes and fire protection.

I might say that the fire escapes at the Mackay School are the best that can be provided, and are in my opinion the real one for large schools, especially where there are small children; they seem get quite adept at going down, and it very quickly.

Two for the girls, and two for the boys are provided on each floor. The openings are always open except in the summer, when loose screens easily removed are put on, so soon as the mosquitoes have left these are taken away.

The doors open outside, and are fastened with an asp. One of the staff are appointed for each escape, to look after the door, and guide the children down.

Owing to an epidemic of mumps we have not been able to have fire drill since the commencement of the present school term, so soon as we are free it commence again.

Dear Sir:

I have the honor to enclose report of my visit to the MacKay Indian Residential School during the month of November, 1927. In addition to the enclosed report I wish to state that the radiators in this school are in bad shape. Sixteen were leaking at the time of my visit to the school, as the weather was excessively cold and a large head of steam was being carried. Sixteen air valves are required immediately to repair these radiators. They also should have one week of a plumber's time in the spring when steam is cut off to have the large radiator valves fixed and repacked, etc.

Since visiting the school the last time the pump has been fixed by the local plumber, but he tells me it will not stand up very long in his opinion. He also says that the lining of the well is in very bad shape, and he does not think it will last much more than a year, if it lasts that long.

The compression tank in the water distributing system has rusted from the inside and is leaking. It is hard to tell how long it will be till large leaks develop. We have the small ones plugged up at the present. It would appear as if this compression tank will have to be renewed shortly, and if so I think it would be well to put in two smaller tanks instead of the one large one, and we could shut off one tank occasionally and paint the inside to keep it from rusting. It is not possible to do anything to this present tank as it is continually in use.

The engine used in the lighting plant is about used up. The Principal states we require a twelve horse power engine for a place of this size, with a generator and batteries large enough to suit. All the present electric light system appears to be too small and light for the job, and they have been continually overloaded since they were installed. The batteries are now entirely out of commission and no storage of electric light is possible.

I am, Sir,

Report on Deep Well Pump.

I have to report that the well casing is either broken at a joint, or corroded at several small places. As long as the pump is working the casing remains full, and pumps water to the storage tank, but immediately the pump stops, the water disappears. I had a difficulty in getting the plunger past a point 35 feet from the surface, the obstruction seems to be a broken joint in the pipe. The water would get away there, and at places where corrosive action has eaten through the casing. I am inclined to think that there is considerable corrosion, as the pipes have been in for about 14 years, and I have had to replace in this district, water pipes that have only done 10 years service. Casing is of wrought Iron pipe.

Dear Sir:

During my recent visit to the Mackay School (May 5 & 6) my attention was directed to the urgent need of a new and larger boat for this institution, and I am writing for the express purpose of soliciting the assistance of your Department in meeting this need.

The School, as you are aware, is situated approximately 7 miles from The Pas on what is known as Fischer Island. As communication between the School and the town is maintained during the summer months along the Saskatchewan River, it is necessary that a serviceable boat to meet the different kinds of weather should be available for the School management. The canoe which is in use at present and which has been fitted with an outboard engine is an 18 foot freighter and is too small to negotiate the currents at the Big Eddy, or to ride the waves on so wide a river when proceeding against the strong wind. I know very well myself from actual experience the dangers to which the School management are exposed when travelling in the discharge of their duties on so small a craft, and I do not think that they should be exposed to this danger any longer than can possibly be helped. At the time of my visit practically the whole countryside was flooded and the channel between the highland of the Reserve and the Island, and in which I had never seen water on any of my former visits, was now filled to a depth of 5 feet or more, and running with a strong current. The need of a bigger and stronger boat fitted with a good engine was so obvious to me that I talked the matter over with Mr. Indian Agent Waddy who stated that he felt it was essential for this School to be provided with a larger and stronger boat such as I had suggested. He informed me that The Pas Canoe Company built
standard boat which cost approximately $500.00, and I am of the opinion that a boat of this type would meet the immediate needs of this institution. As the canoe at present in use can no longer be considered seaworthy, and will soon have to be scrapped, I beg to recommend that your Department authorize the purchase of one of the standard boats as built by The Pas Canoe Company for the use of the Mackay School, or that you make the purchase direct through your Indian Agent.

I have the honor to report as follows on my visit to the Mackay Indian Residential School on the 5th inst.

The pupils are in good health, tidy, well fed and clothed, the school is in very good shape at present.

In reference to the electric light machinery supplied last winter, this has not been put in condition so far. The present machinery room is too small to contain it. The Principal says it would be too costly to enlarge this room in the main building and he suggests erecting an addition to the pump house for the whole electric light plant. This place would be 16 X 30. I am leaving here for Treaty 10 and cannot look after any construction, so I told the Principal to get an estimate of the cost of the place he has in mind and take it up with the Department direct. He thinks it will be necessary to put in larger generator; his present one is 110 and he thinks a 220 one should be supplied.

Some of the plaster on the stairways is cracked and has chipped off, he asks for an appropriation of about $40.00 to repair it.

The flashing around the cupola of the main building should be repaired, it leaks and will in a short time let in too much rain and bring down the plaster on the ceilings. It will take about $150.00 to tear out the old material and make proper repairs.

The well is still operating but may be out of order this summer; it will be necessary to dig a new well some time soon as the old one will be hard to fix when the casing rusts away a little more. It may be that the Department has some expert who could look it over and figure out some way of using the present well again. One or us here can see how it can be done.

Authority was given to get the compression tanks fixed or replaced when necessary. I think it should be done this summer; the old one is gradually going out of order and rusting away.

The average attendance is 81 this quarter up to time of my visit.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent

Requests have been received from Rev. The boat could be built at The Pas for approximately $400 and the engine for same would cost about $410 - or a total cost of approximately $800.

I may add that our Estimates provide the sum of $2100 for repairs and replacements at this school. If the above mentioned items are authorized, it would require an expenditure of approximately $2500. I beg to recommend that Rev. Dr. Westgate be given the necessary authority.

Dear Sir;

I have the honor to report that I visited the Mackay Indian Residential School on Friday the 26th inst in company with the medical officer.

In September the school was visited twice in company with Inspector Hamilton but as he was making a report I thought it best not to interfere with one from this office. The school at present is in fair state, it got badly run down last summer and looked as if a hail storm had cleaned out most of the windows when Mr. Hamilton was there, the youngsters had broken so much glass. The storm windows had not been removed during the summer and in fact it looked like a deserted old shack. I got after the new principal as soon as he arrived and he has had the place cleaned up and at time of my visit most of the glass had been replaced. The inside of the school has received attention and in a short time matters will be back to normal.

The engine house has been built and the engine installed, the lighting plant seemed to be giving satisfaction as it had just been completed. Everything is not just as it should be yet, but Mr. Conlin seems to be a capable man and he is getting things in hand quietly. There were so many matters to talk over and check up at time of my visit that I had no time to check up the class rooms, I will make another visit shortly.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy & Secretary,

McKay Indian Boarding School.

You will note the Inspector says that he was not favorably impressed with the general management of this school. This, of course, is no surprise to me, as we have never had proper management here. Inspector Christianson tells me that at the time he visited this school, two years ago, Mr. F. Turner was acting as a general man and labourer around the school, and he was not a fit person in any way to place in charge of the institution. It seems to me that the whole management here is bad, and with so many children in attendance at this school I think we should insist on its being straightened up and put in proper shape, as it is certainly no credit to the Department under the present conditions. It is hard to know just where to begin. From what I can gather from both Inspectors, the staff is not at all what it should be. You will also note that the building presented a neglected appearance, due to nothing more or less than mismanagement on the part of those in charge. To have the screens torn off some of the windows and destroyed, while on other windows the storm sash were left on all summer is disgraceful, to say the least. I would draw your attention to what the Inspector says regarding the condition of some of the beds in the girls' dormitory which he states are not fit to sleep on. There is no excuse for this. As regards the fire hose, I think another fifty feet of hose should be placed there, and instructions given regarding the care and use of same. The Inspector reports the pressure tank as being in poor condition, and states also that they have difficulty in getting water. This latter item, however, might be a minor difficulty if it were in the hands of a practical man. We are called upon to look after things at long range, and it is almost impossible to get accurate information. On several occasions we have sent men out from here to these points, when according to the reports it appeared to be work requiring the services of an expert and when they have gone out they have discovered very little wrong. You will note that the barn and chicken house were dirty, and the windows in the chicken house and workshop broken. In fact, the Inspector reports that at every turn he could see evidences of a lack of supervision.
They have an insufficient quantity of feed put up for the stock, notwithstanding the fact that the Department a couple of years ago took steps to provide them with new hay lands. You will notice the Inspector says he visited the hay lands for his own satisfaction and found an abundance of hay, so that this shortage should not exist. The report on the whole shows a very unsatisfactory state of affairs at the McKay School, and it is to be hoped that the new Principal is a highly qualified man who will reorganize the whole staff. The Department should insist on this.

MACKAY INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

This school is situated about ten miles up the Saskatchewan River on land that is an island except when the river is very low. The island is practically covered with bush and rock, so that it is impossible to do any farming.

The school is managed by the Church of England and Mr. F. Turner has been in charge during the past year. He was absent when I visited the school and Rev. A. Fraser was acting. I understood that a new principal was to arrive October 1st.

I regret to report that I was not favourably impressed with the general management of the school. The children appeared to have little supervision. I found boys and girls in the kitchen and in the basement with no member of the staff around. In fact, I went from the basement through the kitchen, dining room and front hall, and upstairs before I found any member of the staff. The matron was upstairs and

I learned
I learned later that the kitchen matron was busy doing extra work, due to a shortage of members on the staff. Two members are needed, a girls' supervisor and a laundry matron, and I understand Miss Fraser, the sewing teacher, is only temporary. I might also add that the entire staff was new to the work except Miss Warener, the matron, whom I believe has had too heavy a task and, in fact, appeared very much in need of a rest. I emphasised to Mr. Fraser, the Acting Principal, the grave responsibility resting upon each member in charge of the children and pointed out that boys must not be allowed to roam about the building unless proper supervision be given. He agreed and assured me that he would take the matter up and during the few remaining days while he was in charge a closer watch would be exercised.

I must say the building presented a very neglected appearance. On many windows the screens were torn and destroyed, while on others the storm sash had never been removed. Many of these sash have no sliding glass by which fresh air can be admitted. There was scarcely a window without some broken glass and at least fifty or sixty new panes were needed.

The senior classroom is in charge of Miss Farrow and has an enrolment of 44, 24 boys and 20 girls. Miss Farrow is a qualified teacher and should do well. I found the pupils fair in some subjects, but in reading, they appeared hopeless. They would scarcely speak above a whisper and Miss Farrow was of the opinion that it would be impossible to improve this. I, however, took each member of the class and had them read one line.
one line, after which I moved further away and had it re-read, and after several such tries the voice greatly improved and I think Miss Farrow realized that by perseverance these children can be made to speak so that their voice will carry across the classroom.

Miss Vincent is in charge of the junior room, with an enrolment of 24. The boys numbered 20 and the girls 4. The work appeared very good, although here, again, the children would scarcely speak above a whisper. However, Miss Vincent is determined to improve this and I would expect a decided change after she has been in charge a few months. Miss Vincent holds her Second Class Certificate and promises well as a teacher. The teacher's desk is a homemade affair and is a disgrace.

The junior room was without any screens and the outside windows were still on. I was informed that the classroom was also used as a playroom and it was impossible to keep the children from destroying the screens. I instructed the Principal, and also the teacher, to have two of the outside windows removed at once and to keep the windows open so that fresh air may be obtained. Apparently the children do as they please, regardless of what damage is done to the school property. I can see no reason why these window screens should be destroyed if the children are properly trained and supervised.

The girls' dormitory was clean. Some of the outside windows were still on and many of the screens were destroyed. The bed springs were in bad condition and many...
and many were scarcely fit to sleep on.

The boys' dormitory was in much the same condition as the girls', except that the bed springs were good. I understand these were replaced recently.

The waiting room used for Indian parents appeared more as a store room. It was untidy and certainly not a good example for the Indians.

I tried out the fire hose and found one that was absolutely worthless. The hose on the top floor appeared to have been thrown at the holder and was without a nozzle. A new 50 ft. hose and nozzle should be supplied. The 5 gal. fire extinguishers were all standing in the waiting room. I arranged with the Principal to have these placed in prominent places on each floor so that they may easily be reached in case of fire. Some small Pyrene extinguishers were hanging in various places throughout the building.

The pressure tank in the basement is badly rusted all along the bottom and already has sprung small leaks. The plumber who cleaned this tank out the day previous to my visit claimed the tank would stand no pressure and should be replaced at once. He recommended two tanks so that when one is being cleaned or repaired, the other would supply the building with water. Should this tank give way at any time, the school would be without water. The water for the school is supplied from a drilled well, which is giving considerable trouble. The steel casing goes down only 20 ft. and apparently the rock below this has fallen in and settled around the pump so that now it is impossible to remove the pump. If, at any time, the pump gives out and the repair cannot be carried out...
out, the school will be without water. This well, I understand, is 80 ft. deep.

The barn was in fair repair, but was not clean. The chicken house was very dirty and practically all the window lights were broken. The workshop had the lights out and also some of the window sash were broken. These buildings presented a disgraceful appearance.

The yards about the barn and school are stony. In addition to these stones, they were littered with pieces of wood and rubbish so that the whole place presented a neglected appearance. Mr. Turner, who was Principal during the past year, was an old man and apparently he had far too much work to do. Mr. Fraser, who is now supplying, had only been there a couple of weeks and expected to be relieved on October 1st. I found Mr. Fraser willing to carry out any suggestions and I have no doubt he would do his best during the remainder of his time in charge. On every turn one could see the lack of supervision and general management and undoubtedly a big task awaits the new Principal.

In closing, I should mention that Mr. Fraser was finding it difficult to get sufficient hay up for winter. Probably 30 loads were in stack, but a great deal more will be needed. I visited the hay flats and found an abundance of hay, so that, should a shortage occur, it will be due to a lack of effort on the part of those in charge and certainly not because the hay is scarce.

I did not see the cattle, but I understand about 12 head are kept and also a number of horses.
MACKAY INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

The children were well clothed and I believe receive sufficient food. I was present at the noon day meal, which consisted of abundance of fish, potatoes and bread, along with another vegetable and tea.

The garden was very fine and showed that great care had been given it. The vegetables were excellent and there appeared sufficient to supply the school during the winter months.
Ottawa, November 14, 1928.

Sir:

With reference to that portion of your No. 205-11 of the 7th instant, enclosing the report of Mr. Inspector Hamilton on his visit to the MacKay Indian Residential School, I beg to say that the Department has noted the conditions found by the Inspector under the management of the late acting principal. A new principal, Rev. T. D. Conlin, has been appointed, and, we understand, assumed duties on the 1st of October, last. He was well recommended, and it is hoped that the conditions mentioned by the Inspector will be remedied under his management.

Regarding the pressure tank, I have to inform you that Mr. Agent Waddy was instructed to purchase 2 - 1500 gallon tanks and have them installed.

I shall be pleased if you will arrange to purchase and forward a teacher's desk. It should be similar in type to that described in the catalogue of the Western School Supply Limited, Regina, as their No. 11 teacher's sanitary desk.

Please also arrange for the purchase and delivery of 50' of fire hose, with nozzle.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

During my recent visit to the Mackay School (Feb. 22 - Feb. 25) I made careful note of some of the repairs which are urgently required in connection particularly with the main school building, and subsequently discussed the same with Mr. Indian Agent Waddy, who concurred in my opinion that these repairs and improvements should be undertaken with the least possible delay. They are as follows:

Boys' Recreation Room

This room is 37' long 27'6" wide and 9'6" high. The lower part of the walls is covered with V-joint lumber placed vertically, and is for the most part in good repair. The upper part was originally plastered, but when this fell off, the School Management covered it with beaver board taken from the hospital which was pulled down last year. The repairs thus effected have never been satisfactory either from the standpoint of durability, or as a means of keeping the room weather-proof. This beaver board should be removed, and the whole of the upper part of the walls covered with lumber laid on horizontally over felt paper to keep out the cold, and the lumber again covered with metallic shingles similar to those which now cover the ceiling of this room. I asked a Winnipeg firm to furnish me with an estimate of the cost of the metallic shingles to cover the area in question, which is approximately 5' wide and 129' long, and their figure was $45.00. I am unable to give you an estimate of the cost of the lumber, but Mr. Waddy stated that it would not amount to very much. In addition to the lumber required for the recreation room itself, a little more will be required for the walls of the stairway leading to this room from the outside entrance. If your Department provided the material,
the School Management informed me that they could do
the work, and I beg to recommend that Mr. Indian Agent
Waddy be authorized to have this work taken in hand at
once.

There is always temptation for the bigger boys
to put paper and other combustible material into any
opening in the walls, and it is for this reason that I am
very anxious to have these repairs effected with the least
possible delay.

During the very severe weather which has pre-
vailed this winter, the boys had to spend more time than
usual in their recreation room, with the result that the
glass in the windows of this room was frequently broken.
Our Commission, of course, repair all such breakages but
they feel that expenditure in this connection might be con-
siderably reduced if the windows were protected by heavy
wire screens. I beg to request, therefore, that your au-
thorization to Mr. Indian Agent Waddy include this item as
well. The expenditure involved would not be very great.

Verandah Screens.

The upper verandah which runs along the front of
the main school building was provided some years ago with
mosquito screens, but the lower verandah was not supplied
with the same protection and the staff and pupils have suf-
fered very much in consequence. I beg to request, therefore,
that authority also be given to Mr. Indian Agent Waddy to have
the screens on the upper verandah repaired, and the whole of the
lower verandah provided with this very necessary protection
against these venomous and very troublesome insects.

Inside Toilets

For some reason or other this school was never pro-
vided with inside toilets in the basement for the use of either
the boys or girls, two outside toilets being provided to take
their place during the day time. This arrangement is very un-
satisfactory in many ways, and especially from the standpoint
of health. As it would not involve a very heavy expenditure
to have two inside toilets installed, I beg to recommend that
your representative be authorized to take the necessary action
in this respect also.
Commending the above matters to your careful and sympathetic consideration,

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Sir:—

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 10th instant, 128-1-5, informing me that the Church authorities have strongly represented that a Principal's residence is required at the McKay Indian Residential School if it is hoped to obtain and retain the services of a properly qualified gentleman to manage the institution. In reply I beg to say that I have always advocated that the Principal of an Indian Residential School live in a detached residence. That is what I pressed for in connection with the Blood School and also when it was decided to have the teacher in residence at Old Sun's. I would, therefore, advise that a Principal's residence be erected at the McKay School, but I cannot see how it would be possible to erect this building during the coming summer. The material could be taken up there by boat, but there is no proper landing and it would be a very difficult matter to get it unloaded and conveyed to the school. Would it not be better to make arrangements now to have the work of excavating done during the summer and have the material freighted by sleigh during the winter months, and proceed with the work of erection next spring?

We have several plans of houses here that I think would be suitable for a Principal's residence and the cost should be somewhere in the neighborhood of $7000.00 provided the houses is heated by hot air, which in my opinion is the proper thing for a house situated in the country. I should be glad to have your instructions in the matter.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary

Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 1st. instant, authorizing me to erect a Principal's residence at the MacKay Indian Residential School.

I may say that Mr. Waddy is here today, preparing to go north tonight. I have discussed this matter with him and his opinion, in which I concur, is that it would be well to let it stand until he comes home. He points out that there will be no Principal at the school during the summer and no one to supervise the work. I feel that if we can start at this building the 1st. of September it could be completed by the 31st. of October. A supervisor will be hired, and the freighting of material, which Mr. Waddy tells me can be done by wagon, will be looked after by the Indians. There are also several handy Indians who can assist the foreman on the building. I propose building a house similar to the residence which was erected for the Agent at Battleford - not exactly the same, but a building of that size, and the cost will be kept as low possible.

Sir:-

G. Tweddell, Indian agent, advising me that the work is progressing satisfactorily and that the carpenters are doing a first class job, but it is taking more time than was at first anticipated on account of having to draw every nail in the old siding before the new siding can be put on. The new house being erected for the Principal of the Mackay School was well along, being practically closed in, and the lathing was being started on the day I left. The house is 24 x 26, with 4 bedrooms and a bathroom upstairs and 1 small bedroom, kitchen, pantry, dining-room, living room and hall downstairs. The work, up to the present, has been well done, and the house, no doubt, will be warm and comfortable. The difficulties experienced in digging the septic tank and outlet have been very expensive, due to the rock formations. I instructed the Principal to have all drains and outlets covered with manure and old hay to prevent freezing, and if these instructions are carried out, I do not think any trouble will be experienced.

Dear Sir,

In accordance with your request of yesterday, I duly visited the McKay School and have the following report:

"The wiring in Mr. Turner's room does not show any defects. There is a small amount of current between conduit and one side of circuit, also between steam pipes and one side of circuit, but not sufficient to cause a fire. This is due to induction, as there is no short circuit.

The wiring for the top floor is not in conduit (in the attic), but should be as the ceiling is metal lathed, and knob & tube wiring is not allowable where metal lath or metallic ceiling is employed.

This constitutes a fire hazard and I consider it possible for a small arc to exist between the end of metal lath and building paper on the outside wall, connection to earth being made by frost or dampness on the paper, carrying the current. This would burn slowly, and a small portion of smoldering paper falling down between walls to plate on next floor could cause a fire. There is some evidence of the metal lath being heated at one spot, and there was fire between the studding.

Outside of this I could not detect anything likely to cause the fire from the Electrical Service.

I noticed that all the lighting outlets on the conduit sections have metal covers with unbushed holes for the drop cord. This is incorrect as in time the insulation will wear and cause a short. In several places the drop cord shows sign of wearing.

I found some joints in wiring not soldered.

It is peculiar that the Top Floor is wire in knob & tube, while the basement, first and second floors are wire in conduit.

I would respectfully suggest that the top floor be properly wired in conduit, and the whole conduit system bonded together and efficiently grounded.

The metal covers on lighting outlet boxes replaced with porcelain covers, the drop cord examined throughout, and also the joints in wiring.

Respectfully submitted,

(Sgd) Chas. W. Hill.
Dear Sir:-

I am enclosing a report from Mr. Hill, electrician which will explain itself.

I thought it would be much better to have inspection done by an expert, and if there was any defect in the wiring it could be remedied at your discretion, and prevent any recurrence of the trouble.

I presume that the buildings are insured and that an inspector will view the building, so as to fix damages etc.

In the meantime I can assure you that all necessary precautions are being observed.

I am pleased to inform you that everybody worked well including the carpenters, Dr. Robertson and the children were splendid.

The water supply from the pumps was poor as the cylinder is out of order. It seems that this cannot be remedied as the cylinder is down 62 feet and is joined to the casing. The only remedy would seem to be a new well drilled.

Happily the fire started at noon otherwise it might have been more serious.

I would estimate damage at $500.00.

Awaiting your approval and instructions.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd) W. G. Tweddell,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Re: Fire at MacKay Indian Residential School.

In reply to your letter #205-114 C.S. of the 3rd instant, asking for more accurate account of the fire at the above named school, I beg to reply as follows,

The opinion of those who visited the rooms which were damaged is that the fire started in Miss Cole's room between the outside and inside walls and that fire dropped down between the walls in Mr. Turner's room.

It was impossible when I got there to locate the exact spot where the fire started, as all the woodwork was charred and chopped and torn out, also part of the floor. Mr. Fraser had been in Mr. Turner's room just a short time before, and there was no sign of fire there then. Miss Cole who was sick and confined to her room smelled smoke first and gave the alarm.

It seems impossible to give an exact cause, no fire was being used in the rooms as they are heated by steam. As the fire was between the walls the only source from which it could emanate would be the wiring or spontaneous combustion. Mr. Turner claims that the power was off at the time, as he was charging the batteries, but fire could smolder for a long time before it would flame. Boxed in between the walls once it broke into flame it would form a draft and spread rapidly.

My estimate of damages given you was a liberal one on account of claim for insurance. The damage is caused more by tearing, chopping and water - which was not spared. Mr. Turner's room has a metal ceiling which is not much damaged but Miss Cole's room was a plaster ceiling and the water has made it all fall so that it will have to be replastered also some of the walls in both rooms. A small portion of the floor in each room has been chopped and in such shape that we will have to be taken up for repairs. I do not think that the joists are much damaged, merely charred, that is where they can be seen.

I have again discussed the wiring and probable sources of fire with Mr. Hill and he states that he cannot definitely place the cause of the fire but considers the wiring unsafe especially on the top floor where it does not comply with regulations. I have asked Mr. Hill to make a report suggesting the repairs and alterations required also the cost of same which I will forward to you as soon as possible. Mr. J. S. Dickens is the only other electrician in The Pas.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd) W. G. Tweddell,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Heating Plant at MacKay School

I beg to inform you that I received a letter from Rev. Fraser, principal of the MacKay School, requesting that certain repairs be done to the heating plant and a new plate or arch be put in the fire box.

Mr. Turner, the school engineer informed me that a plate would cost about $200.00, however I visited the school with Mr. Sheddon and made an inspection with the following results.

By putting in some fire brick and fire clay the plate would last for a year or more. Recovering 4" steam pipe in boy's play room with three ply asbestos pipe covering, with asbestos cement fittings on steam main. Taking down radiator at rear entrance door, and refitting same in boy's lavatory. Boring and retapping radiation where necessary and fitting new air vents to same. Repacking all valves on radiators with asbestos packing. Altering steam risers at front of building, cutting and refitting same. The radiator in the boy's lavatory, is up at the ceiling, and is far too small. The one at the rear entrance is useless there, owing to the door being opened so much. The valves freeze and burst, so I thought it would be better to remove it and put it in the boy's lavatory. The entrance for valves in radiators are all eroded and leak steam, causing the flooring to raise. Mr. Sheddon offers to do all the repairs and furnish all material necessary for the sum of $145.00.

I beg to submit that this work is necessary.

Kindly instruct me if this offer is acceptable, or if I should call for tenders as there is one other plumber here.

Your obedient servant,

THE W&T
ORTHO-TOLIDIN TESTING OUTFIT
To Determine the Amount of Free Chlorine
IN WATER

In the sterilization of water by chlorine it is generally agreed that maximum results are secured when sufficient chlorine is applied to the water to leave a slight excess for a few minutes after treatment.

This excess is usually spoken of as "Residual" or "Free" chlorine. Authorities differ as to the amount of free chlorine that should be in a water to insure its freedom from microbes of disease, but in general we believe that 0.10 p.p.m. (parts per million) of free chlorine ten minutes after treatment will be sufficient. Obviously too much might cause tastes while too little would impair bacteriological efficiency. It is suggested in all cases that the State Department of Health be consulted concerning the desired amount of free chlorine. The importance of the free chlorine content of a water and the desirability of making quick and accurate tests, led to the development of the W & T Ortho-Tolidin Testing Outfit.

When ortho-tolidin solution is introduced into a water containing free chlorine the water turns yellow or orange,—the intensity of the color varying with the amount of free chlorine. The W & T Ortho-Tolidin Testing Outfit is a simple, scientifically calibrated device permitting the operator to match the color of the ortho-tolidin treated water against a known color standard and interpret the results in parts per million of free chlorine.

f.o.b. Newark, N. J. See illustration on last page.
DESCRIPTION OF EQUIPMENT

The outfit consists of a two-tube color comparator with a small transparent gauging tube, calibrated both to measure ortho-tolidin solution and to indicate free chlorine in parts per million. One of the color comparator tubes has a colorless glass base while the other is fitted with a colored glass which corresponds to a value of 0.05 parts of chlorine per million.

The color comparator tubes are opaque, the interior walls being threaded. This construction eliminates the errors due to light refraction which are experienced when glass tubes are used and also overcomes difficulties in reading due to reflected light from the sides of the tubes.

Each of the comparator tubes is fitted with a small valve at its base for lowering the level of the solution in the tube. This fundamental feature makes it possible, when comparing colors, to look through the same depth of liquid in both tubes and eliminates any error due to the natural color of the water being tested.

For convenience in carrying, a third tube is assembled with the comparator tubes and serves as a reservoir for the ortho-tolidin solution.

Descriptive Operation of the W&T Ortho-Tolidin Testing Outfit

Fig. 1—Have both comparator tubes "A" and "B" empty and clean. Hold testing outfit as shown and fill both comparator tubes within about one-half inch of the top with the water to be tested.

Note—The sample may be taken at such a point in the distribution system that ten minutes has elapsed since the introduction of chlorine, or the sample may be taken nearer the point of treatment and stored sufficiently long to give the ten minute contact period desired before filling the comparator tubes. In cold weather this ten minute period should be extended to fifteen minutes.

Fig. 2—Hold the transparent gauging pipette with the figures right side up, between the thumb and third finger, and the stopper from the ortho-tolidin reservoir between the thumb and the second finger. Insert the pipette in the ortho-tolidin reservoir. Place the forefinger securely over the top of the pipette, raise it out of the solution and by admitting air at the top by a slight releasing of the forefinger, drain solution from pipette back into the ortho-tolidin reservoir until the solution level in the pipette is opposite the red 1 c.c. mark. Introduce this 1 c.c. of ortho-tolidin solution into tube "A" (having the plain glass base).

Fig. 3—Securely replace the stopper in the ortho-tolidin reservoir, cover the comparator tubes with the palm of the hand, and invert repeatedly to insure thorough mixing. Allow to stand until the maximum color develops, which requires from one to two minutes, before making the color comparison. (In cold weather this interval should be extended to five minutes).

Fig. 4—The color of the solution in tube "A" (having the plain glass base) indicates the amount of free chlorine in the water. Lower the level of the solution in tube "A", by opening the valve at the bottom until it approximately matches the color in tube "B" (having the colored glass base). Now draw down the level of the solution in tube "B" until its level approximately equals that in tube "A". Now, make a second adjustment of the level in tube "A", to match the color in tube "B". In comparing colors hold the comparator tubes over a white surface, such as a piece of paper.

Fig. 5—With the colors matched insert the transparent gauging pipette in tube "A" with the figures right side up, until it touches the plain glass bottom. Place the forefinger securely over the top of the pipette, raise it up and read the calibration opposite the level of the liquid. This calibration indicates the free chlorine in parts per million.

Fig. 6—Empty and thoroughly rinse both comparator tubes.

Dear Sir:

Some time since, the Rev. A. Fraser, Principal of the MacKay Indian Residential School, The Pas, reported to me that the water at the school was bad.

I had the Provincial sanitary Inspector, Mr. Flattery, visit the school and take samples of the water from the well and from the supply tank. Upon analysis the water showed a count of over 10,000 bacteria per c.c. and colon bacilli positive 1 c.c. and 5 c.c. Samples were again taken on September 17th, 1930 which resulted as follows:

| Well      |                                                        | 10000|

This showed the water was considerably worse, and also showed that the water was not properly chlorinated.

On October 7th, I again visited the school with Mr. Flattery who again demonstrated to the staff the proper method of chlorinating the water, and I have had no complaint since.

In the meantime I have had the pupils and staff inoculated as a precautionary measure.

As Mr. Flattery advised me that the only safe measure was to put in a Wallace & Tiernan chlorinator, I thought it advisable to get a price on it. I enclose herewith correspondence from these people who state the full installation of same would cost $1473.00.

MACKAY INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

The classroom work is carried on in two rooms. The senior room is in charge of Miss Farrow, with an enrolment of 46 pupils, and the junior room with Miss Scott as teacher, with an enrolment of 40 pupils. These ladies are both qualified teachers, and use good methods in presenting the work. The children write well and appear to be fairly well along in their respective grades. However, these children will not speak out, and it is almost impossible to hear them read or answer any question. The discipline is only fair, and the children are very
are very lax in their carriage and manner of standing. Both the teachers are small of stature, which is somewhat a handicap in their endeavour to enforce discipline. I find this slackness throughout the institution, which no doubt increases the difficulty of enforcing proper discipline in the classroom.

The girls were neatly dressed and clean in appearance. The boys were a rough and ready lot, and it appeared as though little interest had been shown in their personal appearance, either by themselves or any member of the staff.

The classrooms are large and roomy with plenty of light and fresh air.

The building throughout was clean, and the windows all in good repair.

The dormitories I found to be clean. The beds were all neatly made, and I understand all bedding is washed every two weeks. Both the boys and girls are provided with nightgowns in which to sleep. The mattresses are in bad condition. Many have been re-covered, but this does not do away with the strong undesirable odour which I detected on entering the dormitories. New mattresses are badly needed.

The outside windows were all on, which makes ventilation more difficult. Two of the windows in each dormitory, facing on the large verandah, might have the upper half without glass, and these would need to be heavily screened so as to prevent the children escaping during the night. The inside windows could then either be raised or lowered from the top, as desired, in order

to prevent
to prevent draught. I believe this arrangement would greatly improve conditions.

The fire escapes have been improved by the new steps leading down on the verandahs from each dormitory. The water supply is good, but it is difficult, with the present pump, to keep up the pressure when once the fire hose are in use. There is one large fire extinguisher in the hall on the first, second and third story, but I think one should be supplied for the kitchen and one for the bakery, which is in the basement. I understand fire drill is observed, but I believe it should be practiced more often, especially at night.

The soft water cistern is in the basement. It is built in the middle of a large room, and the walls are about 6 ft. high. A small platform is built along one side, about 4 ft. high, on which the children stand in order to bail the water from the cistern. This is a dangerous arrangement, and the entire cistern, which is about 10' x 10' square, should be covered with plank and a proper pump supplied.

The tables in the children's dining room should be covered, as the boards have dried apart, and it is difficult to keep them clean and sanitary. Two or three of the tables, along with other furniture, came from the old Battleford institution and are past repair. These should be renewed. The walls leading to the entrance of the kitchen and the boys' playroom should be repaired. The plaster is off in places, and I think if these walls were covered with metallic sheeting, it would prevent further destruction and also lessen danger from fire.

There are
There are a number of places throughout the building where the plaster needs to be repaired, and this work should be carried out before any interior decorating is done. The building should be decorated throughout as the place is dark and gloomy, and has had little painting done for a number of years. The roof leaks in two places and this should be repaired at once as it is effecting the plaster and will cause it to fall. The roof could no doubt be patched for the present, although the shingles do not look good and it may be found necessary to re-shingle it in the near future.

The water supply has become contaminated, and it is necessary to treat it before being used. The last test showed it to be free of germs, but the treatment will need to be continued until further tests are made. I noticed the water trough for all the stock is just outside the pump house, and the stock coming there for water keeps the place dirty. I think if the water were piped to the barn and this trough removed, with the surroundings thoroughly cleaned, some of the trouble might be overcome. I understand there is a pipe line to the barn, but no one knows why the use of it had been discontinued. No doubt it froze at the barn, after which the trough was removed to its present location by the well.

The barn was clean and all tools neatly put away. The floor of the barn is badly worn in places, and should be renewed. A new chicken house has been erected, and next year Mr. Fraser said a start would be made to keep poultry. At present they have none.

I saw the horses and cattle, and their condition has greatly improved. I believe they are receiving some care and attention, and this year they have obtained
about 100 loads of hay, so that no shortage should occur. The present bull has been at the school four years, and should be disposed of.

The meals provided are plain, but well cooked. The breakfast consists of porridge with sugar and milk when possible, also bread with lard or butter, and tea. At noon, the meal consists of meat or fish with potatoes, carrots or some other vegetable. Bread and tea are also given. The supper consists of boiled puddings (rice or batter pudding), Johnny cake, bread, grease and tea. The children looked well, and I believe receive plenty of whatever is served.

The staff consists of the following members:

| Position                  | Name                      |
|---------------------------|---------------------------|
| Principal                 | Rev. A. Fraser            |
| Mechanic                  | Mr. Turner                |
| Farming Instructor        | Mr. White                 |
| Night Watchman            | Mr. Fraser (Principal's Son) |
| Matron                    | Miss Warnener             |
| Sr. Teacher               | Miss Farrow               |
| Jr. Teacher               | Miss Scott                |
| Boys' Matron              | Miss Griffiths             |
| Laundry Matron            | Miss Northwood            |
| Kitchen Matron            | Mrs. Evans                |
| Sewing Matron             | Miss Fraser (Principal's daughter) |

I found many improvements made during the last year, and the building and yards are in better condition, and yet there is room for vast improvement.

The boys have no supervision during recreation hours, and apparently are left to run wild. They are ill-mannered, and I do not think the staff have much control. I believe if a proper boys' supervisor were secured, and he would need to be a real man, it would be a big step towards handling the children. This would also strengthen the authority of the other members, who at present find themselves often unable
often unable to control the children. This situation applies to both the girls and boys. To my mind this is the weak spot of the institution, and until someone is placed in charge or made a member of the staff, who can handle children and enforce discipline, the object of the school will be defeated.

I find Mr. Fraser, the Principal, apparently willing to carry out any suggestions, and considering the condition existing when he assumed control, less than a year ago, progress has been made. He is not, however, a disciplinarian, and as a result, the children are not receiving the training along this line which they much require. A man as boys' supervisor, who is a disciplinarian, would make a vast difference in the tone of the institution, and I think the other members would find it less difficult to control the children.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

THE W&T CHLORO-CLOCK

WATER supplies at camps, on private estates, at institutions and where consumption is relatively small, are readily chlorinated with the W&T chloro-clock. Small swimming pools can be adequately sterilized with this equipment.

The chloro-clock is designed to accurately feed small quantities of prepared sterilizing solution. Such solutions are generally available and, where the daily water consumption does not justify the installation of larger types of chlorine gas control apparatus, are to be recommended.

The apparatus operates on the displacement principle, the control being obtained from a clock work mechanism which actuates an arm from which a displacing cylinder is suspended. The rate of solution feed is adjusted by means of a pendulum lever and is arranged so that the contents of the cylinder container can be discharged in varying quantities ranging from 30 hours to 8 days. A water supply under pressure feeds the small constant level box into which the solution drops. The same water supply also operates an injector which draws from the constant level box and applies the diluted sterilizing solution to the desired point of application.

The chloro-clock is started in operation by turning on the water supply and moving a lever which starts the clock mechanism in motion. Raising the weighted cylinder for filling the container jar automatically winds the clock mechanism.

Height: 67 in. Width: 12 in. Depth: 18 in.

Specifications

The equipment shall be a self-contained unit mounted on a cast-iron base and with suitable metal support. It shall be suitable for feeding a hypochlorite sterilizing solution of definite strength and shall operate on the displacement principle, the control being obtained from a clock-work mechanism which actuates an arm from which a displacing cylinder is suspended. The rate of feed of solution shall be adjustable by means of a pendulum lever so arranged that the contents of the cylinder container can be discharged at varying rates as required from 20 hours to 8 days.

Where the sterilizing solution must be applied against a positive pressure, the equipment shall be provided with an injector operated by an external water supply under pressure and drawing from a constant level float box so placed as to receive the sterilizing solution that flows from the cylinder container.

All parts of the equipment with which the chlorine sterilizing solution comes in contact shall be of materials resistant to the action of sterilizing solution. All parts of the clock-work mechanism shall be properly protected but easily accessible and so designed that raising the weighted displacement cylinder will automatically wind the clock mechanism.

Guarantee: The apparatus shall be guaranteed against all inherent mechanical defects for a period of one year from date of shipment from factory.

THE W&T
ORTHO-TOLIDIN TESTING OUTFIT
To Determine the Amount of Free Chlorine
IN WATER

In the sterilization of water by chlorine it is generally agreed that maximum results are secured when sufficient chlorine is applied to the water to leave a slight excess for a few minutes after treatment.

This excess is usually spoken of as "Residual" or "Free" chlorine. Authorities differ as to the amount of free chlorine that should be in a water to insure its freedom from microbes of disease, but in general we believe that 0.10 p.p.m. (parts per million) of free chlorine ten minutes after treatment will be sufficient. Obviously too much might cause tastes while too little would impair bacteriological efficiency. It is suggested in all cases that the State Department of Health be consulted concerning the desired amount of free chlorine. The importance of the free chlorine content of a water and the desirability of making quick and accurate tests, led to the development of the W & T Ortho-Tolidin Testing Outfit.

When ortho-tolidin solution is introduced into a water containing free chlorine the water turns yellow or orange,—the intensity of the color varying with the amount of free chlorine. The W & T Ortho-Tolidin Testing Outfit is a simple, scientifically calibrated device permitting the operator to match the color of the ortho-tolidin treated water against a known color standard and interpret the results in parts per million of free chlorine.

Price: $____ f.o.b. Newark, N. J. See illustration on last page.
DESCRIPTION OF EQUIPMENT

The outfit consists of a two-tube color comparator with a small transparent gauging tube, calibrated both to measure ortho-tolidin solution and to indicate free chlorine in parts per million. One of the color comparator tubes has a colorless glass base while the other is fitted with a colored glass which corresponds to a value of 0.05 parts of chlorine per million.

The color comparator tubes are opaque, the interior walls being threaded. This construction eliminates the errors due to light refraction which are experienced when glass tubes are used and also overcomes difficulties in reading due to reflected light from the sides of the tubes.

Each of the comparator tubes is fitted with a small valve at its base for lowering the level of the solution in the tube. This fundamental feature makes it possible, when comparing colors, to look through the same depth of liquid in both tubes and eliminates any error due to the natural color of the water being tested.

For convenience in carrying, a third tube is assembled with the comparator tubes and serves as a reservoir for the ortho-tolidin solution.

Descriptive Operation of the W&T Ortho-Tolidin Testing Outfit

Fig. 1—Have both comparator tubes "A" and "B" empty and clean. Hold testing outfit as shown and fill both comparator tubes within about one-half inch of the top with the water to be tested.

Note.—The sample may be taken at such a point in the distribution system that ten minutes has elapsed since the introduction of chlorine,—or the sample may be taken nearer the point of treatment and stored sufficiently long to give the ten minute contact period desired before filling the comparator tubes. In cold weather this ten minute period should be extended to fifteen minutes.

Fig. 2—Hold the transparent gauging pipette with the figures right side up, between the thumb and third finger, and the stopper from the ortho-tolidin reservoir between the thumb and the second finger. Insert the pipette in the ortho-tolidin reservoir. Place the forefinger securely over the top of the pipette,—raise it out of the solution and by admitting air at the top by a slight releasing of the forefinger, drain solution from pipette back into the ortho-tolidin reservoir until the solution level in the pipette is opposite the red 1 c.c. mark. Introduce this 1 c.c. of ortho-tolidin solution into tube "A" (having the plain glass base).

Fig. 3—Securely replace the stopper in the ortho-tolidin reservoir, cover the comparator tubes with the palm of the hand, and invert repeatedly to insure thorough mixing. Allow to stand until the maximum color develops, which requires from one to two minutes, before making the color comparison. (In cold weather this interval should be extended to five minutes).

Fig. 4—The color of the solution in tube "A" (having the plain glass base) indicates the amount of free chlorine in the water. Lower the level of the solution in tube "A" by opening the valve at the bottom, until it approximately matches the color in tube "B", having the colored glass base). Now draw down the level of the solution in tube "B" until its level approximately equals that in tube "A". Now make a second adjustment of the level in tube "A" to match the color in tube "B". In comparing colors hold the comparator tubes over a white surface, such as a piece of paper.

Fig. 5—With the colors matched insert the transparent gauging pipette in tube "A" with the figures right side up, until it touches the plain glass bottom. Place the forefinger securely over the top of the pipette,—raise it up and read the calibration opposite the level of the liquid. This calibration indicates the free chlorine in parts per million.

Fig. 6—Empty and thoroughly rinse both comparator tubes.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I would draw your attention to the following paragraph on Page 8 of Inspector Hamilton's report on the schools in The Pas Agency, which concerns the Mackay Indian Residential School:

"All doors leading to the fire escapes are locked. The Principal and Matron claim they can do nothing else as the children run away at every opportunity."

I am of the opinion that this is a terrible thing. In the event of a fire taking place at this school, we would undoubtedly have a repetition of what has taken place in recent fires at schools in the north; there would be a panic, the children would pile up in front of the doors, and in all probability there would be a great loss of life.

In my opinion instructions by wire should be issued to the Principal to have the locks taken off these doors at once.

Ottawa, December 5th, 1931.

Sir,

The Department wishes to refer to the question of fire escapes at the MacKay Indian Residential School. I understand that the doors are locked and that two members of the staff are appointed to each dormitory, with keys in their possession to open doors leading to fire escapes. This precaution is not sufficient and I have to authorize you or the Reverend Principal to have extra keys made for these fire escapes immediately. They should be placed in little boxes hung at each door and the front of the boxes to be made of glass, which can be broken in the event of fire. In addition to the members of the staff who are responsible for the dormitory and for the exits, there should be in each two beds closest to the fire escapes the most responsible pupils in the school, who will receive strict instructions as to what action they should take in the event of fire. In the case of the dormitories for small boys and small girls, at least one of the oldest and most reliable pupils should be in the dormitory and should sleep at the fire exit.

Further, regular fire drill should be held at various times during the day but particularly when the pupils are in the dormitories. The night watchman, of course, must be a thoroughly reliable man, who will constantly patrol the building during the night.

I am sending an extra copy of this letter to the Reverend Principal for his information.

You may spend, approximately, $50.00 for material and labour in repairing the cupboards in the junior classroom at this school. You should, also, arrange to have metal binding on the edges of the linoleum on the dining room tables. Brass tape is quite suitable for this purpose. The materials needed should be purchased from indicated sources.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Storage battery & Generating plant at the McKak Indian Residential School, Big Eddy.

Dear Sir:

Col. Mermagen, Assistant Secretary-Treasurer of our Commission, visited the Mackay School during the month of August, and in his report recommended that the Principal be instructed to take up with the Indian Agent the question of having the steel pole fire escapes which were removed some years ago, reinstalled. When these poles were removed, wooden stairways were built to take their place, and he describes these as being "steep, flimsy and a positive menace". Why the steel poles were removed, and the wooden stairways supplied to take their place, I am, at the moment, unable to determine, but the poles are still there, and as they could be installed without incurring any great expenditure, and the wooden stairways removed, our Commission recommend that you instruct your representative at The Pas to take the matter up with the Rev. Principal Fraser, and have this part of the school's fire protection system placed on a more satisfactory basis. A few years ago you authorized the installation of steel poles at our Lac la Ronge School, and these have proved very satisfactory at that institution. Our Commission believe that it would be a wise procedure to have the steel poles re-installed at the Mackay School.

While writing about this matter I beg to state that the Assistant Secretary-Treasurer of our Commission in his report referred to the need of a new barn, and of an ice house at this school, and our Commission sincerely hope that provision may be made in the departmental estimates for the fiscal year 1933-34 to build the same.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Reverend Sir,-

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 27th ultimo, with reference to the fire escapes at the MacKay Indian Residential School.

In November, 1929, the Department received a letter from the Assistant Deputy Minister of Public Works in Winnipeg, in which he stated that the MacKay Residential School had recently been visited by the Building Inspector of the town of The Pas. In commenting on the Building Inspector's report, the Assistant Deputy Minister's letter reads, in part, as follows:

"Reference is made to the brass rod fire escape system. This, as an efficient fire escape, went out of date in Manitoba long ago and the only fire escape we consider satisfactory is the stairway type or, better still, the metal chute."

Following consideration of this report, the Indian Agent was instructed to install the stairway type of fire escape. I note from your recent letter that Col. Mermagen states that these are "steep, flimsy and a positive menace" and, in view of this report, the Department is writing to the Agent.

The need of a new barn and an ice house at the MacKay School has been noted but, at the present time, the Department is not in a position to state if funds will be available for their erection next year.

Your obedient servant,
