Sir:

Mr. Inspector Hamilton, who recently visited the MacKay Indian Residential School in September, last, reports as follows regarding the toilets:

"The toilets, especially in the girls' dormitories, were very offensive and certainly have not been properly looked after. I pointed this out to both Mr. Fraser and the Matron, as there is no reason why these cannot be kept clean, and the ones in the dormitories should certainly receive special attention. The bathtubs were also dirty and had not been looked after since last being in use."

You should draw this matter to the attention of the Principal. There does not appear any reason why these toilets and bathtubs cannot be kept in a clean and sanitary condition.

The Inspector states further that the boys were dressed in overalls and shirts, some of which were ragged and untidy. This matter should also be drawn to the attention of the Principal and he should arrange to see that this condition is remedied at the earliest possible date.

Further, the Inspector drew attention to the menu served the pupils. He states that, for the noon meal, no butter or lard is served, that the children receive only water to drink and that desserts are not served at this meal. He also reports that the supper meal appears rather light, in view of what the pupils receive for dinner. It is considered that the children should be given either milk or a hot drink - tea or cocoa - with the noon meal. You might report whether milk is served the pupils and the quantity used at the school each day. Milk is an important item of diet, especially for the younger children.

Attention is drawn to the case of one of the pupils who had been placed in St. Anthony's Hospital to receive treatment for an infectious skin disease. The Inspector considered that this child could quite well have been cared for at the school and isolated in the hospital ward. Please inform the Principal

S. Lovell, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.
that it is expected, in the case of minor illness, the pupils should receive treatment at the school and it is not necessary to incur the expenditure of having them sent to hospital.

Dear Sir,

Re The McKay Indian Boarding School Heating Boiler.

I have inspected this boiler as per your request, with special reference to the Iron Arch & brickwork above the same.
The arch is down very low and the brickwork has fallen into the firehole. This has left the flue open direct to boiler end, at the front, i.e. above the firedoor.
The iron arch is very badly warped, and it is very doubtful whether or not it can be used again.
It is generally conceded the iron arch is a thing of the past, and I would respectfully suggest to you that it be dispensed with in favor of Plibrico Jointless Firebrick. This would replace the iron arch, also the brickwork above it.
For a return tubular boiler, this is the most logical thing to use.
One installed in a boiler of this class, it eliminates the necessity of taking down the outside brickwork to get the iron arch in. It can be economically repaired, as any burnt portion (say near the firebars at the side) can be cut out and a new portion dovetailed in.
I attach hereto an estimate for this work, and await your further commands.

Yours truly,

Deputy Superintendent General,

Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Dr. McGill:

As instructed by Department wire of March 24th, I left for The Pas and carefully checked all property remaining at the MacKay Residential School. Attached will be found an inventory of all property.

Mr. Fraser the present man in charge is unable to say who the owner is in relation to some of the stock and also many of the implements. Undoubtedly all the small items were purchased through the Church Commission and consequently they are claimed by the church authorities.

Some years ago the school was supplied with nine cows and these have increased to over thirty head, although in the meantime a number have been butchered. Of the original stock only three head remain, and the Principal intimated that is all the Dept., are entitled to. However one would imagine the nine head should be returned or replaced. These are matters, however, for the Dept., to decide. The same situation exists in relation to the horses.

I checked over the machinery which passed through the fire and all that remains, which would perhaps be of use again is the boiler, two pressure tanks and a small water pump. The Principal and Engineer were both instructed to drain the boiler but this had not been done. Fortunately the water was still warm and apparently the boiler was not damaged. I had it drained to-day. The jacket heater had also been left and froze, destroying it for any further use. All laundry machinery and other equipment appears totally destroyed.

The electric light plant which includes the engine 10 H.P. generator, batteries and switch-board are in splendid condition. The two smaller engines are in fair running order. The above machinery and equipment could perhaps be used at some other school, and the batteries and switch-board should be packed and transferred as soon as possible.

The motor boat has been neglected and is in need of repairs. The engine is disconnected and stored in the warehouse, but I understand to be in good condition. This boat, according to the Principal, has not travelled 100 miles. I would recommend that the boat be repaired, the engine installed and that the same be kept as an Indian Department boat for the paying of Treaty and the shipping of supplies to Moose Lake, Cedar Lake and Chipewyan.

It is necessary each year to rent a boat for certain Treaty payments and this costs over £100. Further expense is incurred when rations are shipped. These expenses might well be eliminated by retaining this boat, which cost a large sum, and I doubt if we could even secure a bid for it, if put up for sale.

Cont'd on page 2
The horses number six with two colts raising three year old. Three of the horses I am informed were purchased by the Church Commission, the other three and the two colts I presume are Department stock. The three horses might be issued to the Indians at Loose Lake and Cedar Lake where they are very much in need of such assistance. These Indians often find it hard to secure enough hay, because they have no horses to work, and many are obliged to cut all their hay by the use of scythes. The team of colts would make splendid drivers for the Agency use. In the winter it is difficult to secure good horses and the livery bill for the Agent, Doctor and Nurse reaches quite a sum. Horses could also be used on The Pas Reserve in the summer and thus eliminate a large percentage of the taxi service livery charges for the Agent, Doctor and Nurse. I am sure average over $25.00 per month. No doubt some of the older harness belongs to the Department.

The democrat and sleighs could be used at the Agency, but the Principal claims the same is church property.

The wagons, harrows, disc, plows, sleighs, mower, rake, are old, and perhaps were supplied by the Department. They have done many years of service, and I think would render most value to the Department if issued to the Indians on the out lying Reserves. The equipment would help them in gathering and haying. I doubt if this machinery would be worth shipping south to outside points.

There is as noted by the inventory, other machinery, but I am informed it was purchased by the Church Commission. If such is not the case, I think it could well be disposed of in the manner suggested above.

The dining room suite and range in the Principal's residence is Department property. It has been in constant use but is in fair condition. The Principal expressed his desire to purchase both and this would perhaps be the best way to dispose of it. To place it with the second-hand dealer at The Pas would be the only alternative and would result in little return.

I regret that a more definite understanding could not be arrived at in regard to the property, but as the large bulk of it was supplied before Mr. Fraser's time or my own, it was difficult to arrive at what property belonged to the Church and what actually could be termed Government property.

The following list of buildings remain:

- Principal's Residence
- Barn
- Warehouse
- Chicken House
- Power House
- Ice House (partly burned)

At the present time these buildings could not be disposed of and I doubt if any reliable party would wish to live there. Rev. Fraser requests that he be left in possession at least till the end of June, and this no doubt would be the best arrangement. After that it would be necessary to board up all windows and doors until such time same can be disposed of.

Your obedient servant,

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Manitoba.

Sir:

I have been directed to acknowledge receipt of your letters of the 31st ultimo and 4th instant, regarding the inventory which you forwarded of the property remaining on hand at the MacKay Indian Residential School after the building was destroyed by fire. The difficulty in deciding the ownership as between the Department and Church authorities has been noted.

In this connection it is considered that the authorities of the M.S.C.C. should appoint an officer - either the Rev. Mr. Fraser, the Principal, or another party - and that you or Mr. Agent Lovell should arrange with the person appointed by the Church authorities for a selection of the stock, equipment and supplies remaining on hand. When their selection has been made, they should arrange as soon as possible to have the supplies distributed.

Regarding the cows, it is considered that, as the Department some time ago supplied nine cows, although only three of the original number remain, the original number, viz., nine, should be transferred to this Department. The cows transferred to this Department should be sent to either the Nelson House Reserve or the Cedar Lake Indians, as decided by the Agent and yourself. The cost of transportation should be kept as low as possible.

Regarding the horses, it is considered that at least three should be transferred to this Department. If this number are acquired, they should be issued to the Indians at Moose Lake and Cedar Lake. If the team of colts is turned over to the Department, they should be kept for use in connection with the work of the Agent,

Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 31st ultimo, I have to say that you may arrange for the demolishing of the two cement chimneys which are still standing on the site of the Mackay Indian Residential School as, you state, they are a source of danger. It is noted you estimate the cost to be approximately $15. I enclose an Encumbrance Certificate providing the funds required for this purpose, which amount should not be exceeded. After the work has been completed, please forward a certified voucher, in triplicate, covering the cost.

The Department recently received from Mr. Inspector Hamilton an inventory of the property remaining on hand at the school. It would appear that there is some difficulty in deciding the ownership as between the Department and the Church authorities. The Inspector has been requested to arrange with you and the officer appointed by the Church authorities for the disposition of the stock, equipment and supplies remaining on hand. The Department is anxious that all this equipment be disposed of and removed from the present premises as soon as possible. You will, no doubt, hear from Mr. Inspector Hamilton in due course.

Regarding the buildings that remain, I have to say that Rev. Mr. Fraser has been granted permission to reside in the residence until the end of June, next. You should arrange to see that the lighting equipment and any other supplies which are not distributed are properly stored in the remaining buildings and that these buildings are securely fastened. You should visit same from time to time to see that there is no damage incurred.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Sir:

With further reference to Department Letter No. 128-1-5 dated April 7th, in company with Actg. Agent Lovell and the Rev. Mr. Fraser, I have made a division of the property remaining at the MacKay Indian Residential School, and attached is a list showing the distribution of same.

The property retained by our Department was issued, as far as possible, to meet the requests set forth in the Estimates. The scales and gates are not needed at The Pas and no doubt at a later date can be transferred to some of our farming agencies.

One of Mr. Fraser's sons has kept the lighting plant in operation and the batteries up to the required charge. The Delco Light people state that these batteries, once having been charged, deteriorate quickly if neglected in this respect. The batteries and switchboard were supplied last fall at an approximate cost of $800.00, and I would not want anything to happen to them when no doubt there is some school or agency where they could be used. Mr. Lovell intimated that they might be sent to the Guy Residential School. However, as it was impossible, just at this period of the year, to get in communication with Father Doyon, the Principal, I am not in a position to say whether they are required or not. If the Department have no other place in mind where they wish the equipment to be sent, this matter could be considered as soon as communication opens up.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

The Rev.
The Rev. Mr. Fraser has not yet submitted his offer in connection with the dining room suite and range, but as soon as it arrives I will forward same to the Department. It may be possible that he will be unable to raise the required cash, and if such should be the case I would recommend, when Mr. Fraser leaves the residence, that the above furniture be stored in the Agency warehouse until it can be disposed of.

It was impossible to move the cattle as the ice had not gone out of the river and yet was not safe to cross. As soon as the river opens, the cattle will be placed in charge of a white man who is willing to look after them for the milk during the summer. Next winter six head will be shipped to Nelson House. The other four head of cattle and a team of horses will be taken to Chemawawin (Cedar Lake) and Moose Lake as soon as the river opens up. The machinery has already been moved from the school premises.

I experienced no difficulty in making the division of property and was assured by the Rev. Mr. Fraser and Dr. Westlake that they were entirely satisfied.

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

Dear Mr McKenzie,

Having been left in charge of the electric lighting plant, formerly of the Mackay School, The Pas, Man., by authority of Mr Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Affairs, for Manitoba.

I have been looking after the engines & keeping the batteries in shape ever since the 25th day of March, 1933.

I have no repairs for the engines and should they break-down, I have no authority to get new parts, and great harm would be done to the storage batteries.

Also I have not received any salary for this work, and I feel that I am entitled to receive some payment in return for my work, and I trust that you will look after this for me Sir.

I shall give you some idea of the plant, which I am looking after, and the shape & conditions, which that I found the engines & batteries in, when I took charge of the plant, on the 25th of March, 1933.

Hoping that this will be of some use & help to you, As they are worth good money, & it will be too bad if they cannot be put to work elsewhere.

On the day that I took over the plant I found the following.

there was a 6 HP, Fairbanks Morse Gas engine to run the generator for the lighting plant, it had been taken off the water pump, because the batteries had to be charged, & the big IO HP, Fairbanks-Morse Semi-Desile engine was out of commission.

Well this 6 HP gas engine gave a lot of trouble. It would run for half an hour time, then stop. So I had a look at it, & found that it was a little TRIP, which trips the magnetoe, of course it being broken, it would trip out of time, thus throwing the spark out of time, the only remedy, was to buy a new one.

I asked the commission, & the Indian Dept office for a new part, but was told that neither party had the authority to get it.

In the meantime the storage batteries would become discharged, and they were only 6 months old.

So I immediately left the 6 hp, engine, and started to overhaul the big IO hp, engine.

It had just had a new cylinder head & new rings, & a new eccentric arm, put onto it.

As the engine was too stiff to start by hand, I had to take the little 5 hp, engine & make it drive the big one until the new parts were working smoothly enough to allow
II
to allow me to start it by hand. It took three days to do
this, the engine running 12 hrs each day,
I also found the big engine out of time, so I adjusted
it, and it has been working nicely ever since,
of course the 10 hp engine could do with a new sleeve
& a new feed pump, but the engine will run nicely without
those parts for awhile yet. If new nozzle-tips & head gaskets
were supplied,
There should be another ten years life to that engine.

Now about the 6 hp, Fairbanks engine,
It has just had a new cylinder head, & new piston rings put
onto it, and for just the cost of a new (magnetoe) trip,
a new intake valve-exhaust valve, cylinder head gasket,
& a new spark plug,
this engine could be put into good running condition
and it should be good for another five years or more,
there is also a new magnetoe on this engine that must
have been bought only a short time ago.

Now the SAW engine,
A 5 hp, Fairbanks-morse engine, I hear it was a new engine
last fall, but it is a very sad looking piece of machinery
for a new engine,
I have overhauled it, The bearings are in fair condition,
& so is the magnetoe, but the valves were badly burnt
It needs a new gasket & a sparkplug, Also it should have a
new set of piston rings, they should be ten-thousandths
oversize,
I have ground the valves, but the engine needs a new
head gasket now, as the one I have on now lets water through
to the cylinder casing, & piston rings, and it is doing great
harm to cylinder casing, (scoring the cylinder casing)
I have also tried to get a new one, but I am told there
are no funds for it, but just the same the engine has to
pump water for the cattle & horse trough.
I would be very glad if you could get a new one soon.

Now the water pump.
All the bearings on it need rebabbitting & trueing up, also
you shall have to buy a new foot-pump cylinder casing, as
it is about 90 ft, down in the ground, and it would be of too
much expense to pull it up.
and if you have another place to move it to, I think
that the rest of the pump would be worth the expense.

Now we come to the storage batteries.
I understand that they were new batteries last fall, well
they certainly do not look like it now.
they have a rich deposit from the positive plates on the
bottom of the jars, which is over a ¼ of an inch in depth
and whenever the batteries begin to gas freely on charge,
this sediment starts moving, & settles over the plates
causing short circuit in each battery, and the only remedy
is to take the element, positive negative plates, out of
out of the containers, & wash them thoroughly, also the acid should be strained to keep the dirt out, then the jars washed out, and the batteries assembled, then the old acid put back into the jars, and new acid added to bring the specific gravity, of 1.250, (when I took over the batteries their specific gravity, averaged 1.160 to 1.165, but up to the present date I have only been able to reach a specific gravity of 1.210 to 1.215, and in their present condition, it is their full capacity.)

Now when the batteries are all assembled, they should be given the rejuvenation treatment, then these batteries should be good for another five years service, providing they are given proper care.

I think the main trouble with these batteries was that they were not charged often enough, by this I mean that more ampere hrs were taken out of the batteries in discharge than were put into them by charging.

And should you move the batteries to another place, It would be advisable to give them their treatment at their destination, because batteries would be disturbed through transit, and also it gives the operator a better chance to watch & care for the batteries.

The Switch board, --- There is only one thing wrong with it, There is a graphite resistance connection, about 5 inches long and as thick as a lead pencil,

I was informed that it was broken when they shipped the switch-board to The Mackay School,

It should be replaced, to enable the generator to give its best of service.

The Generator, --- It is in pretty dirty condition, and needs cleaning, also there is too much end play. It seems to me that a ball race is broken, but of course I am not sure what the fault is because as yet I have had no authority to overhaul it, but I knew that the end play should be taken out of it before it becomes damaged too much.

Also it needs new brushes, (carbon.)

Belts,--- there is only one belt that is in good condition, It belongs to the lighting plant, The pump belt is in poor condition, as it is made up of short lengths, and is always breaking apart.

Now Sir, I have covered all your machinery and I have tried to let you understand just what machinery you have up here, and their condition, and also the repairs that are needed that these engines might give satisfactory & economical service in future.

As I shall soon run out of fuel-oil, I wish you would allow me to get some, that I may keep the batteries up to their full capacity.

Yours Faithfully Howard L. Fraser
Ottawa, May 16, 1933.

Dear Sir:

Relative to our telephone conversation in connection with the 56 cell type KKH-13 rebuilt Exide battery located at The Pas, you have suggested that instructions have been given to have this battery dry stored until such time as it will be required for future use elsewhere.

We would strongly recommend that this should not be done but that instead the battery be flushed to the water line found on the jar, completely charged at a suitable rate (not more than 12 amperes) until all cells are gassing freely and the hydrometer does not show an increase in gravity for three hours, taking readings at intervals of one hour.

The foregoing being done it can be assumed that the battery is completely charged. We would then suggest that the cells be disconnected at the terminals, the top of the cell cleaned and all moisture removed, and the battery be allowed to remain in this condition until such time as it is disposed of. This can be done in its present location quite satisfactorily providing once every month to six weeks the battery is given a small charge or boost. If no one is available at the battery's present location, I am satisfied a reasonable charge would be made by a local battery dealer to maintain the cells for say a period of one year in their present condition.

We believe removing the acid and disturbing the element is more harmful to the battery than the general wear and tear that takes place if the element remained in solution. In addition it is a costly process to remove the acid as well as replace it and bring the battery back to full charge.

In making the foregoing recommendation we are assuming that the Department will have use for this battery at some time within a year in some other location.

Yours very truly,

EXIDE BATTERIES OF CANADA, LIMITED,
(Sgd) P.C. Armstrong
Manager, Winnipeg Branch.

Dear Sir:-

I am writing you today in reference to the Principal residence at The McKay School.

I feel that since the burning down of the McKay Residential school and there is a possibility that it may never be rebuilt again, it would be good business to have the residents of the Principal moved down to the nurses clinic building where it could be used for hospital purposes.

I wish to suggest that this be done at once and that it be fitted up at once for the care of less serious cases, the more serious cases would have to go to St Anthony's Hospital, of course.

There are some Tuberculous cases on the reserve that could be taken care of it if these cases are not allowed to go to the St. Anthony hospital.

As the care of the sick is at the expense of the Band's fund I think the full cost of bringing down the building and of fitting it up for a hospital building should be carried by the Government.

There is now a Government District Nurse employed, and she could -- live in this building at the same time taking care of the patients, with some one to help her perhaps.

In regard to the fuel for the winter it could be supplied at one half the cost of getting it in to town, by the Band who would earn some money for delivering it.

Please ask the Indian Department to consider this matter at once, as I feel that the matter is quite urgent.

Awaiting your action in this matter, we remain,

Yours Truly,

Dear Sir,-

Your letter 123-113, of June 12th, has been brought to my attention with the request of The Pas Band that the Principal's residence at the MacKay School be moved to the nurses clinic building for hospital purposes. The Department's impression is that this would not be a wise thing to do. The Department has a considerable investment in St. Anthony's Hospital, which appears to be a thoroughly up-to-date institution. It is very doubtful if patients could be maintained in a small building at less expense than in the hospital, and the expense of fitting up the building would be very considerable.

I am prepared to receive any further representations you wish to make in this matter, but at present can scarcely encourage the Band to think it can be done.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

In the comprehensive list of requirements for our Society's Schools for the fiscal year 1938-39, which I forwarded to you on the 15th inst., a new school on the Hudson Bay Railway was included. Shortly after I posted my letter to you I received the following information from the Rev. D.L. Greene, B.A., Rector of the Anglican Parish in The Pas, Manitoba:

"There is a magnificent outfit of buildings at Cormorant Lake—property of the Air Base—that are lying idle. The suggestion has been made by someone that they would make an excellent plant for an Indian School. Cormorant is at Mile 42, Hudson Bay Railway."

I myself know nothing whatever about these buildings, and while the location appears to me to be too much to one side of the vast area to be served by the school required, I thought it well to forward the information to you for any action you may feel disposed to take in the matter. Should the buildings mentioned be made available for the use of your Department, and should you agree to their being adapted to Indian Residential School work under the management of our Society, I would gladly undertake to inspect them in company with any representative of your Department you might name, and furnish you with a report of their suitability for the purpose suggested. While I am of the opinion that these buildings, considering the purpose for which they were originally established, are not likely to prove suitable for a large and permanent Indian Residential School, I feel that there is a possibility they might be made to serve for a few years for a limited number of pupils, until funds are available to provide the permanent structure required.
As the need of a School for the Anglican Indian children in the vast area between the Pas and the Western shore of Hudson Bay, has been dealt with in my letter of the 15th inst., I need not deal further with it now, but our desire to give these children the benefits which such a School would provide has prompted me to furnish you with the information received about the buildings at Cormorant Lake.

Yours very truly,

Re Airbase buildings at Cormorant Lake

Dear Doctor Westgate:

In compliance with your request I looked over these buildings on Monday and am favourably impressed with their possibilities for a temporary school at least. I have sketched a rough plan of the layout and will refer to the buildings in order as they appear from the left side of paper.

1. This is a frame building approximately 22' x 42'. It was the men's sleeping quarters and the caretaker told me it had 17 beds. It is lined with gyproc and at present is occupied by the caretaker and his wife who say it is a very comfortable house.

2. This is a large log construction. Logs are varnished and present a beautiful rustic appearance. It was the Officers Mess etc. The width is approximately 21'. There are two rooms each 33' long. The centre room was the main dining room. Then comes a 12' room which was officers' dining hall separated from the lounge or common room by an arch. The lounge is 19' long and has a nice fireplace. The kitchen 22' square opens into main dining room. It is well equipped with cupboards, etc. and still has a large range for cooking. Outside of kitchen is an ample refrigerator for use with ice. Over the front entrance is a commodious verandah.

3. This is a frame building also lined with gyproc. It is 22' by 42' and divided into three rooms—a large common room and two bedrooms 12 x 11. It was the Officer's quarters.

4. This was the store room about 22' x 50. It is lined with gyproc and is divided as indicated in sketch. The flooring is not so good as the others being rough spruce. This building has been disposed of to the Bishop of Keewatin for removal to Gillam for a residence for the Missionary. I understand it is to be demolished for this purpose in the spring and shipped to Gillam.

5. The radio house, a frame building about 30 feet square. The caretaker occupied this for a time and says he could re-occupy it if his present residence were required for school purposes.

6. An old log store room about 18 x 20.

7. The hangar, a magnificent oval roofed building about 95' x 80. Roof is supported by steel girders and floor is cement. This would make a wonderful indoor playground. There are tennis or badminton courts already marked out on it. All along each side are compartments formed by the supports for the girders that would make splendid places for work benches etc.

8. The workshop with door leading from hangar. This is bright and airy room with high ceiling. It is about 32' x 48' and would make two admirable school rooms. Along the side of this room are the electric light engine room, furnace rooms, and coal bin. The dynamo has been removed but the whole plant is wired for lighting. The furnace is still there but the blower has been removed.

There are some smaller constructions such as oil houses, gas tanks, and
There is also a bath house equipped with showers (which I have used in days past.)

Sir,

As instructed in your letter of the 25th of April, No. 37371/1, and after the treaty payments were over, I took up the question of a site for the Le Pas Indian Boarding School with the Chief and Council of that band. I took them up to the Big Eddy part of the reserve, about four miles from the town, as we all agreed that the quantity of land required could not be had on the reserve any closer to Le Pas than that point. There are eleven houses starting on the high land there, nearest to Le Pas, spread along the ridge for about one half a mile, about seventy feet elevation above the river, and we started to look for a site, and I engaged three Indians to cut lines and dig pits about a quarter of a mile north of the last house. We ran a line for about a quarter of a mile straight east through thick bush, (I might say that all of this part of the reserve is what may be called thick bush), and found that after we had gone one hundred yards we struck dry muskeg with hard stony bottom, and this continued for all the distance we ran the line.

I then went to Fisher Island, which is also completely covered with poplar bush, and went through it from south to north, about three quarters of a mile, without cutting a line, but had an Indian with a spade to dig small pits to enable us to judge the character of the soil. We found the soil so good that I decided to have two out across and the long way of the Island, so that I could have the levels taken and determine if it was high enough above the water for the purpose required. Mr. Stewart, a Civil Engineer, and myself took the levels, and we found on this Island everything required, good soil, high level, excellent drainage, a good lime stone quarry on the northwest quarter of about twenty five acres.
and as good water can be had, in wells all over this country, north of the Saskatchewan river, we can feel assured of that most important consideration for a site for such a building. Mr Fischer after looking over all the reserve, came to the same conclusion that in this whole north country, it would be hard to find another spot of the same size as good. I had test pits put down every three hundred feet on the lines cut and the soil was uniformly good.

I send you a tracing made by the Engineer showing the Island on a large scale, and also on a small scale, with the alternate eighty acres on the main land, and the levels of the island are also shown. There is a plateau on Fisher Island 2200 feet by 3400 feet, which lies from 20 to 28 feet above the present water level. You will notice by the profile a spot twenty feet above water level, and this is the proper location for the school, perfect drainage, as in 500 feet there is eighteen feet of a drop in the island, a great place for pits, if you wish to purify the sewage. Within one quarter of a mile of this site is situated the limestone quarry with enough good rubble stone to build all the buildings required.

I also ran a line, from a point on the main line nearest the Island, east for about a quarter of a mile, and found that the land for about nine hundred yards is fairly good, then for 900 feet it is muskeg nearly to the bottom of the ridge. There is then a sudden rise of hill too steep for teams in the next 350 feet, or in all 2150 feet from the water to the ridge road. This line is just ninety yards north of the last house. All this high ridge is solid gravel fourteen feet deep to blue clay as shown by two wells at the Indian houses. There is from six to twelve inches of fair soil on the top of this gravel, and potatoes grow very well in a wet season, but are not a success in a dry one. This eighty acres alternate mentioned would be
a good site for the buildings, if nothing more was required, but in view of all the requirements I would strongly recommend the Island as the building site.

I enclose you surrender of the Island, and attached thereto a resolution re the alternate eighty acres, passed unanimously by the band, which speaks for itself. I also send you my office copy of the reserve showing where we ran the lines, and would like same returned. If the Department decide to take the Island, it will be necessary at once to clear of bush say twenty acres, and I would suggest that while I am at Le Pas, I be authorized to get the Indians to clear this land. To connect this Island with the main land by a pile bridge sixteen feet wide will cost about $2500.00, three hundred and fifty feet with at present four feet of water. I got a rough estimate of cost from the Finger Lumber Company.

Yours truly,

J.D. McLean, Esq., Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Ass't Deputy and Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario
Mr. Pedley,

Mr. Inspector Jackson, acting under instructions given him in April, last, to select a site for the proposed new boarding school at The Pas, reports that after going into the question of a suitable site with the Chief and Councillors and a careful examination of the different places suggested by himself and Mr. Stewart, a Civil Engineer, he is satisfied that Fisher Island is admirably adapted for the school. It contains about 350 acres, good soil, high level, excellent drainage and a good limestone quarry of about 25 acres and good water can be had. Mr. Fischer, our Agent, came to the same conclusion. They also examined a suggested site on the Big Eddy part of the reserve, about four miles from the town, and came to the conclusion that the quantity of land required could not be had and that the soil was unsuitable. Mr. Jackson obtained a surrender of the Island site and attached thereto a resolution re. the alternate eighty acres, agreeing to exchange this site for an equal quantity of land on Fisher Island should the Department wish to place the school on the mainland.
In view of Mr. Jackson's report Fisher Island is the most suitable site for a boarding school and the Department would do well to accept the surrender and have it put through Council in the usual way.

I may mention that there were no tenders received for the erection of the school at The Pas, which were called for sometime ago, and it is too late to do anything this fall, but the surrender could be accepted and tenders called for next spring.

Gideon Halcrow J.P., late Manager of the Hudson's Bay Company's Post at The Pas, is over 65 years of age and has been at and around the Pas for over 35 years, and remembers all the high water for that length of time. The highest water known was about 10 or 11 years ago, at that time before the flood Fisher Island was only separated from the main land by a very small creek. The flood of that year opened up quite a big channel, as the Saskatchewan River came over a low place in its banks about 2 miles west of the island and filled up the lakes and the pressure of water opened up this channel. I have known Fisher Island for all of these 35 years, and never knew of its being flooded and I would have known of it if such a thing had happened. When the Indians selected their reserve in the first place they took only high lands, and among them Fisher Island, what low lands they took were for hay lands, and Fisher Island has always been covered with wood, which shows it was picked for its elevation above the water and the quality of its land.

Joseph McGillivray Sr., No. 104 of the Pas Band is 85 years old. He knows Fisher Island well; he has been up there since he was a boy 18 years of age, or every year for 67 years, and never knew or heard of this Island being flooded. He has seen 3 big floods about 28 years ago was the biggest flood he has ever seen, and the next biggest was about 10 or 11 years ago, and the only land up there not flooded was Fisher Island, and the Big Eddy. All of the country across from where he lived south and west was under water. He was living where The Pas Town now is at that time and it was not flooded.

Simon Cook a Non Treaty Indian, lives up at the Big Eddy back of the reserve. He knows Fisher Island since he was a child, his Grandfather picked out the Island as high land to live on, and they lived on this place for over 30 years, and then they came back to the main land. At the time they were on the island they were Pagan Indians, but Chief Constant got them to join the English Church, and then they moved back on the main reserve. He says that ever since the world was made this island was dry land, except when Noah made the Ark, and all the world was flooded, he knows the site on the island where the school is going to be built, having seen the lines cleared within the last few days, and he says that the land there is good for farming. He remembers that there were a number of big floods but the biggest of all was the one about 27 years ago, at the time of this flood he had a house on the Island and lived there, the water came to the willows on the north west side of the island about 5 feet of a rise. When the flood was on, the island was as big as ever, you would not know the difference. They had a garden on the island for about 30 years, and grew the best of potatoes, corn, turnips, onions, and all the other smaller vegetables, they also ripened barley and wheat in their garden. There could not be found as good a place as this island, on the whole of the Pas Reserve.

Sir,

The conditions at the Island are just the same as in the Stonewall district, there we bore a six inch hole to the rock put in piping from the ground to rock, anywhere from 6 to 25 feet, and then bore a five inch hole in the rock till we find a good supply of water, always under a hundred feet.

April 7th, 1914

Dear Mr. Scott,

There are still one or two matters I wish to bring before you re. the Pas Boarding School.

For the greater economy of the management of the School, & that is, for the benefit of the I.D., certain things should be done now or during the summer to prepare for occupation. The people at the school, whether pupils or staff, will want fuel & food from the start, the cost of which may be much lessened by forethought. (1) 400 cords of wood should be cut & piled from the school property, & 1/2 an acre would be broken up into little plots for potatoes. As to (1), I reminded the I.D. of this a year ago, & suggested that as the ground is cleared for building the wood should be piled, etc. I approved the suggestion—thought. But I am informed that those who cleared the land were allowed to pile & cut the timber—a shocking waste. But the fuel will be needed, & should be ready, & the ground has been cleared—I can undertake to start with this big initial expenditure.

(2) This also is necessary & will fit in with (1).

I would ask the I.D. to advance $1,000 ($500 expended on fuel preparation & 1/2 potato-planting; as much as possible, but not more than $1,000) as a grant, the balance to be an advance. We need...

VERRY POOR COPY
by degrees, by the School in the first year or two. The Church in Saskatchewan has no money to advance in this purpose, so it seems wise to be fairly referable to the S.D. We are then prepared to get the work done. I have appointed a young man to that mission for the summer whose services should enable him to look after the potato planting & cultivation. I am trying to get tenders for (a) cutting & picking in cords 400 cords of wood & (b) breaking 5 acres for potatoes. I hope you will be able to meet me in this matter, as it will simplify matters. There is no time to lose if this is to be done.

The well-water is very hard, the river water is hard, & boiling it means much labour. There will be a great body of rain-water from the roof of all that building which should be saved. I hear there is not tank built in. Dear Mr. Scott,

I am writing the "McKay Boarding School." I wish you or some one from Ottawa interested in the Indians could be here between now & September to see the progress, almost wonderful, in the garden & surroundings. A large clearing, constantly growing, stumping & clearing up, growing a lovely fine potato & vegetable garden. It has meant much work & care, & the doing it has been a good training lesson to the boys. Everything seems in good order, & I think Mr. Laronde is showing good capacity.

Now, I wish to mention three things requiring the consideration & action of the J.S.C.

1. The no. of pupils authorized for Capitation grant should be increased from 50 to 100. Support last year is strongly in favor of it, & has privately written. At present there are 47 boys in the two dormitories, but each dormitory could take 26 & 23 beds without undue crowding, say 53 or 50 boys in all.

There are now 35 girls in their two dormitories, & these could be likewise increased to 53 or 55.

There are many applications now hope to facilitate
from Red Earth, Moore Lake, Cumberland, etc.

Speak of Miss from the Pass River, etc.

The staff also is large enough in this mission so that the school would pay better returns in the larger number. Discipline, health, conduct, are good, so I hope the S.D. will sanction the increase.

I believe Inspector Jackson asked for a supplementary grant of $250 toward the expense of clearing. I do not think he has yet heard the reply of the S.D. I most earnestly back his request. The clearing is very difficult a costly work. The amount of stumps & rocks not only makes the work hard, but also uses up a great number of tools. The work already done is marvelous. The Church in Saskatchewan is already in difficulties with the Bank & can not possibly grant a dollar towards this work, which belongs rather to the S.D. than to the Church.

A farm is entirely new land, a plant such a work, can not hope to reap any profit in two years. It is all expenditure at first. But I can confidently prophesy that in that time this farm will be paying its way & partly supporting the school.

I wish to speak in good time for a possible further request presently for financial help. It may not come again, but it may do so, if you may
We wait for the actual request, but may rely

after all my information. The Saskatchewan river has been high this land flooded as has not happened for years. Mr. Lariviere got to work early in anticipation a began cutting hay in the usual hay-grounds. He cut a great deal in three different places; but the flood rose rapidly, covered all of them, washing away all the cut grass. He only saved 5 or 6 loads, with every possible effort, where he had to haul while green, and dry them here. There is now no possible hay-cutting all around the place. The nearest he can get is up the Carrot River, some 40 miles away, so he is sending up the first load of workers' horses & machinery today. His men are hiring a steam-boat & barge to carry them up, & bring them down when all is cut. He will then haul the hay in winter, though he may have to fetch home some of it before that, when his hay runs out.

This will mean great expense for a young and half-green school-farm, & will cripple us greatly unless you help us—

Commending all these matters to your interest

I remain

your faithfully,

J. A. Maclean

I have come to the conclusion that it will be to the best interests of the school, to divide the amount of land the department would be willing to grant into two lots; that instead of one hay-reserve to set aside two for the school, one close at hand on the Saskatchewan and the other as a last resort, further away on the Carrot River. I have ventured to mark the suggested hay-lands on the map you sent me, marked hay-reserve Nos. 1 & 2.

Hay Reserve No. 1 would be seven miles up the Saskatchewan from the school, and would be at a convenient distance from the school, as compared with Hay-reserve No. 2 on the Carrot River which is about thirty miles from the School. A well defined ridge runs at right angles to the River and another ridge runs parallel for quite a distance. A line drawn East and West from a point half a mile from the North end of Big Island would mark the South boundary.

An interval of about three weeks elapses between the word of a flood at Edmonton and its arrival on the School Reserve, and there is a further interval of over two weeks before particular hay-field marked Hay-Reserve No. 1 is flooded; as the fields are flooded not by the overflow of the banks of the river but by the coming up of the water from the rear. In this way the month of July, by ignoring our own flats, and going to this hay-field on receipt of word of a flood, we could get hay and have it all stacked on the River-bank in good time.

Hay Reserve No. 2 would be located on the Carrot River, on Twenty-three miles from The Pas, on the West side of the river, about a mile above the Creek named Waskwei on the Map. We would be about a mile above Waskwei on the South bank, and our hay-field is further up on the North bank. This hay-field is very good, and it's only drawback is its distance from the school, but it should be dependable.

I desire to place before you two of the needs of this school toward which I would respectfully ask the kind assistance of the Department.

1. We need to bring more land into cultivation. The land is good, but it is wood land and very stony, and there is first of all plowing to do and then the stones to remove. If it were prairie land, where there is simply breaking to do, there would be no need for extra assistance, but breaking forest land involves a great deal of labour that is purely manual and necessarily expensive. We have now about 25 acres under cultivation, and, if we could have even twenty-five more, we should have a fair start. What we have under cultivation has helped greatly. Last season we raised over seven hundred bushels of potatoes and a fair crop of oats, besides over ten tons of roots and various vegetables. We were able to reduce our consumption of flour by at least sixty sacks, and we had no occasion to buy oats for our horses. From present appearances we shall have this year a larger crop of potatoes and oats, besides barley for our pigs, wheat for our poultry, and

The Deputy Superintendent
Indian Affairs
Ottawa
Poveshell corn for our cows. Our root crop will not be as good as last year, but that is owing to destruction by cutworms. There is sufficient encouragement in farming to make one feel that it would be a great help to have more land under cultivation.

2. It would be a great advantage if the road to the Reserve between this and the Big Eddy were improved. Most of the time during the season of open water, the only practicable way that we have of getting to the Oas is by boat between the Big Eddy and the Oas, and by wagon between the school and Big Eddy. Starting from the school, the road on the school island is good enough, and also on the gravel bed between the island and the mainland, for about a mile there is no improvement needed, then we come to a plough which should be corduroyed for about 100 yards. Then a distance of about 200 yards which is very muddy and sloppy, and then a steep hill which should be graded. The hill is mostly gravel. The work would be to grade the hill and draw the gravel to the lower part of the road.

In submitting these matters to your kind consideration, I am not losing sight of the fact that we should not ask for any extra expenditure in this time of need, but I would draw your attention to the fact that, owing to the attendance in the school being a good deal below the number allowed, our per capita grant is very much reduced.
For the last quarter we drew only $1806.75 instead of $2200 which we should have drawn if the School had been full. For the current quarter it will be about the same. Thus in two quarters we shall draw very nearly $800 below what we should have drawn with a full attendance.

Could the Department allow us $200 for improving the road and $400 for raising more land under cultivation? Such help would be thankfully received and carefully applied. If it is taken into consideration, it may be considered advisable to refer the matter of improving the road to your Agent here.

Yours, Sir,

Yours obediently & sincerely,

J.A. MacKay

RE SITE FOR MACKAY BOARDING SCHOOL

November 15th, 1911.—Letter from Bishop of Saskatchewan recommending site on Big Eddy Reserve.

December 7th, 1911.—Agent Fischer recommending Big Eddy Reserve.

January 5th, 1912.—Agent Jackson wrote stating that Pas Band were willing to surrender 320 acres of land as site for proposed school.

On April 25th, 1912, Inspector Jackson was instructed to receive the written consent of the Indians to surrender the land required, at the annuity payments. He was also instructed to pick out a suitable site.

August 23rd, 1912.—Inspector Jackson reported that an investigation he found land at Big Eddy Reserve, unsuitable, and recommended Fisher Island and enclosing surrender of same.

September 2nd, 1912.—Agent Fischer approves Fisher Island site.

September 14th, 1912, Inspector Jackson reports that with the Bishop of Saskatchewan, he had again gone over the Fisher Island site and that the Bishop approved it.

September, 27th, 1912.—Letter from Bishop approving Fisher Island site.

December 14th and 16th, 1912, Inspector Jackson sent letters from various Indians and old settlers expressing favourable opinion of the Fisher Island site.

November 30th, 1912 Departmental letters addressed to Inspector Jackson and Bishop of Saskatchewan informing these gentlemen that Fisher Island site had been decided on.

Dear Mr. Waddy,

With further reference to the hay-lands situated on the flats surrounding this island, I beg to report that owing to the unusually dry summer we were able to cut grass on portions of the land which are usually too wet. The whole of these flats is cut up by sloughs so that a large part of it is of no value as hayland. Even this year we have not cut more than 70 tons and have cut all the grass suitable for the making of hay. In an average year we could not cut many of the parts which we were able to use this season. Often the whole of these flats is under water during the early part of the year.

At the present time we have 23 head of stock and 5 horses to keep during the winter so that there will not be very much hay to spare. The number of stock is constantly increasing:- last year at this time we had only 18 head as against the 23 of this year.

I believe that a little more of the land can be made suitable for hay as stock increases by getting rid of some of the willow.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honor to report that, according to your instructions I left Regina on the morning of the 18th of May and proceeded to The Pas, Manitoba for the purpose of inspecting the Agency.

The location of the school and hospital is something that I cannot understand, and it is hard to figure out what Inspector Jackson had in mind when he picked out this site, as it certainly would have been hard to find a more unsuitable place. The only way to get at the school at the present time from The Pas is up the Saskatchewan River. During high water one can go up the river past the school and up the creek with a canoe, but there is water in this creek only during the Spring floods so when they have subsided the creek again becomes dry. Therefore it is necessary to land at the bend of the Big Eddy about a mile from the school, and about half of this distance is through a marsh. I wish to point out that the matter of getting in and out of the school is a vital question, and something that should be looked into. The Frindin was of the opinion that a tunnel could be dredged through the marsh from the river in front of the school so that they could get up and down with a canoe. However, from what experience I have had, think that this would be impracticable, as the tunnel would gradually fill up with mud as the water would be practically still. I am of the opinion that the most economical and satisfactory method would be to put a road across the marsh. The distance I have mentioned is about half a mile and this could be filled up with brush and logs. As there are piles of stone that the school has hauled off the cultivated land these could be put on the top of the brush and logs in the winter time. During the month of August, I was informed, this marsh dries up pretty well. At that time with a couple of slushes the stones and brush could be covered with earth and in this way a good road could be made across the marsh, thus making the school much more accessible. To do this it will be necessary for the Department to give the school some assistance.

The matter of hay land for the school is another important question. There is no hay on the Island where the school is situated and during the last two years they have had to go seven or eight miles to get sufficient hay for their stock. There is good hay section across the river from the school which they have been endeavoring to get from the Department of the Interior without success. I understand it is held under lease by Mr. McNeil of the Pas. Steps should be taken, as soon as this land is available, to reserve it for the use of the school, as it is the only hay land in the vicinity of the Island, and is certainly very badly needed by the school.

M. Christianson.

Sir,

This Department considers that it is necessary to have more land at the disposal of the MacKay Indian boarding school at The Pas. In order that a proper amount of stock can be maintained by the school, it is of course necessary to provide sufficient forage. The hay supply in this locality is, as you are no doubt aware, one which varies very greatly from season to season on account of the excess of flooding in the Saskatchewan waters. For instance, in the month of December it was reported to the Department that already a portion of the hay lands belonging to the school were partly submerged and that this fact, together with the spring floods, would prevent any hay being available on those portions next season. The island on which the school stands is composed chiefly of rock and low lying land; as a result there is a very small acreage surrounding the building which may be cultivated. It is necessary that the natural hay supply be supplemented by cultivated crops.

While the arrangement which now exists with the Controller of Timber and Grazing, as set forth in his letter of 28th July last (copy of which is enclosed) augments the natural hay supply considerably, it does not provide the Department with the opportunity of cultivating such portions of this land as are suitable for the purpose of raising extra forage. From the information to hand this problem could be satisfactorily provided for if the following lands could be obtained by this Department for the purpose and use of the MacKay Boarding School,—Frac.Sec.15-56-27-W.P.M., that portion of Sec.22-56-27-W.P.M., lying to the S.W. of the Saskatchewan River and this Department could relinquish those portions of Secs.22 and 27 lying W.of the Whitefish River. As the acquisition of these lands will have a very considerable effect on the economic administration of this school, I shall be pleased if this application can be given favourable consideration at an early date.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:- Re:- Removal of Hen-house & Work-shop:

Referring to your letter #128-1-9 of the 21st, November 1929, in regard to the above mentioned buildings, I find it would be impossible to move them as they stand.

The work-shop is a very old building, the studdings at foot are not good. It has a concrete floor, and consequently no floor-joints to work on.

I would suggest that the two buildings be taken apart and the lumber be used in building a proper hen-house.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, relative to the removing of the present old henhouse and workshop at the Mackay Indian Residential School and using any material of value therein in erecting a new henhouse, also with reference to the enlarging of the girls' playground and fencing same.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of removing the present henhouse and workshop and the building of a new henhouse. Dear Mr. Graham:

In connection with the cows which I purchased last summer for the Mackay Indian Residential School at The Pas, I note in the Department letter No. 138-1-14 of the 21st inst., it states that the church authorities consider it their duty to inform you that the animals which have already been prilled, are very much inferior to those which were destroyed, and that one of the cows had a hoof so greatly enlarged that it was compelled to walk on the ball of the foot. Also that the same cow was minus a brush on her tail.

I wish to inform you that 17 cows were bought by me at the same time, 10 for the Residential School at Pine Creek and 7 for the Mackay School. The animals were all thoroughly examined by me and I considered them all to be a fine lot of grade Holsteins, and in fact, most of them had more the appearance of Purebred animals but they were purchased from a third to a half less than pure animals could be bought at.

You had a letter from the Principal at Pine Creek who said:

"I beg to inform you that on the 26th inst. I have received in good order the 10 cows shipped from Nokomis and that I find them a fine lot of animals built up to give milk. Six were giving milk, and yesterday one of them calved."

"I must thank you sincerely for this appreciated help you have obtained for our school."

This shows what he thought of them, and the cows were practically all of the same class. I remember distinctly 2 cows out of the 17 which were the oldest in the bunch, were not quite as well up in flesh as I would have liked them to be, but I consider that they were the best milch cows in the whole bunch, and it was milking cows that I was buying, not beef cows.

I am quite sure that the hoof on the cow in question, was alright when I saw her, and if she is now walking on the ball of her foot, it has happened since the time the cow was purchased. With regard to the same cow being minus a brush on her tail, this is too trifling a matter to deal with as I cannot

say whether there was a few hairs short in the tail or not and if so, no doubt it will grow out again. If I am quite sure if the animals that he received were properly looked after and cared for as they should be, they will give good results.

I might mention that these are the same kind of animals that were supplied to the Duck Lake School and Rev. Mr. Delmas is highly satisfied with the cows he got.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 21st ultimo #128-1-14, referring me to Department Letter 128-1-14 of June 25th, and my letter #205-11A of October 8th concerning the purchase of stock for the McKay Indian Residential School.

I note that you are in receipt of a communication in connection with this matter from Dr. Westgate, in which he complains that the animals received were much inferior to those which were destroyed; that one of the cows had a hoof so greatly enlarged as to compel her to walk on the ball of her foot, and that this cow was minus the brush on her tail, also that another of the cows is so hard to milk that it is with difficulty any milk can be extracted from her.

In the first place I would point out that we were only buying grade Holstein cows, not thoroughbred Holstein cows, and that the price which we paid for these cows was about one-third what we would have paid had we been buying thoroughbred Holsteins. However, it was milk producers we were after and I believe that a fine lot of cattle were sent to the McKay School, notwithstanding Dr. Westgate's report to you.

On receipt of

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
On receipt of your letter I took this matter up with Inspector Christianson, who happened to be in the office, and had him write me a report which is enclosed herewith. You will note from the Inspector's report that the seven cows and a bull which were shipped to the McKay School were part of a herd that was purchased by the Department. The other part were sent to the Pine Creek School. You will also note the report which I received from the Principal of the Pine Creek School, whom I believe to be a practical man. He is very grateful for the cattle which he received, and is well pleased with them.

The chances are that if one of the cows at the McKay School has an enlarged hoof it is a temporary ailment. She probably needs her toes trimmed so as to throw the weight on the hoof proper, instead of on the ball of her foot, and I doubt very much whether Dr. Westgate or Mr. Bird would understand this, neither of them being a practical man.

So far as I am concerned, I do not think that the Department should be called upon to replace any of the animals that have been sent there. I have every confidence in Mr. Christianson's judgement in this matter, which appears to be well backed up by the Principal of the Pine Creek School, who received ten out of the seventeen cattle purchased.

Mr. White, who supplied the cattle, was recommended to me by the Department of Agriculture here. I have had dealings with him before; I know the man well, and I know his stock. We bought cattle from Mr. White for other points and the parties who received them were well satisfied.

If Dr. Westgate was expecting thoroughbred Holsteins which would cost the Department in the neighborhood of $250.00 to $300.00 a head, he might as well be given to understand clearly that it was never the intention of the Department to supply animals of this type.

I do not suppose that Dr. Westgate can be stopped from making complaints and finding fault, as he appears to be doing wherever he goes, but it is not very satisfactory to have this sort of thing going on all the time. The Department's officers have some intelligence.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Dr. Westgate:

With reference to your letter of the 9th instant which arrived today, re the cattle supplied by the Department to take the place of those destroyed by order of the Veterinary Surgeon.

When the Veterinary Surgeon visited us the first time, one cow was ordered to be killed; at his second visit, six cows and the bull were ordered to be destroyed; this was done; on his third visit during the first week in July another cow was destroyed by his orders.

The Agent was notified of the results of each visit to the Veterinary Surgeon; the last notification was during the first week in July, when Mr. Bishop the Surgeon and myself informed Mr. Waddy in his office that another cow had been destroyed.

About the second or third week in August, as I arrived in The Pas by canoe, I observed some cattle being loaded on a barge; on investigation I found that they were for the Mackay School; on seeing the Agent I mentioned what poor condition they were in, and that it was not with travelling, and that one cow had an enlarged hoof and the end of her tail nipped off (minus the Brush). He mentioned that he had milked them that morning, and found one cow was so hard to milk that it took him all his time to milk her as her teats were very hard to squeeze. I asked him how it was that the full number had not been supplied to replace those destroyed, and was surprised to find that the last cow killed had not been reported. He was leaving that day to go to Regina. On the day he returned Mr. Grant and I met him on the Street, and he expressed the hope that I had not put in a very adverse report on the new cows to your office giving us to understand that he had been up before Mr. Graham, but not telling us what transpired. I mentioned about the cow again and he said that there was plenty of time to report about her at a later period. This is the last I have heard in regard to the cows with the exception of receiving the papers of the bull, which I had applied for at an earlier date. Mr. Grant will corroborate the above statements if necessary.

With reference to the quality etc., I beg to submit the following statements:

1. The animals supplied are very much inferior to the old stock - take about 30 per cent more feed to keep up.
2. One cow had an overgrown toe and walked on the ball of the foot (this has improved somewhat).
3. The cow mentioned in No. 2 had her tail cut off at the end, there being no brush on the end, apparently done at a recent date as the end of the tail was raw.

4. One cow is about as hard a cow to milk, as any cow that I have ever milked.

I most certainly do not consider that the animals supplied are in any way equal to the former stock, and this is the opinion of all who knew the former stock.

Trusting this covers all the information required.

Yours faithfully,

(SGD) Rev. E. V. Bird,
Principal.

Dear Sir:

I regret to have to direct your attention once more to the stock which was supplied by your Department to the Mackay School in December 1925 to take the place of those which were destroyed by order of the Health of Animals Branch, but a letter which has just been received from the Principal in connection with the milk supply necessitates this action.

On March 16th, last the Principal wrote to Mr. Indian Agent Waddy stating that as the bull had been kicked by a horse and had to be shot, he requested, in view of the fact that as your Department had only supplied 7 cows in place of the 8 which had previously been destroyed by order of the Health of Animals Branch, a bull be purchased in place of the cow which was due, and to replace the bull which had recently been shot.

In the Principal's letter just to hand and dated May 5th, he states that your Department has agreed to buy a bull but accompanied this promise with the request that our Society should purchase another cow as the nurse had reported that the younger children should have more milk.

Before our Society can undertake to meet this additional expenditure, I beg to remind you, as briefly as I can, of the correspondence which has already passed between us in connection with the quality of the animals which were shipped to the Mackay School by Commissioner Graham towards the close of 1925. This correspondence is as follows:

1. On April 9th, 1925, (letter 13-0-14) your Department agreed to replace animals destroyed by order of the Director General of
the Health of Animals Branch.

2. On June 25th, 1925, (letter 128-1-14) you informed me that you had instructed Mr. Commissioner Graham to replace the 8 cows and 1 bull which had thus been destroyed.

3. On December 16th, 1925, I informed you that only 7 cows and 1 bull had been purchased to replace those mentioned under section 2 above, and that these were of an inferior quality to those destroyed.

4. On December 21st, 1925 (letter 128-1-14) your Department replied stating that you were referring the matter to Mr. Commissioner Graham.

5. On January 9th, 1926, your Department wrote again stating that the officer who had purchased the animals declared that all were in good condition when shipped to the School.

6. On January 14th, 1926, I again wrote to your Department enclosing a copy of the Principal's letter dated December 12th, 1925, and requested an authorization to purchase 3 more cows. One to take the place of the 8th cow destroyed by order, and 2 to take the place of others which had been sent which were practically worthless.

7. On January 21st, 1926, your Department replied to this letter stating that in view of the Commissioner's report you could not purchase the 2 cows mentioned above but were authorizing Mr. Commissioner Graham to purchase one cow in place of the one which had been omitted from the first shipment.

It is clear from the above correspondence that the animals which were supplied by your representative to take the place of those which were destroyed have never been accepted by our Society as a satisfactory replacement, and in the Principal's letter just received and dated May 5th, 1927, arising out of your request that our Society should increase the milk supply at this School by the purchase of another cow, he offers the following comment on the animals which you supplied:

"These animals may be called cows by some people, but I can only call them GULLS. Their last year's record has been far below that of the ordinary cow, and this, in spite of them being fed practically as the Agricultural Department would have fed them. We have not room for more animals, but what we require are COWS, and not such animals as we have been obliged to accept from the Department. Although 5 of these cows have freshened since January 20th last, yet from these we receive only 3 gallons of milk a day. We can only call them BOARDERS and I consider that the Department should give us any additional animals required equal to, and to take the place of those destroyed."
In the light of the above correspondence it seems to me to be a reasonable request that your Department should purchase any additional cows required. The animals supplied by Mr. Commissioner Graham were reported at the time of their arrival as utterly unsatisfactory, and our subsequent experience with them has fully confirmed the opinion set forth in that report. It does not seem to me, therefore, quite fair to our Society that we should be asked to meet any additional expenditure in connection with any increase in the milk supply which may be necessary at the Mackay School, and I shall be obliged if you will reconsider this matter and authorize the Commission to purchase 2 more good grade cows in the immediate future.

Believe me, Sir,
Yours very truly,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Sir:

I have the honor to report that the Acting Principal of the Mackay Indian Residential School reports that they should have fifteen acres more land broken at the school. His explanation is that if he had the land broken he could raise oats and green feed and supply the milk cows and live stock with food at much less expense than it is done at the present time.

I fully concur with him in his opinion that he should have more land broken. All they have at present being just enough for vegetables and root crop, with a small patch of oats. The school is situated on a very rocky island covered with timber, but most of the timber has been cut off, just leaving the small poplars. Much of the land is very rocky. He asks in the first place to be supplied with a small Fordson Caterpillar Tractor, with a braking plough attached. He would also want an appropriation for cutting off the brush and probably some assistance in tearing out the roots, and for labor breaking the land. The whole appropriation which would be required would amount to about $2000.00 and for this sum he would have his land cleared and would also have the Fordson Tractor and the plough left over after the operations are completed, and he requires a tractor in order to replace the teams at the school, which are getting very old.

I did not put this in the estimates, as I had not discussed it with the former Principal, but I strongly recommend that if possible this school be supplied with as large a grant as possible for the purpose noted when the funds can be obtained. Mr. Turner is doing the best he can at this school, and is bringing it along in very good shape.

Memo. Mr McKenna,

About a year ago Rev. Dr Sutherland applied for the establishment of three boarding schools, two in the North-West and one in Manitoba at Norway house. The Minister approved of providing for the proposed boarding school at Norway house, and for making the usual per capita grant for 50 pupils. He also decided that the other two schools asked for could not be provided, nor could anything be given for the hospital. Three thousand dollars was placed in the Estimates for last year for the Norway house school and Dr Sutherland was asked to furnish plans. The plans, when supplied, called for an expenditure of about $12000 and a great part of the summer was spent in correspondence on this subject.

Dr Sutherland urged that the Government undertake the erection of the building and nothing has been done so far towards commencing operations. The sum granted is to be revoted for next year, and unless something is decided upon immediately, as to who is to put up the building and what it is to cost, I do not see how it is to be completed next year.

Dr Sutherland wishes to know if the Department would concur in the expenditure of the money under the inspection of its own Agent on a building such as could be erected for that amount, leaving it to the future to make any enlargements that may be necessary.

It has not been the practice of the Department...
Department to contribute the whole cost of boarding school buildings, although I do not see that there is any objection to its doing so, if the title is vested in the Government, as boarding schools could in many cases be made quite as serviceable as the so-called industrial schools and at nearly half the cost.

Dr Sutherland complains that his Society has been discriminated against in the past in regard to boarding schools, and although there are only two Methodist institutions of this class I do not think that this Department is to blame, as the Society has been slow to take the initiative. The boarding schools now established have, in every instance, been started by the different churches, many of them being the result of the growth of the day schools originally established in connection with the missions. The Methodist Missionary Society has had missions established along the northern portion of Lake Winnipeg for a number of years and if they have not succeeded in establishing a boarding school in that locality I think it was more for want of funds on their part, than from any undue discrimination on the part of the Department.

As the matter stands now, Dr Sutherland apparently wants the Department to assume the responsibility for putting up the building. Plans, specifications and an estimate will be necessary and I think no time should be lost in obtaining them, either from the Society or from the Department of Public Works.
