Dear Mr Scott,

In further reference to your letter of the 2nd of June last, I beg now to submit copies of the dietary of the Norway House Indian Boarding School, in response to your request therefore. You will note that there is copy marked "A" and a copy marked "B", in this connection I offer the following explanations.

The copy marked "A", is a true copy of the dietary posted in the kitchen of the school, for the guidance of the cook, in the preparation of the meals for the pupils of the institution. It was compiled by the assistant Principal, the Rev H.T. Wright, and is systematized and put in order by him, he got the information to do this from the copy "B".

The copy marked "B" was prepared by the Principal, the Rev J.A. Leusley, in connection with a reply to an enquiry, from you I think, with reference to the dietary of the school.

During the past summer, since I arrived in the Norway House Agency, and once or twice outside of it, I have listened to a number of complaints from Indians about the food given to the children in the school at Norway House, one has to be careful in accepting such complaints, as the complaints often lack proper and sufficient cause, however I always
always note such complaints, they are a guide in enquiry; I have investigated this and I have arrived at the conclusion that there have been some grounds for the Indians to complain as they have done.

Dr Morquay has informed me that he has had a number of the children from the school brought to the hospital for treatment, and in very many of the cases, he noted that when he had them under observation to locate their trouble, or the cause of trouble, he usually found low physical conditions, and that these conditions soon improved, and in a large measure disappeared, when they received proper nourishing food in the hospital; from this I think it can be fairly deduced that the prime cause of trouble was lack of proper nourishing food, implemented also by a physical predisposition to tubercular troubles in the person being treated, which would cause the health conditions to be sensitive and easily affected, by the conditions I have mentioned.

I talked over this matter fully with the Principal and plainly told him, in a courteous manner, that there was a complaint, he courted the fullest investigation, what I pointed out was the absence of a sufficient quantity of fatty foods, and such food as would put the children in good physical condition to resist disease. The quality of the Bread is open to criticism, I saw it on the table, it was not well cooked, the fleur may be all right, but in handling the dough and converting it into bread, there is not the proper measure of success to produce good bread, what I saw was heavy, and I would think not readily digestible, the fish I saw, was cooked all right, I have been informed that this is not always the case, and that the fish have not been of prime quality, this I put before the principal, and he emphatically denied it. In matter of vegetables, the principal admitted that they had only a limited quantity, that they could not yet by their own
own effort grew sufficient vegetables to freely furnish the pupils this feed in liberal quantity; he informed me that last season he gave only 2 meals a week of potatoes, up to the end of January 1915, and in February and March only one meal a week, and after that, up to the time of my enquiry, practically none had been supplied for food, in addition to a meagre supply of potatoes there were a few turnips, beets estimated and cabbage and carrots. The crop of potatoes for this year will be about 200 bushels, the principal informed me, and this would be amended by some turnips, carrots, beets and cabbage, and that he intended to secure by purchase all that he could, this however is not very satisfactory, and the school should certainly bend every effort to raise all the vegetables they require. After next spring there should not be any lack of this essential in the dietary of this institution, I intimated this to the Principal.

To more effectively supervise and confirm the dietary of this institution, I would suggest that the Doctor should be instructed to inspect the food supplied, from time to time, at regular intervals, say twice a month or oftener, and that he should verify the dietary at every inspection. This inspection would be a protection to all concerned, the food supplied would be kept up to a proper standard and such action would properly and readily combat unfair complaint.

I have noted in a feet note on copy of dietary marked "B", that intimates that 10 lbs of lard is provided weekly, I submit that it should not only be provided, but that it should be used, it could be used by being spread on bread, if it is good pure lard, it should be a splendid food for the growing children, in the way I mention, it would take the place of Butter. Used both Ruth's Lard could be used.

The beef supplied in the winter of 1914-1915, was about two ordinary carcasses, this was not very liberal in quantity,
in quantity, the quality was fair the Principal assured me, for the coming winter of 1915-1916, he informed me he had on hand four head of beef cattle for killing to supply beef; the formula for the preparation of Boston Baked Beans, was 8 lb Bacon to 60 lb of Beans. I told the principal that I was of the opinion that he should use more Bacon, and supply this feed oftener; and if possible, he should not furnish for the food of the children, any of the fish known as "Suckers", they are a poor food, particularly the "Grey Sucker", the giving of these fish to the children was complained about by the Indian people. In preparing Fish for food, it would be well to have them cooked by frying, at least once a week. More attention should be given to having the bread well baked, this I understand was being arranged, as there was to be a change in the cook, one who could handle the work to better advantage and with better results. This was a needed change.

I have endeavored to get all the facts I could for your information, and I trust I have been able to give you some good and proper data.

I might also add that I showed the dietary to Dr. Grain, he expressed the opinion that he considered it rather light, he also thought it would be an advantage to cut out tea as a drink in the evening, and get some suitable substitute.

I have the honor to be,

Your obedient servant

Dear Friend,

Your Grandson reached here alright on Thursday. He was well but his cheeks had been touched with the frost. The most of each cheek had been touched but nowhere deeply. There was only one spot that was sore and that only slightly, so you know the frost bight was not at all serious. Of course you must not blame me for this, but yourself, for had you sent him back when you should have this would not have happened. I received your note saying you sent him back under protest, well, I am sorry that a man in your position and at your age and with your reputation for integrity and uprightness should be so long becoming reconciled to the right.

You must know dear brother that God cannot be pleased with the way you have acted about these children. I pray that God may pardon you and let you know your mistake before He calls you away from this earth. You have long hindered the children of your people from attending these great schools that God has provided for your people and you ought to ask God to forgive you before you go into His presence for it would be a fearful thing for you to go into the presence of an offended God. So I, one of the men God has sent to your people in this North Land call you to repent of this your wrong doing before it is too late.

With prayers for your temporal and eternal blessing

I am yours in Christ,

Dear Mr Carter,

Soon after writing you Mr Bunn came along and a little later Mr Stewart, and as Policeman was on his way out we sent him after the Beren's River children.

Dear Chief Berens;-

I understand that a number of your children from the reserve who were sent to the Norway House Boarding School and were sent back home on a holiday have not been returned by their parents or guardians to the School, and that certain reports have been made regarding the treatment of these children at the school. These reports and objections are based upon the way the children have been fed and clothed.

Now I wish to say to you by way of explanation from the point of view of managing the school and the difficulty that Mr. Lousley the Principal, was under last year, that we did not know that the school would be opened to receive pupils until almost the close of navigation. Nor did we anticipate that the attendance would run up so high as it really did during the nine months, so that the supply of food and clothing sent in ran out in some lines before navigation opened up again when fresh supplies could be sent in. The Principal did the very best he could under the circumstances. The children were never cold as the building was always comfortable and they had plenty to eat.

We had another difficulty and that was they had no proper place to keep fish and meat. You know the old buildings were burned down. This condition has been remedied this summer.

A proper supply of food and clothing has been sent in and a refrigerator in which to keep meat and fish has been built.

Thus you will see that any grounds for objections that they might have had has been taken away and overcome by the provision that has now been made. now that they have been entered as pupils of the school. But my object in writing you is to give you this word of explanation and also to ask you for your assistance in influencing the return of the children to the school so that it will be done without any harsh measures.

Stock and Garden:

The stock consists of 17 head of cattle, 4 horses and 19 pigs, 4 of which are brood sows. All of the stock are looking well and of good quality. These will supply the institute with all the beef, pork, butter and milk that will be consumed during the coming year. Both the stock and garden are an object lesson to the people as to what can be accomplished toward supplementing the native food, such as moose, game, berries and fish.

To assist the management two things are greatly needed. (1.) A good barn, stable and root house. These could all be accomplished with one good building which would cost about $2,000.00 for material. (2.) About five or six thousand drain tile to drain the land now under cultivation and these drained to the lake in a deep open drain. This open ditch will be dug this fall and about twenty-five acres cleared of timber on the island about four miles down the Nelson River.

The interest taken in the different departments is shown by the order, neatness and cleanliness of the building and also in the general appearance of the pupils. Special mention should be made of the amount of land that is in preparation for garden and pasture. The entire 40 acres of mission property has been cleared during the past two years and some grass seed sown on about 8 acres. About 5 acres are under cultivation and planted in garden produce, potatoes and turnips.
outlook for a good return this fall is not very encouraging on account of the backward spring and continual rainfall up to the present. The land is very cold and wet and growth is slow. However, the principal is well versed in the art of gardening and farming and will be able to cope with the natural drawbacks that are peculiar to this northern climate.

Many improvements have been made. Special mention should be given to the grading of the roads and preparation of land. More has been accomplished in this line during the past two years than in all the previous years combined.

A few minor repairs are required such as broken plaster in the main building. These will be repaired by the plasterer who is here plastering the new mission house. The rain water from the main building should be conducted to the water tank in the rear of the building. It is now caught in eight different places by forty gallon barrels. All of these are kept over-flowing during the rainy season and more or less of the surplus water soaks around the foundation as shown on the laundry floor and other parts of the basement which were never properly shaped to the drain, being higher at the drain than most floors which results in an inch of water in other places.

The building is kept neat and clean throughout. Good work is done in all the departments. More work on the garden is being accomplished than has been in the history of our school work here and this accomplished by the boys. The order and discipline is good. The children are well cared for. The food is wholesome and yet in harmony with present restrictions. Their clothing is up to the mark, particular attention being given to footwear.

The members of the staff who are here are capable and of a fine spirit and it is to be hoped that the new members will fit into the spirit and atmosphere of the institution.

Special mention should be made of the work of the Principal, who is the first on the job from early morning and the last to quit at night. The day's work covers some part of the entire programme of duties with special care over the welfare of the garden, land, stock, freighting and building of the new house and immediate oversight of all the boys while engaged in their industrial pursuit. Thus giving the key note to the industrial, moral and religious life of the pupils and staff.
Close by the site of the Mission House there is an old grave-yard. This was the first grave-yard started by Rev. James Evans, our first missionary to Norway House, who invented the Salabie characters whereby our hymns and the Bible have been given to the Cree people in their own tongue.

This grave-yard has been growing wild and the fence rotting down. It is many years since any dead have been buried there. During the year Mr. Denyes has removed the fence, plowed it up and intends leveling the surface and seeding it down with lawn grass, also building a low stone fence on the south side next to the mission house. The people are expressing some dissatisfaction about what has been done. We explained to the Chief that we would place a stone with one inscription for all the dead, there being no mark of description upon any grave.

Mr. Denyes and I have conferred together and we think that it would be very fitting to place a good stone there in memory not only of the dead but in memory of James Evans, for he being dead yet speaketh by every hymn book and Bible printed in the Cree language.

-------------------------------

The question of handling the supplies for the Inland Missionaries must receive special attention by the Board. The North-West Navigation Company land it at Norway House for $0.50 per 100 lbs. It is here stored and taken care of by the Principal of the school and usually given out to the canoe men who come after it. Freighting from here to Island Lake costs $14.00 per 100 lbs. To Oxford House it costs $6.00 per 100 lbs. This should be provided for over and above the usual salary.

Mr. Gaudin makes about two trips especially for freight at a cost of about $25.00 per trip. The balance of his freight is usually taken back when he has to come to Norway House for other reasons. I would suggest that the missionary of Gross Lake have a special grant of $50.00 be made to cover cost of freighting and that a grant of $600.00 be made to the Island Lake and Oxford House missionaries and that it be expended by the purchasing of a canoe at $100.00 and the $500.00 be given to two good men for three months' service with the understanding that they make two trips to Oxford House and two to Island Lake. That these men be hired by the Principal of the Norway House Boarding School and be under his order and direction.

The balance of the freight required can be handled by the missionaries themselves when they come in to Norway House for other reasons.

In this connection a special grant of $150.00 should be given to Nelson House toward freighting goods from the Pas.
The new mission house is under construction and is well on the way towards completion. We have three men all specialists in their own line, looking after the carpenter work, installing a furnace and doing the plastering. These are assisted by the Principal and boys of the school together with a few good men of the community. The building is two storey, 30 x 36'. It has a cement wall and floor basement the full size. A summer kitchen and wood shed behind and a veranda in front. All are built with first-class seasoned material in modern plans and specifications heated by a large wood furnace. A three flue chimney with footing on the rock built of stone and cement to first floor answers for furnace, kitchen range, and fire grate in the study.

The Basement:

The basement walls have footing on the rock with drain tile all around the outside and all drained by a 4" pipe to the lake. The ceiling is lined up with finished lumber and serves for furnace and fuel. There is a cement cistern, laundry and store room for milk, fruit etc. also a winters' supply of vegetables.

Ground Floor:

The ground floor consists of parlor, study, dining-room, kitchen, pantry and a reception room for the Indian people.

Upstairs:

The upstairs has 4 bed-rooms, bath-room, sewing-room and clothes closets.

Attic:

The attic is covered with shiplap and can be used as a store-room. It has a water tank supplied by 4 pumps from cistern and well. We have also laid a 1-½ inch pipe in the drain to the lake for water supply.

The outside wall has two air spaces and six thicknesses of building paper; three inside and three out; finished outside with siding and inside with plaster. The material is all first-class, the lumber mostly British Columbia fir well seasoned. Some of it has been stored for four years. The roof is covered with British Columbia cedar shingles. The ground floor is hard maple. The present finish is two coats of oil on all the wood work inside and out. This will preserve the materials and make an excellent foundation for painting.

The building is up-to-date, modern, warmly built, well constructed and has ample provision for heating. It is in keeping with the Government buildings, school, hospital and Agent's home, is sufficient for our work and its needs and we trust will prove a comfort to our
missionaries and a credit to the Methodist Church for many years to come. At present prices for material and labor it would cost about $9,000.00 and should be insured for $6,000.00. The principal of the school and his boys with members of his staff dug the cellar, put in the cement walls for the basement, hauled the sand with York boat towed by a gasoline launch a distance of nine miles, carried the lumber and material from dock and warehouse, dug the drain, filled in around the building, shaped the surroundings and assisted very materially with all unskilled labor. We engaged Mr. Allin of Toronto to put in a year's service and build the house for $1,000.00 and board. Our experience warrants the suggestion that we keep a skilled man for building and repairs on the District. Such a man should have been sent out with Mr. Atkinson to Oxford House to assist him in getting his home comfortable. Mr. Allin has proved to be such a help to our missionary work as well as in building this house that we propose to keep him on our staff at Brandon or Norway House and send him out to any place where important repairs are required or a new building to be constructed. This policy should have been adopted years ago by our Board in the expenditure of money for buildings on our home missions as well as on Indian missions.

The Hudson Bay Company appears to have a large store of flour in all their Northern posts throughout the North country. It is a question whether there is not as much flour held by the Companies in this country as ought to be distributed under present restrictions during the next two or three years.

Much of the flour in stock is of the higher grades and a better quality is being used than is allowed in any other part of Canada. One exception to this is a grade called Prince Albert flour which was made of frozen wheat and when first brought into the country some eight years ago was sold as low as $2.00 per sack. Now it is sold at $8.00 on the plea that flour is scarce. At Island Lake flour is sold at $40.00 per sack and butter at $2.00 per pound and other prices are in proportion. These are paid for in trade for furs. These prices prove that the Company is not doing business in this country upon any charitable basis or with any desire to help the poor Indian.

It is also common report that not an employee of the Hudson Bay Company has been conscripted in all the Norway House Agency and there are among them men physically fit and of military age. The plea is that the Indian would starve if the men were taken. This should be looked after by the Military Authorities and they should see that no favors are given to any company in these times of war.

There should be an order from the Food Controller that no more flour be shipped by the Hudson Bay Company to its outside posts until 1920 without special permission from the Government and Food Administrator. Also that the flour now in the country should have a fair distribution.
among other traders and settlers who have not stored up supplies beyond present regulations and also that the prices be fixed according to wholesale rates plus freight rates. There are more traders in this country and more money being received by the people than in times of peace. The latter is accounted for by Separation allowances. Men are greatly in demand and high wages are being paid. The fishing season was good, men making from $250 to $300.00 per month during the two months of white fish catch. The result is that the people are living on flour, meat and canned goods without any restrictions when they should be living on the native foods of this country.

This is a very strategic time in the history of these people. They are willing to be loyal. They need leading and can be trained to take a great step toward independence. No greater blessing could be given them than to force them to secure their food from the land, forest, lake and stream. The people need organizing on a progressive policy on gardening and securing the natural foods of the country and how to preserve and store the same, particularly garden produce and potatoes.

They need to be pressed and made to prepare their land this Fall for gardens next year. To this end all Government officials, traders, teachers and missionaries should unite to lift these people to a higher grade of living and a more progressive policy toward the independence of the people. This is a time when we have a splendid reason to teach them they must root hog or die and we need not fear that any of them will die of starvation.

It is also a question whether this would not be an opportune time for some standard bank to open a small branch at Norway House. It would be a great convenience to the traders and other settlers and a source of education and inspiration to our Indian people to lay by for the future.

Sir,

I beg to report that I this week completed an Inspection of the Norway House Boarding School.

I may say that much improvement has been made in the school building, especially in the way of brightening the rooms; considerable interior painting and kalsomining has been done, clothes cupboards and other conveniences added, and repairs made to walls and floors. The playrooms of the girls and boys have been made much brighter, and with no great expense, much of the work having been done by the staff and pupils. The electric wiring has been overhauled and made safe. The building, however, is being damaged by the heaving of the rear foundation wall.

I found the building very clean and tidy, and everything in excellent order. The boys and girls are, with few exceptions, in excellent health, and are well clothed, well fed, well behaved and courteous.

The children are encouraged to take plenty of outdoor exercise, and an outdoor skating rink is kept in good condition, while almost all of the pupils are provided with skates. In the summer there are football, basketball and tennis.

The diet of the children is looked after by a nurse who has had considerable experience in Indian and Social Service work, who is in charge of the kitchen, and who besides cares for those in the Institution who require the assistance of a nurse. The food is of good quality, sufficient in quantity, well cooked and well served.

I visited the stables, and found them very well cared for, but cold, low, damp and inconvenient. A number of good cows are kept, and the milk and butter used in the School. There should be an additional team of horses for hauling wood in winter, as those on hand are overworked at present.

In the class-rooms I found very good work being done. The old difficulty of securing clearly audible reading and answers to questions is evident here to some extent, but there is improvement in this direction. One class room is in the main building, where the class is divided, half the class attending in the morning, the remainder in the afternoon. The junior class room is a separate building some distance from the main building. The pupils here attend the former. The pupils are fully up to their Grade work, in fact, somewhat advanced in Arithmetic, I think, but this is rather an advantage. Four pupils of this School passed the Entrance Examination last July.

Sir,

I beg to report as follows on Norway House Boarding School, this Agency. While I have not made a formal inspection of this School for some time, yet I am in close touch with the work at all times, in the building and round the grounds frequently, meeting the children and the members of the staff, or some of them, daily.

I find that the building is kept in excellent condition, clean and sanitary. The grounds are also kept very well, but are being changed considerably, which upsets things, and detracts from appearances for the time. As I have previously pointed out, on more than one occasion, the foundation wall on the north side of the main building is in need of attention. The water system has been out of commission since April that is, the water line from the lake. My tanner and team have been hauling water to the old reservoir, from which it is pumped into the building. The new stable is progressing and will be a very good building, and will add much to the appearance of the premises, when the old stables are removed. My letter of June 11th, No. 10A contains recommendations re the water line.

The area of broken land is being gradually added to. This is a slow and difficult process, as the ground is very full of stumps, and also stony in places. A fair area can be brought under cultivation on Hope Island, but this too must be cleared of stumps and stones, and will represent a great deal of work. In a few years' time the feed problem should be solved. The school has a good number of good cows, and these supply a large quantity of milk to the table, also some butter.

Sir:

I beg to report that on July 1st, two young men, Matthew Nakawey and Alex Saunders, Indians of this Reserve and returned soldiers, and who were employees of the Forestry Branch, became intoxicated, and created considerable disturbance in the vicinity of and within the school here. I was away from the Agency at the time the trouble began. On my return, later in the evening, I was informed of the occurrence, and immediately placed the young men under arrest, and sent them to the R.C.M.P. Barracks.

The next morning, July 2nd, on the information and Complaint of the Principal, Mr. J.T. Blackford, I tried these men under Sec. 139, Sub.-sec. 2, and convicted them, and imposed a penalty on each of a fine of $50.00 and costs, or two months' imprisonment. The fines were paid.

Before proceeding with the trial, the Principal informed me that he intended to press two other charges against the men, assault and Disturbing a Religious meeting. As these did not come within the jurisdiction of an Indian Agent, I did not proceed with them. One of these charges, Assault, we settled out of court, the young men agreeing to pay Mr. Blackford $75.00 for broken teeth (false set), which money was paid the Principal through my hands. Regarding the second, the Principal sent to Cross Lake for a Magistrate, who fined the men $30.00 each, with costs of $27.60 each. In all, the spree cost each man about $147.60.

Not yet content, the Principal demanded of the Forestry Superintendent for the District that the men be discharged. He stated, in my hearing, that he was going to see that they were discharged, if he had to write to Forestry headquarters at Ottawa. The men were discharged.

LONG ON OUTPOST DUTY

Mrs. Willard Cummings, of Calgary, recently made a visitation of the Indian hospital, school and mission to the Crees at Norway House, nearly four hundred miles up Lake Winnipeg and the northern waterways of Manitoba. On return to Winnipeg she describes her surprise at finding at the northern post a boarding school which housed 100 boys and girls. It was well equipped and attractive as any similar institution in a city, Mrs. Cummings reports.

The hospital, which was burned down over a year ago, was being rebuilt. The Indian Department's generous and wise provision for educational needs of its wards found a warm admirer in the visitor, but her chief amazement was at the long service of the workers. The mission has been in charge of Rev. S. D. Gandin, a Methodist, for the past thirty-four years, and his wife, a nurse, has been there for twenty-nine years.

The Indians, being trappers, were still nomadic and their long absences in the bush each year meant a trying loss in religious matters. The children were more and more remaining at school in residence and were acquiring more settled habits and modern outlook.

Not knowing how this matter was presented to the Indian Dept. by the Agent, and believing that if the former were informed of all the circumstances in this connection they would give a favourable consideration to our application to allow an increase in the number of pupils for this school, I would very respectfully ask the privilege of briefly stating here the case for the school.

It was never my intention to accept Applications for Admission in excess of the number authorized by the Indian Department. That this number has been exceeded was largely through the unexpected successful recruiting of boys.

Ever since the opening of this school the number of girls received from year to year has been greatly in excess of the number of boys. The number of pupils from distant Reservations were always small. That for several years several of the Outpost Reserves failed to send a child. That for several years we have been pushing the recruiting of children, especially boys, for the school. That it is only this last two seasons we have had much success.
When the number of applications for admission of girls reached the maximum number of girls admitted to the school last year, no further applications were accepted—the number thus deferred being fifteen.

Realizing that we had as much room for boys as we had for girls—in fact a little more, the dimensions of dormitories is given at the last of this letter—we did push the recruiting of boys. We were successful and we have five more boys than we had last year, viz. 47. We have no more girls than last year although, as I shall point out, we have more sleeping accommodation. This is owing to the fact that not less than four—sometimes more—girls sleep out on their balcony. This is Jan. 5th, the girls are still sleeping there and will continue to do so all winter. This has never been done in the winter before.

We have a spare room that could be utilized as sleeping apartments for a number of girls but—as this room is not very convenient—it did not seem necessary, under the circumstances, to use it.

Briefly put—1st. That while we have but the same number of girls as last year we are utilizing more sleeping space.

2nd.—That, in my judgement, we have ample room for fifty boys while we have only forty seven in the school at present.

3rd.—That in refusing to accept more girls than we accommodated last year and in accepting more boys, I was not seeking to ignore the Dept's. instructions as to the number of pupils allowed but rather was I seeking to act in accordance with what I believed to be their active policy of keeping their Boarding schools full. I felt that, under the circumstances in which I found myself when school opened at the close of holidays, the Indian Department would approve of my actions?

Yours very Respectfully

James T. Blackford
Principal

Some time ago I received a communication re half-day classroom work in this Institution. I have awaited the time when I should feel more or less competent to speak on the plan and its results. After continuing from about Sept. 15, it would appear that I might be able to state something dependable.

Sir:

I enclose formal report on the Norway House Residential School. May I offer a few observations for which there is not room on the form provided.

The school does not, in my opinion, fulfil its main functions to the extent that it should. I take it that the main object of a school should be, to advance the Indian, educationally, morally, physically and economically.

Educationally. The average school graduate can speak read and write English. He can make simple arithmetical calculations which help in trading. But he speaks Cree in his home, he does little writing, takes, with few exceptions, little interest in reading, and uses his figures very little. A few have gone on to Grades 9, 9, or 10. One boy from Island Lake, transferred from this school to Brandon after Grade 9 is reported as doing well. He has ambition. The average graduate, however, does not appear to take any interest in reading, or anything which would take his mind from the petty scandals, etc., of his companions, or would occupy his mind during his leisure time, to keep him out of mischief. Educationally, however, some gradual advance can be discerned.

Morally, the effect of the school appears to be detrimental. The segregation of boys and of girls, and the school restrictions appear to sharpen and develop in the pupil the sex idea, so that when they meet without these restrictions, this idea is dominant. The idea of resistance to the sex appeal does not appear to exist. One would naturally suppose that years of moral and religious training would inculcate some inhibitions, but except in rare individuals, this does not appear to be the case. Naturally, the girl who has been in the school dresses better, is neater and more cleanly than the average outsider, and as such is more attractive to the men. Add to this the fact that she is less conscious, and it will readily be seen that she has greater temptations than the girl who has been raised at home. Boy graduates also are likely to be more attractive to the women and girls, and at the age they graduate, have no desire to be moral. Having been in the school for some years, and being taught that education should make them superior to their parents, there is naturally very little restraint exercised by the parents on the school graduates.

Physically.- School graduates should be superior to those children brought up on the reserves. We hear frequently of "starvation" Indians on the reserves in these days, and there is no doubt that in many families the food supplies are neither abundant nor varied. Dear Sir:

I hope you will not consider me presuming if I say something here in addition to what I have said in my report on the Norway House residential school.

The school is well equipped with modern machinery and comforts and the instruction given is careful and comprehensive and the pupils when they graduate could do good work if they continued to live under anything like similar conditions. But since those attending this particular school live under vastly different conditions I feel that the course offered here does not give the maximum preparation for life and yet it costs a good deal.
Sir,

In a previous report, in March last, I offered some criticisms of the effects of our educational efforts, so far as applied to our Northern Indians. I realize that these criticisms were largely destructive in character. At the time, I had intended to follow with some suggestions as to improvement in our methods, but have found it difficult to clarify my ideas to a degree which would warrant their presentation to the Department.

I would suggest that, so far as our Indians are concerned, the main objects of education, in the order of value are:

(A) The development of a stable and dependable character.

(B) To train the Indian to make the best use of the natural resources of his district for the maintenance of himself and his family. This would include thrift and conservation.

(C) Sufficient academic training that he may be able to read and converse intelligently in English, desire to read, and to protect himself from exploitation from whatever source. Exceptional cases, where higher education would be advisable, can be easily provided for.

I would like to see an experiment tried in this district; an experiment which, from its very nature, to be a success, would not be costly; a large measure of self-support being its very essence; and which should be a real benefit, not only to the pupils, but to the parents as well.

Island Lake would be an ideal place for this experiment. There are approximately 240 children between the ages of 7 and 16 years in this Band. Of these 35 attend Boarding Schools at Norway House, and about 140 were enrolled during 1933 as attending the Day Schools at Island Lake for varying periods. Our Island Lake people are very primitive in their ways, but are teachable and tractable. The majority of the men, and some of the women and children can and do read the Cree Syllabic in their bibles, hymn books and some church papers which reach them from time to time.

The natural resources of Island Lake are probably the best in this Agency. The cost of carrying goods into Island Lake is high. The population is large. Hence the necessity of developing these resources to the limit. On the islands in the lake, the timber is good, a considerable area of arable land could be found, almost any kind of vegetable or cereal of the North Temperate Zone.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Zone can be grown, fish abound in the lake. There is still a good supply of fur and game. There is abundance of water power at a short distance. The mines are still unproven.

My suggestion would be that a good location be chosen, preferably on an island, not too close to either reserve, where there would be a reasonable area of arable land, if possible also with sufficient timber for building purposes and for fuel for some years. Here experiments and tests might be made to determine the value and best means of developing and conserving the resources natural to Island Lake area. In this work the pupils would participate.

The school could be begun with very few pupils, boys, and the buildings be cottages or houses built largely of local material, and so constructed that they would serve as models for Indian homes, and some even for winter camp buildings. Some adaptations would, of course, be necessary. The academic work could be limited to a few hours per day, and instruction in, and practice of, building, carpentry, masonry, furniture making, skiff and boat building, clearing and cultivating the land, care of gardens and later of grains, fishing, care of nets, trapping, care of furs and skins, etc., and later, as the school developed, and it was found necessary, the care of horses, cows, pigs, poultry, etc., provided the growing of cereals was found practicable. Vacations could be taken during the best trapping seasons, or the supervisors could take boys trapping, to instruct in best trapping methods, and to supervise camp life.

The food could be limited, as far as possible, to that which could be grown and secured locally. This would be very important, as one of the chief objects of the school would be education in self-support. The value of deer, moose and rabbit skins as articles of clothing and bedding could be emphasized, as well as methods of keeping them clean.

The houses would have such conveniences as could be constructed locally, and of local materials. Furnishings could be largely of local construction. Fireplaces in the houses would be very natural and beneficial. Strict sanitary rules could be enforced. All of which could later be expected of graduates in their own homes, as being possible for them to make for themselves.

I am of the opinion that such an experiment should be carried out by the Department, and not by either church. The sympathy and assistance of both the Protestant and Roman Catholic churches at Island Lake could and should be enlisted, and each church should look after the religious teaching of its own followers. The main principle, however, should be insisted on, that so far as possible, self-support be the basis and objective of the effort, and the rule of the school.

A staff of about three men and one woman should be necessary in the beginning—a Principal or Manager; a Carpenter and a fairly handy man for gardening, fishing, etc., and a cook. The cook might require an assistant for some time, until she could depend on the assistance of some of the boys. These staff members would, of course, require to be exceptional in character and zealous in performance.

The work could be enlarged gradually, by the building of
of more houses, and by additions to the staff. If the boys' unit proved successful, a girls' school could later be established along similar lines, or whatever experience proved as best.

I have tried to summarize my idea. Many details, of course, would require working out. Salaries and expenses would, of course, be met by the Department. A small sawmill would be very necessary. Later, if wheat growing proved successful, a small flour mill could be added.

I am of the opinion, that with the proper management, and with proper support, such an undertaking would be a success in the best sense of the word. The selection and retaining of a proper staff would probably be one of the greatest difficulties to be met, as they would need to be of very exceptional character.

I trust my suggestions may not be considered impertinent. My first essay in Indian work was in a school, a small Boarding School, which I think had a good reputation. Long years of experience, and close association with the schools convince me that our present system does not give satisfactory results among our Northern people. A desire for the improvement of conditions is my only object in presenting these suggestions for the consideration of the Department.

Your obedient servant,

Wm. Gordon,

Dear Sir—

I have been informed that the present principal of the Norway House Residential School has been given notice that his services as principal will be no longer required. I am bound to say that at this occasion me regrets, and I take this opportunity to write you and express them.

I have been connected with this school since 1927 as Medical Attendant, and today the general health of the pupils is better than ever before. Rev. Mr. Shoup has been paying particular attention to their health since his arrival, and has succeeded in his efforts to a marked degree. His first thought has been for the welfare of the children's health, and comparison with health standards before his arrival are decidedly favorable to his efforts.

Mr. Shoup has at all times given his whole-hearted cooperation in all matters relating to my work and suggestions; this was not the case before his arrival here. The diet of the children has undergone considerable change since his advent. This change of diet, or rather the study he has made of the present diet reflects itself in the health of the pupils. He has developed to a marked degree the gardens at the school and the vegetables have improved the children's health.

Might I also point out that he has had to carry on his work with a substantial reduction of the Federal grants. In doing this, credit must be given him for his ability as a manager under extremely unfavorable circumstances. The ability of a man to carry on under the conditions with which he has had to contend, and at the same time present a favorable balance sheet, cannot be overlooked.

The children are far better clothed at the present time than at any time under another principal. He has also augmented the supply of cows, and developed the live stock end of the farming activities.

In conclusion, I must once more express my regrets at his dismissal and in this unsolicited letter give him credit for what in my estimation has been a worthy achievement. I must also state that I have found him at all times willing to cooperate in any way to better conditions that would add to the comfort and welfare of his pupils.

Yours Sincerely,

Dear Sir,

I have been intending to write to you for some time reporting such progress as it has been possible to make in one year towards making this school a factor in the economic betterment of the Indian people, but I have had such a busy programme since the spring, coupled with the difficulty of obtaining suitable staff, that I have not had time. The matter of the inadequacy of our teaching arrangements at this school has already been given attention by the Department resulting in the material being supplied for new class-rooms, which material is now arriving. I feel that the addition of these class-rooms will do much to make the school an asset to the Indian territory it serves.

In reply to my letter of about a year ago re the employment of a vocational instructor, I was much struck with your remark that the residential schools serving our particular Indian territory were "little more than charitable institutions". This was the conclusion I had already arrived at. There can be no doubt that, if the residential school is to fulfill its function, its graduates should be equipped, both academically and practically, not only to be an influence on the reserve for better standards of living, but to provide for themselves a better livelihood. Not only has the Indian looked upon the residential school as a "charitable institution", but he has actually considered that he was conferring a favour on the school in giving us his children to feed and clothe and educate. The schools have been partially to blame for this impression, for the Indian has had little reason to think otherwise than that the function of the schools was simply to feed and clothe the children.

I feel that these people must eventually be industrially assimilated, but in the meantime the process should be confined to such opportunity of industry as can be provided in their own environment. We must admit that these opportunities at present are actually insufficient to provide a livelihood, much less independence. It has, and will be, my endeavour to discover new methods of industry, such as can be carried on in their native environment.

I have already, a year ago, approached the Hudson's Bay Company with a view to the employment of boys trained in the residential school in the permanent Hudson's Bay Service. The time of approach to this matter was opportune for the Company, with the result that an agreement has been reached, according to the terms of the attached letter. I have only had two boys who were at all suitably equipped to introduce into the Company service and these are doing very well in short apprenticeships at the local posts. However, I am anxious to take advantage of the agreement.
Mr. Hoey,

turning out graduates who will make good in the Company service. This would have been impossible under the old system of class-room education employed here. With the engagement of two teachers this term and the full-day class-room instruction of the junior grades, I feel sure that we will be able to take advantage of the opening provided by the Company, not to as great an extent as could be desired for a few years, perhaps, as the system under which we conducted our class-room instruction for the past number of years has tended towards an extremely low academic standing. Further, it has been the desultory habit of the Indian parent to present a child for school admittance much beyond the minimum age, thus not giving either the school or the pupil much of a chance. I have, to a great extent, corrected this, with the result that most of our pupilage is now of junior age. However, although it will take some time for the results to show, I think, under the present system, we should have no difficulty in graduating most of our pupils with a grade 8 pass, as is found quite possible in British Columbia, even with the half-day class-room instruction for the junior grades.

May I ask you to note the age requirement referred to in paragraph 1 of the arrangements in Mr. Honley's letter. Although since coming here it has been my policy to adhere to the maximum age limit of 16 set by the Department, I presume the Department would be agreeable to extend this in the few instances required by the terms of the arrangement.

Apart from the new opportunities opened to the Indians by the establishment of supervised trapping areas, I think it possible that other means of industry might be discovered for them. I have this year been investigating the possibility of engaging in fish-meal production, from fish otherwise commercially useless. Fish-meal used to be considered a fertilizer by-product of the fish oil that has been extracted from the pilchards and herrings on the West Coast for years. Now, however, it has been discovered that this fish-meal has a high vitamin content and, as well as a fertilizer, it is used extensively for chicken and hog feeding. The present price of it F.O.B. Winnipeg from the Coast is $80.00 per ton. The labour is available here, the fish are available, the industry would be seasonal, probably just after the spring trapping season, and the machinery need not be elaborate or expensive. I was not quite prepared to bring this matter to the attention of the Department, as I had intended, but I am now given to understand that the Provincial Government would be interested in the venture and I have arranged to discuss it when next I am in Winnipeg. (You will appreciate also the great demand for the oil produced for paint.)

With the saw mill established here, there is possibility also in the manufacture of boxes from Poplar wood for the conveyance of fish caught on Lake Winnipeg. Thousands of these boxes are used yearly by the fishing companies. I have, however, in this regard, run into rather a snag in that the Selkirk box-factory has at present practically a monopoly. However, this outlet for Indian industry will still bear further examination.

I wish to thank you for making possible the new class-room arrangement. I am not sure just when I will be able to complete the class-rooms. Much will depend on whether I can procure the furnace which is requisitioned for. However, I desire you to know that this innovation has prospect of enlarging the sphere of usefulness of the school.

Dear Mr. Caldwell,

I was glad to hear from Mr. Bonnycastle on his return from a recent trip to Norway House that he had had an opportunity of discussing with you the employment of young Indian lads at our trading posts.

You may recall your discussion with the writer here last summer, when I outlined briefly the type of employee we want to get and what we are prepared to offer them.

I understand from Mr. Bonnycastle that you would like some assurance from us that we can take a certain number of lads each year from your school. I suggest, therefore, for the present, that you count on us taking four each year under the following arrangements:

1. The boys trained by you we would be prepared to take on at not less than 16 years of age, and preferably 17 or 18 if you are able to keep them in the school this long. I think your suggestion of selecting the likely recruits at 12 to 14 years of age—well in advance of the time they would be employed—is a good one since in this way you may be able to earmark them for special instruction. I believe Mr. Bonnycastle also discussed with you the advisability of giving employment during school holidays to these boys, but that you agreed it would be preferable they return to their families each summer until taken on permanently by the Company.

2. With regard to the type of training these boys should receive while under your supervision:
   (a) We should be glad if you could stress particularly good grounding in writing and arithmetic, as, in this way, they will be of greater use at a post, and be able to undertake more responsibility than simply doing chores and odd jobs around the store.
   (b) It is also our intention to employ these lads at points which, because of their location or the size of the business, do not warrant the employment of white assistants. In these cases they must live in the same dwelling as the white manager; therefore, I think you should stress the importance of clean personal habits.
   (c) Practical instruction in carpentry and mechanics is also valuable, if available in your curriculum.

The above remarks are intended to serve as an outline of the programme for the next twelve months when I consider the arrangements should be reviewed with yourself, Mr. Learmonth and the Saskatchewan District Manager, R.A. Talbot.

Meanwhile, we are asking Mr. Learmonth to consult with you in the selection of two more boys to commence employment at Norway House and Rossville not later than 15th June. About freeze-up we should be ready to take on another two.

I am very hopeful that this plan will work to our mutual advantage and that we may continue to take a few boys each year. Any criticisms or suggestions from you on the arrangements outlined here will be most welcome.

Yours faithfully, (J.W. Henley)

It is our intention to include in our 1948-49 estimates, a sum for the erection of a Residential School at Norway House, Manitoba.    (c) Wash rooms
   (d) Recreation Room
   (e) Manual Training Shop

It is suggested that this be a one-storey building with a full basement. The sleeping quarters, staff rooms and wash rooms could be on the main floor with the recreation room and manual training shop in the basement.
(2) Girls' Dormitory Block:

The general planning for this building would be the same as for the boys' dormitory block. The exception would, of course, be the manual training room which, in this building, would be replaced by a domestic science room. This room should have extra electrical outlets provided for a power sewing machine and electric range.

(3) Administration Building:

This would be a two storey building and would have a full basement. We would require the following rooms in this building:

(a) Staff quarters for eight
(b) Assembly Hall
(c) Kitchen and dining-rooms
(d) Wash rooms for use of school pupils and staff
(e) Power House. (we are prepared to accept your recommendation that the power house should be located in a small building. It is felt that the whole unit should be steam heated from this power house).

(4) Classroom Block:

This would be a standard four-room school previously designed by you for use at Eskasoni and Shubenacadie.

It is recommended that a meeting be held between your architects and our school officials to finalize the exact details of the buildings required.

Director.
Norway House, Manitoba,

Indian Affairs Branch,

Attention Mr. B. F. Neary,

I am in receipt of your letter of August 27th 1946
Re: Proposed Indian Village at Rossville.

Our letters have, unfortunately, been crossing each
other in the mail. I greatly regret your decision to disallow our
requested building site and I would ask you please to reconsider
the matter. The site is ideal for the purpose and is the only one
available on Rossville point. I have carefully examined the ground
where it is proposed to erect the cottages. It is all rock and
bush, rough ground, and has never been made use of by the school
at any time except as a nuisance ground. It is fenced off from the
rest of their property and its use as an Old Folks' Village would
not inconvenience the school even if it should be rebuilt on the
same site. The only piece of ground which is of value to the
school is the strip of ground requested for gardens for the cottages
and this if need be we might be able to get along without.

This site was chosen and requested by the Chief and
Council and they have their hearts set on it. If it is definitely
disallowed I may have to abandon the project altogether. I am
having a tough time putting the scheme across in any event.

A reply by wire, if possible, will be appreciated
as the season is becoming late.

I have assembled all the necessary building material
except windows. These I am still trying to obtain. I need 64 and
am willing to settle for any size.

E. B. Goodman,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sirs,

When I returned from Winnipeg a few days ago I was handed my school report for the past Jan-Mar quarter with the information that they had been returned to him to have them completed up to Mar. 31st. This I have done and have again handed them to Indian Agent Mr. Gordon for approval. I am sorry that in forwarding the report last March that I overlooked to add a note of explanation as to the reason why we closed the report on Mar. 21st. A request had come to hand three years ago from the Board of Home Missions in Toronto to try to always have all reports in as nearly on time as possible, in order that there might be no undue delay in the forwarding of the Per Capita grants to the Board Rooms. Our spring mails over the ice are so uncertain that we have made it a practice this past three years to close the quarter on Mar. 31st and by so doing place the reports on the last mail before the ice breaks up. The last ten days of March we included in the April-June quarter. Did we not do so?

Norway House Indian Residential School

The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,
Ontario.

Dear Sir:

We have just received your cheque for $2,057.75 marked September quarter per capita allowance, Norway House Residential School. We would like to draw attention to the fact that no advance on December quarter has been received for this school due to the fact that when the advances were made the returns for the September quarter had not been received. The Principal was absent the latter part of September owing to his wife's illness. We would be glad to receive a cheque on account December quarter at your convenience. Yours sincerely,

Mr. R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

November 16th,
1937.

My dear Mr. Hoey:

As it is now the middle of the quarter and two-thirds of the prospective grant from the Department has already been forwarded to the Indian Residential Schools carried on under the auspices of this Board, I am writing to ask if it would be possible to secure from the Treasury Department an advance on account of the grants to these Schools.

I would also like to draw your attention to the fact that the Government grant to the Norway House Indian Residential School for the quarter ending September 30th has not yet reached us. If the delay in payment has been caused by any tardiness on the part of the Principal in forwarding his returns, we should be glad to know, so that we may request him to forward them more promptly in future.

Thanking you for your attention to these matters,

Believe me,

Very sincerely yours,

MLT.

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer to vouchers which you submit each month in connection with the services of Alex Duncan who operates the light and power plant at Norway House.

As you are aware 60% of his monthly salary, or $36.00, is chargeable to the Norway House Indian Residential School. As the Department does not pay for lighting at any Indian residential school nor for the wages of the man operating any lighting plant it is necessary for us to charge the $36.00 each month against the per capita grant and at the end of the quarter we have to deduct this amount from the quarterly earnings. This involves considerable bookkeeping and it would be much simpler if the management of the Norway House School would pay Duncan $36.00 a month and you could submit a voucher for the balance of $24.00 of which amount $9.00 is paid from Medical Vote and $15.00 from Administration Vote. Please take up this recommendation with the Principal of the Norway House School at once and I trust that he will co-operate with us in the manner suggested.

In 1938 I understand that two years' supply of gasoline was purchased and when the account was submitted the firm also charged for the barrels on the understanding, of course, that refund would be made for these when they were returned. Of the total amount charged for barrels the Department considered an amount of $974.40 applied to the Norway House School and this amount was deducted from their per capita grant. Subsequently we allowed them $152.00 for barrels.

Mr. P. G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent,
Norway House, Man.
returned. It would appear that they are still entitled to a refund of $824.40 provided the barrels have been sent back. I have made inquiries but we do not appear to have received any credits for barrels returned during the summer of 1939. Please let me know the number of barrels, if any, that were returned to the firm during last summer and also the approximate number of empty barrels on hand at the present time which no doubt you will return as soon as navigation opens. Possibly it is your intention to use these empty barrels to replace the barrels that will be required when a new supply of gasoline has to be ordered. In that event there would be no refund coming to the school.

For your information I may say that the following amounts will be deducted from the June quarter per capita earnings of the Norway House Residential School:

| Voucher | Description                  | Amount |
|---------|------------------------------|--------|
| 412     | Alex Duncan's wages          | $36.00 |
| 430     | Power & Mine -- supplies     | 1.02   |
| 421     | Alex Duncan's wages          | $36.00 |
| 447     | Oil and grease               | $59.49 |

Total $142.51

It is possible that before the June quarter return is received you will also have submitted a voucher for Duncan's wages for the month of June. In that event there will be another $36.00 deducted. It is hoped, however, as stated above, that the Principal will adopt our suggestion of the school paying its share directly to Duncan.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sirs:

Re December Quarter Grant - Norway House Residential School

We recently received from the Department a cheque for $3988.39, to cover the December quarter grant to the Norway House School. We are now in receipt of a letter from Mr. Chapin in which he says that for the December quarter his aggregate attendance was 6271, his average attendance 69.9, and the grant earned $3935.12. I have written to Mr. Chapin, asking him if he can figure out what the difference is between the Department's figures and his. I should be glad, however, if you could help us to explain the discrepancy.

Re - June Quarter

In my letter of December 17th, I included, amongst other matters, the following paragraph in regard to the grant for the June quarter:

"With further reference to the grant to the School for the June quarter, Mr. Chapin figured that it should have been $4237.37, whereas the amount received from the Department was $4094.76. This would look as if Mr. Duncan's salary for April and May, amounting to $72.00, as well as the $70.00 for repairs to the engines, was deducted from the grant for that quarter. Now, in the statement which came with your letter of November 5th, 1940, it is shown that Mr. Duncan's wages for April and May - $72.00 - were deducted from the September quarter grant. It would look as if a mistake had been made and that the deduction had been made twice - first in the June quarter and then in the September quarter. I should be glad if you would look into this matter and let me know whether or not Mr. Chapin is correct in his figuring."

I have had no acknowledgment of or reply to this letter. I should be very glad, indeed, if you could forward us the explanation for which we asked.

Believe me, Very sincerely yours,

My dear Mr. Hoey:

I am in receipt of a letter from Mr. Caldwell, Principal of the Norway House Indian Residential School, in reference to the method in which the Department charges for the oil and drums shipped to the School. We had correspondence in regard to this matter some time ago while Mr. Chapin was Principal. We accepted your suggestion, I believe, that the School's share of the oil which is shipped to Norway House would be about $2,000 a year and that when a charge is made for drums there would be a refund in subsequent quarterly payments.

Mr. Caldwell's objection to the present method is that, under the present arrangement, the Department simply makes a deduction from the quarterly grant without letting us know how the amount is arrived at. It does seem to me quite a reasonable suggestion that, if this method of charging for the oil and drums is to be followed in the future, we should get an itemized statement telling us just how much is deducted for oil and how much for drums, and if refunds on account of drums returned are to be added to the quarterly grant, we ought to have a statement of these too.

There is a good deal to be said, too, for Mr. Caldwell's other suggestion, which would change the whole method of payment in this connection. Mr. Caldwell thinks that it would be fairer to have the full per capita grant paid quarterly to the School and then bill the School for the amount due for oil and drums, so that the School accounts would show the receipt of the full grant each quarter and the payment for oil and drums would also be recorded in the School accounts. It may be that this method would give the Department extra work and complicate the bookkeeping somewhat, but it does look to me to be the more businesslike way. It hardly seems fair that the School should have to wait sometimes for a considerable period before getting repayment on account of the drums.

I should be glad if you would consider these suggestions and let me know if they are acceptable to the Department. I should also like to have an itemized statement showing how the amount paid on account of the June quarter grant is made up.

Believe me, very sincerely yours,

Sir,

I enclose a copy of a letter from the Rev. Mr. Ferrier respecting the Norway House Boarding School, in which you will observe he expresses strongly the opinion as to repairs that "it will be a total loss to put any more on the present building", and that the only thing to do is to erect another one on a different site.

I find that on the 22nd of March the Principal reported that the building had been extremely cold and all but uninhabitable during the winter; that in the office the thermometer would not average more than 15 degrees above zero, and that bacon left there was frozen so hard that it could not be cut with a knife. Yet from the 1st of November over 200 cords of wood had been used in an effort to heat the building. The Principal in his letter states "it is really up to the Government or the Church to do something or close the school".

I find that in the estimates for 1906-7 $1000.00 was provided to "drain basement, repair and paint new building". I understand that certain expenditure has been made, but mainly in procuring material. In the estimates for the present year $500.00 is provided for certain repairs.

Upon receiving Mr. Ferrier's letter of the 7th June, and reading that from the Principal already referred to, I concluded that it would be wise to have a report.

Dear Sir,-

Last year there was a grant of $1,000 made to improve the Boarding School at Norway House. I did not sanction the investment of any of this money inasmuch as I believe it will be a total loss to put any more in the present building. There is only one solution worthy of consideration, and that is to build another building on a different site. I should like you to find out what is the opinion of the Agent and the Inspector on this matter. My own judgment is that inasmuch as there were ten deaths in that school during the past nine months, a new building cannot be too soon on the way.

Norway House, June 21, 1907.

Rev. T. Ferrier,
Brandon, Man.

Dear Bro. Ferrier:

I enclose herewith a statement of Finances of the Boarding School to end of June, 1907. The Government Report also goes out on this mail, it being the first mail since March 31st.

You will understand that the big deficit of this year is not due to carelessness or extravagance when I state that we opened school with sixty-five children and had to make provision for them all. That is fifteen for whom no Government grant was given. Then I cannot hold myself altogether responsible, that is, I am responsible, but do not condemn myself, because I am poorly served with dry goods. For example, I have on four occasions ordered heavy brown duck suits for the boys from Capt. Robinson and he, in spite of repeated protest, has sent me light canvas. These have come late in Fall when I could not exchange and I was compelled to use them and of course they only lasted a short time. Those heavy suits which you ordered for me and which did not arrive till last spring went to pieces like asbestos paper and are now after one winter's wear cast aside. Indeed, if we had not had others we could not have got through the winter in decent shape. My first order last summer for stocking webbing, most express emphasis being laid on quality and going so far as to say not to send anything but the best was rotten. I duplicated the order and half of it was rotten, and our supply and outfit of stockings now is a disgrace to the school. Considering these things I have felt compelled to have a good stock on hand.
I hope you have been able to secure Government aid for the purchase of horses, harness, waggon, and a large freighting boat as these things are absolutely necessary to the management of this school through another year.

I expect to be out in July to order drygoods and will try to see you then if you are not in.

Yours sincerely,

J. A. Lousley.
REPORT
of the
NORWAY HOUSE BOARDING SCHOOL
For the year ending June 30, 1907.

Class-room.--
There are two teachers, one for the Reserve and one for the Boarding School, and the children from the Boarding School and the Reserve are graded in classes according to their standing. The junior room is taught by the Reserve teacher and the senior room is taught by the Boarding School teacher. The plan works well and both schools are helped by the arrangement.

Being holiday time, I had no opportunity of seeing the work done nor examining the children.

When the school closed June 29th there were fifty-four pupils in attendance.

Health of the Pupils.--
The year has been a long and trying one on the general health of the pupils and more deaths have occurred than in any previous year. Ten have died; nine of these were brought in last year, and nine died of consumption of the lungs or bowels, one of spinal meningitis. Only two of the deaths were of pupils from the Norway House Reserve.

The school started with sixty-five children, probably more than should have been in the dormitories considering the lack of ventilation.

A hospital is a much needed institution so that afflicted children could be removed at once from the school.
The Staff and Salaries Paid.--

Principal, $750.00, furnished house and table
Assistant Principal, 300.00, board and washing,
Matron, 300.00, " " "
Cook, 216.00, " " "
Seamstress, 200.00, " " "
Teacher, 300.00, " " "

Buildings.--

The main building is kept clean but it is of such a finish that what is done does not show up to advantage. The floors on the ground flat are about worn out. The cellar and basements are in tumbledown condition and with about a foot of water in each and the only relief is in bailing it out with pails or pumping and at present the pump used is out of order. They are certainly very unsanitary and there must be a drain, which will be a very difficult task to be accomplished when we have to depend upon native help. Quicksand and rock will be encountered and it will need shoring up and it is next to impossible to get Indians to work at that kind of job.

Heating and Ventilation.--

The furnaces are placed in these dilapidated basements which are merely holes in the ground and the way they are installed it is an impossibility to heat the building. The Department have made a vote of $100.00 to fix the furnaces. What is required are new furnaces, new basements, and new flues if the building is to be properly heated and ventilated, and nothing whatever can be done towards this end with so small an amount of money. I advised the Principal to get the consent of the Department to spend this $100.00 in box stoves and discard the furnaces altogether.
There are so many requirements for this building to make it what it ought to be that I have already reported that nothing but a new building will be a satisfactory solution of the problem.

Other outbuildings.—

A good ice-house has been built and does good service in keeping milk, meats, etc.; a large woodshed, also, used for storing lumber and other supplies of a light nature; a root-house for keeping potatoes and vegetables but it is a difficult matter to keep it frost-proof; and a good warm stable that will accommodate ten head of cattle and a team of horses. There are eight head of cattle belonging to the school.

Sir,

Your letter No. 122/78 of the 11th. of June has for long lain in the Stonewall Office owing to my continued absence from home.

In reply to your request for a report upon the advisability of sanctioning the erection of a new building for the Norway House Boarding School, I wish to make some remarks.

(I) In the summer of 1906 the Rev. Thompson Perrier called at my Pay Tent and asked me to accompany him to the Boarding School for the purpose of considering certain suggestions he had to make by way of improvements which he hoped with my recommendations the Government would provide for.

I went with him and spent some time in discussing what appeared to be desirable. After mature consideration I recommended certain things as seen in my last special report totalling $1000.00 dollars. He has not been able to carry out the improvements to the great detriment of the school's health. He now says he "does not sanction the investment of this money". He was the one to ask for additional grant for improvements. He failed to use advantage afforded. He now covers up his failure by saying the building is not worth it. Why not have asked for a new School a year ago when he knew all he now knows concerning it.

The Indian Commissioner,

Winnipeg.
Had the improvements which I suggested been carried out, I could easily have recommended that a further improvement which I had kept in reserve be provided for this year. You will see that the new part lately added to the rear must needs add to the warmth of that side of the building. Now if to this new siding with a thickness of tar paper had been placed south west and east the Building might have been serviceable for another five years. This was my idea which of course has not been realized.

As it is now the building is scarcely fit for use and the children are bound to suffer with cold, and this may result in much ill-health, as was the case last year. It is impossible to place a new building there during the present season. I now feel disposed to recommend that the school be suspended for a year, and that in the meantime an amount be placed in the estimates covering the cost of a new building to be erected on a new site.

In doing this I think that a representative of the Department should select the site and have authority to exercise supervision during the course of construction, and that the workmen should be sent out by the Department, that is to say the contract should be let to some responsible contractor, so that the work done should be guaranteed and the unfortunate failures noticeable in the first building be avoided.

I know all this is radical enough, but it is not the fault of the officers of the Department that things are as they are, and yet responsibility remains largely with the Department and ill-health is likely to be charged against the Government by the general public, who do not understand how things have gone.
I shall be glad to have a personal interview with you at any time, so as to reach the best conclusions and arrive at speedy and definite results.

I have the honour to be,

Your obedient servant,

(signed) John Semmens,
