The Indian Commissioner has forwarded a report from Mr. Inspector Simmons on the condition of the boarding school building at Norway House, from which it appears that it is in such a delapidated condition that it is dangerous to the health of the pupils, and the Commissioner asks whether the Department should allow the school to remain open during the approaching winter.

The Methodist Church authorities are responsible for the shell of a building that was first erected, and what has been expended thereon since appears to have been thrown away. The Commissioner further remarks that it is probable the Principal has already laid in most of the food and clothing required for the winter, yet he gives it as his opinion that, unless the Church authorities strongly object, the school should be closed on or about December 1.

Mr. Perrier in speaking of the building says, "The cellar and basements are in a tumble-down condition and with about a foot of water in each, and the only relief is in bailing it out with pails or pumping it out. There is no drain and it is in a most unsanitary condition. The furnaces are placed in these delapidated basements, which are merely holes in the ground, and the way they are installed makes it impossible to heat the buildings." He concludes by stating that...
that there are so many requirements for this building to make it what it ought to be that nothing but a new building will be a satisfactory solution of the problem.

There were ten deaths in the school last year, and if it is continued this winter this number is likely to be exceeded, as I find on March 23 the Principal reported to the Commissioner that in the office the thermometer would not average more than 15 degrees above zero and that bacon left there was frozen so hard that it could not be cut with a knife. Yet from November 1,200 cords of wood had been used in an effort to heat the building. He concluded his letter by stating that it was up to either the Government or the Church to do something or close the school.

Mr. Semmens in his report above referred to says that he feels disposed to recommend that the school be suspended for a year and that in the meantime an amount be placed in the estimate covering the cost of a new building to be erected on a new site. He remarks that this is radical enough, but it is not the Department's fault; yet responsibility lies largely with the Department, if the school is kept open, and ill-health is likely to be charged against the Government by the general public, who do not understand how things have gone.

In view of the dangerous condition of the building, which is a menace to the health of the pupils, I would suggest that the consent of the Methodist Church authorities be asked to close the school at the
the date recommended by the Commissioner and that in the meantime the question of rebuilding on a more suitable site be considered. The present premises are the property of the Methodist Church and are most unsuitable in every way for a school of this kind, and no doubt grave blame would attach to the Government if it was allowed to continue in its present condition. No expenditure would make the present site or buildings fit for the purpose for which they were intended.

This is only another instance of the want of foresight and common sense shown by the Churches in establishing schools.

Sir,

Referring to my Estimates for this Agency for the year 1922-23, in my Estimates for Norway House Boarding School I asked for the construction of a silo.

I would ask the Department to let me know at an early date if this will be allowed, as unless the silo is to be built, it would be useless to sow for sunflowers, since they are of little use except as silage.

If we were to sow sunflowers, we should know in time to order the seed before the mails over the ice cease. If ordered on the last mail, the seed could come in via the Hudson's Bay Railway and Cross Lake. The first boat up the Lake, reaching here about the beginning of June would be a little late, but this would depend largely upon the season.

As there is very little arable land here, and as milch cows are a necessity at the School, silage is the most profitable means of feeding. Sunflowers can be grown here without difficulty, and have proved themselves very satisfactory for silage. Hay costs here from $5.00 to $20.00 per ton. A silo would diminish the quantity of hay required by the School by 40 or 50 tons per year, or a saving in hay of a minimum of $600.00 per year. The work of cultivating the sunflower or corn, preferably the former, as the corn might be frozen, could all be done by the staff and pupils, to the advantage in experience of the pupils, and after the first outlay for silo and feed cutter, the cost would be negligible.

Owing to the mail arrangements here, if a reply to this letter is to reach me in time to send out an order over the ice for seed, it would require an immediate answer. THE octagonal barn has advantages over both the oblong and the circular types, viz:

1. Has all the advantages of the circular, yet easier to build.
2. Maximum strength and minimum amount of outside wall surface.
3. Freedom from snow drifts.
4. Easy for ventilation, cleaning and feeding.
5. No high gables to catch the wind.

In many cases it would be a great advantage to omit the space now devoted to loose stock, and to use that space for a silo.

With these points in its favor—it should be a barn that will command itself and provide the owner who wishes to get the best results from his stock, with the best amount of labor.

The picture shows a driveway leading to the large loft, and is preferred in many cases, but this is entirely optional—ordinary loft doors may be used if the driveway cannot be substituted.

LOCATION AND FOUNDATION—The foundation and location of the barn should be on high ground to permit good drainage. Barn drainage should always be away from the house. This is necessary both from the standpoint of health and cleanliness. Barn yards should be well drained.

The foundation walls should be made of cement or stone, and built up at least one foot above ground to prevent wood posts and planks rotting. Floors should be made of concrete, they should be clean and sanitary. Floors should be six or eight inches above the surrounding ground, and should be well drained by grading the entire length of the barn in a straight line and on a slant, to ensure dry stalls. The floors of the stalls should be overlaid with brick or cement stones.

It will be seen that there is accommodation for eight horses in four double stalls, and 16 cows in eight double stalls, besides which there are two large box stalls and stalls of ample size for loose stock.

The system of ventilation has been well proportioned, and the owner may rest assured that his barn will be dry, and that the cattle will be getting the maximum amount of sunshine and fresh air.

The silo should be 14 ft. in diameter and 25 ft. high, or equivalent in storage capacity.

I enclose a cut taken from the catalogue of Brown & Rutherfurd, of Winnipeg, which would accommodate a few more head than required here, but the plan of which, if it could be reduced somewhat would be satisfactory. The silo could be placed in the centre, where is shown the box for loose stock. One entrance might be used, the passage, for the cutting box and gasoline engine. If necessary, the silo could be made larger, and not so high. Sir,

With reference to my report on Norway House Boarding School of even date, I would respectfully call attention to two or three matters which should be attended to this coming Summer if at all possible.

The rear foundation wall of the building heaves considerably with the frost, and is not only breaking up the concrete floor in the basement, but is separating the walls of the first story from the floor. There is at the present time a space of some three inches along the wall, between the wall and the floor. A reference to the plan of the building will show that on the East and on the west sides just close to the north end of each wall, a door was cut through, extending above the concrete wall, thus leaving the North or rear wall to stand alone, without any connection with the East and West walls, with the exception of the framework above. Owing to this heaving, the plaster is being cracked on walls several feet away from the North wall. Considerable damage has already been done, and unless something is done shortly, the north side of the building will be wrecked, and might even collapse.

In a letter dated June 20th last, No. 5A, I made a recommendation that the N.W. wing of the building be extended some 12 feet, with full basement wall, to protect the foundation wall of this wing, and to provide a very necessary additional space in the kitchen, which is too small for an Institution of this size, where girls are in training for cooking. This Winter the N.E. corner has also heaved, and as the Institution is in need of a roothouse, one could be put in at this point, where it would be convenient, and would protect the wall.

Further damage could be avoided by putting the wall below the frost line, or by putting in a wall outside of the present one, about two feet thick below the present wall to the frost line, and tapering into the present wall at the top. But this would be expensive with only one advantage, while the suggestions I have made, while more expensive, would protect the wall and give the additional space required.

Dear Sir,

Replying to yours of March 29th No. 123-5-5:

I have just returned from a visit to Norway House and have looked into the matter of material that was purchased by the Department and used during the past fiscal year. I find that $325.00 worth of lumber, cement and wire netting was used to repair and make mouse-proof a large ware-house used for storing supplies. This ware-house was built and owned by the Methodist Church, during the time the old building was used as a boarding school. Fully 80% of the building is used for storing supplies used in the boarding school. The Principal of the school keeps the key and has full charge of everything that goes into the building. The remaining space of the building is used for storing goods off the steamer to be shipped further inland to our missionaries. Inasmuch as this building in the greater part of the boarding school I would suggest that the $325.00 which has been spent for repairs be contributed by the Department. I may say the Church has spent during the past year $400.00 for repairs on this building and on the house occupied by the mechanical instructor.

If the Department will grant this request we will be very grateful for the same.

"Tenders have been invited for Coqualeetza barn. Concerning Norway House barn, please prepare rough sketch and specifications. Concerning the Norway House barn, the Department understands the desirability of placing on the proposed site rough material for the foundation and framework, before navigation closes this year. This will permit the principal to have the work well under way by the time the first boat reaches Norway House next spring.

It will be necessary, however, that you prepare rough plans and specifications of a suitable barn, and the contractor at Brandon should estimate roughly the quantities of cement and lumber that could be used to advantage by the principal before navigation opens in the spring. As intimated in my night letter, the Department will then give consideration to the purchase and shipment of these rough materials this fall.

During the winter, the Department Architect will prepare proper plans and specifications from the rough sketches, and the work could be proceeded with next spring. It may be necessary to arrange for a further appropriation for this purpose.

Ottawa, October 4, 1922.

Dear Sir:

We have, at Norway House, a building owned by the Methodist Church. This was formerly situated close to the church building. Rev. Mr. Denyes, former Principal, moved this building to another part of the reserve. There have been some Four or Five Hundred Dollars' worth of improvements made to it, and it is occupied by the mechanical man in the employ of the school.

This building should be on the school property and under the control of the Department. I would suggest that the principal be instructed to move it to a suitable site on the school property. For the expense of moving and some consideration for the value of the building, I would suggest the price of $500 to be paid by the Department. It would take at least $1500 to erect the building at the present time.

The Methodist Church also owns a school house that has been used for the Junior classroom of the boarding school. It is situated alongside of the reserve school. There are serious objections to sending the children of the boarding school out onto the reserve to play with the reserve children during intermission and other play hours. The building is in need of repairs. It should have new sills, should be lined up and made more comfortable, some repairs made to the windows and shingles, and removed to the school property. For these repairs and moving it will require about $500.

I would like the sanction of the Department to move this building and make the needed repairs for the above sum. It would be quite satisfactory to the Church and the management of the school if these items were placed in the Estimates for the next Parliament, but, in the meantime, we would like the authority to move the building and make the repairs.

Yours sincerely,

T. Ferrier

Education cheque No. 2112, 1921-22 is for a payment of $1,800.76 to Wm. Robinson Co., Ltd., on account of lumber and hardware supplied for the boarding school at Norway House. This payment was supported by five accounts, four of which are as follows:

Dear Sir,

Replying to yours of the 8th, No. 123-5-5 re the Wm. Robinson Company's account: My understanding of this transaction is as follows:

The Wm. Robinson Company shipped goods to Norway House for the Indian Department and the Methodist Church in the fall of 1921 amounting to a total of $2,201.89. In November the Department sent a cheque for $1,800.76 and I sent cheques from the funds of the Missionary Society amounting to $27.09 making a total that the company received of $2,527.85. This was $325.96 too much and at the beginning of the New Year the company drew my attention to this fact and sent me a cheque for $325.96 to correct their error. I then wrote the Department in March concerning the matter and deposited the cheque in the Imperial Bank to the credit of the Norway House Boarding School. Later on I asked the Department to allow this amount to be left to the credit of the school on the grounds that the greater bulk of the material purchased by the Methodist Church was used in the ware-house. The only interpretation I placed on the Department's letter of September 2nd, No. 123-5-5 was that the request had been granted.

In my judgment there are two ways in which this error could have been corrected. 1. By having the Wm. Robinson Company render account to the Department for material charged to the Methodist Church to the amount of $229.36 with the understanding that the Department's cheque of $1800.76 included this amount. 2. By granting the Department's request in sending a cheque to the Receiver General for $229.36 and charging it to the Norway House Boarding School Account.

As per the Department's request herewith enclose the cheque. In doing so I wish to draw your attention to the fact that the Department has contributed nothing to the repair of the ware-house.

Yours sincerely,

Sir,

In Sept. and Oct. last I received a shipment of lumber and building material which I understood was for the building of a new stable at Norway House Boarding School. I handed this over to the Principal of the School, as he had storage facilities and I had none.

I find that the Principal has a plan for the stable and instructions from the Rev. T. Ferrier, of Brandon, to proceed with the building, and to get at least the foundations in this fall. The foundations have been put in and part of the frame erected.

I may say that I have no objection to make to the building of the stable by the Principal, but would ask what my responsibility is in the matter. Naturally, as the Agent of the Indian Department here, I would expect to be responsible for the proper performance of work for which the Department pays, but since the plans and instructions have been sent to the Principal of the School, I presume he is to be held responsible, especially since I have received no intimation of any kind in this connection.

As to experience in building, I have in the past inspected considerable work for the Department, and think all such work has followed very closely the specifications laid down. If I am supposed to inspect this building, I would ask for a copy of the plans and specifications, also the conditions upon which it is being built.

Your obedient servant

Wm Gordon
Indian Agent.

Sir,—
I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 123-5-5 dated Oct. 10th, giving authority to move the building used as junior classroom for the Norway House Indian Boarding School to a location on the School property.

I may say that I quite agree with the desirability of moving this building, but the serious objections to sending children of the Boarding School to this building for classes because of its situation beside the day school building evidences a change of heart in the Boarding School authorities, since when I came here in June 1921, it was necessary to keep a check on the number of children who were pupils of the Boarding School and who were being sent to classes in the Day School, sometimes to the detriment of the Day School pupils from the Reserve.

I will endeavor to have the Principal prepare Vouchers in accordance with the Instructions of the Department, and will forward these in April next.

Your obedient Servant

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 22nd ult., with reference to the building of a barn at the Norway House Indian Boarding School, I beg to say that the materials required for this barn were purchased last Fall on instructions from this Department, by Mr. Bunn, in order that they might be shipped to Norway House before navigation closed. This was done in order to have the materials available for the building of the barn early in the spring, before navigation opened.

No instructions were given to Mr. Ferrier or any one else for the erection of this building and the Department will not be responsible for the payment of labour which is undertaken without the authority of the Department.

It is the intention that the building be erected under your supervision, as early in the Spring as weather will permit, employing what labour is required and submitting regular time sheets covering the same, to the Department. If any additional material is required for this building, a requisition for same should be forwarded to the Department by you.

Your obedient servant,

DESCRIPTION OF HINGE

Read This Carefully--It is Important.

No chain is stronger than its weakest link. Also the life of a school desk cannot be greater than the life of the hinge. In the development of the New Globe Automatic our energy was directed toward the elimination of faults in the Hinge.

OUR SUCCESS IS COMPLETE

We sincerely believe that the Hinge in the New Automatic is the strongest Automatic Seat Hinge ever invented and comes nearer to being noiseless than any other now on the market.

Absolute noiselessness can only be secured by the use of rubber or leather buffers, or springs and when such parts are used it is only a question of time till they become worn or dislodged and must then be replaced or the desk is too noisy for further use.

Those who have had experience in getting repairs for school desks know how difficult and unsatisfactory it is, and, therefore, the desk that will wear the longest without needing repairs is the most valuable one to the school.

There are fewer parts in the Hinge of the New Globe than are found in any other School Desk Hinge on the market. This alone reduces the possibility of its getting out of order.

It does not depend on bumpers or rubber, leather or other material, nor on springs of any kind for its noiseless action.

The steel balls used in the Hinge are one-half inch in diameter, being twice as large as those used by any other manufacturer, thus giving greater wear resisting qualities.

The balls in the Hinge of the New Globe ARE NOT held in position by means of springs, because when such is the case the spring will in time lose its tension allowing the balls to get out of their proper position, or drop out entirely.

In the Hinge of the New Globe the steel balls absorb all friction there being no wearing contact of iron against iron. In every other so-called Ball Bearing Desk there is a wearing contact of iron against iron.

The accompanying illustration, Fig. I, will give you a fairly accurate understanding of the great simplicity of the Hinge, and you will note that "A" is the Seat Arm; "B" shows a portion of the Desk Leg or Casting. When the Seat Arm is in its place, the Ball "D" fits into the socket "O." The Shoulder "R" on "A" moves in Groove "S" on "B" when the seat is raised or lowered. Ball "D" rests in Socket in "R," and runs along the inside of the Casting "B" at "K," between "P" and "K." The Casting grows gradually thicker as it nears the point "K," so that the Ball runs less easily as it reaches the end of its course. This brings the seat to a gradual stop without jar or noise. When the seat is lowered the ball rolls towards "J" where the casting is also thicker. The seat comes to a gradual stop in the same way and for the same reason as when it is raised.

The office of the Bolt "F" and the Cap "D" is merely to hold the parts together. The bolt passes through the Seat Arm "A" in Slot "G" and through Casting "B" at "H." The notch "E" Casting "D" is placed over the Lug "C" on "B" to prevent "D"s" turning with the Seat Arm.

The Lugs "L," "M" and "N" prevent the Seat from raising or lowering beyond the proper position and also carry a part of the weight of the pupil, thus relieving the working parts of some of the strain.

Sir,

I regret to have to inform you that about the end of March last the water line to the School began giving considerable trouble. With much labor, as the ground was frozen so hard, we opened the line at the connection with the Hospital line. Here we found the main pipe broken. We patched it up, and cut off the Hospital line, as we thought the trouble might be there. However, very little water could be pumped. We then opened the line just outside of the school fence, and found another break in the line. These breaks were not caused by frost, as they were straight round the pipes. I presume that when the line was laid, the bottom of the trench was not levelled, and when the weight of earth settled on the pipe the pipes were broken across at different points.

We patched up this break, but could still get no water, although the water would flow a good stream from the school to the intake. The pump is apparently all right, as it pumps from the reservoir against any pressure quite satisfactorily. Were the line frozen, the water and steam would not go down the pipe to the intake. For some time the water has pumped slowly, or sometimes in rushes, and almost always required a much longer time to get water than should have been necessary. I am of the opinion that there is something in the pipe which draws up against a connection or elbow, somewhere on the line, and stops the flow.

I would recommend that this whole line be taken up this summer, and the line straightened, so that instead of four elbows as we have now, one would be sufficient, and that a 15 ft. would then box the pipe for the whole distance, filling the pit at the elbow with clean fresh fill material, and putting a union there so that the pipe could be disconnected and drawn if trouble occurred. By placing a cable in the box beside the pipe, fastened at intervals to the pipe, this could be done with blocks and cable in the basement of the school for the longer part of the trench.

The lumber required for boxing the line would be:
- 4000 ft. of plank, 2" x 10"
- 2400 ft. " 2" x 6"
- 1 keg nails, 4"

It might be as cheap to secure new pipe as to excavate the old for the greater part of the length. There will be 1100 feet of pipe line to be boxed, and this quantity of 3" pipe would be sufficient.

Donald McKay, the Agency teamster, and the Agency team have been busy practically every work day since April 23rd hauling water for the School. I have found it difficult to get the team to do work for the Agency. I have found it necessary to purchase extra feed for the team, and altogether it is expensive to provide water in this way. If a good ditching machine could be secured for a time, that might be the least expensive way of making the excavation.

Your obedient servant,

Acting Superintendent General.

In connection with the Norway House Indian Boarding School, it is found necessary to re-lay the pipe line supplying water to this institution. The existing pipe line has been giving considerable trouble these last few years and has been patched up many times; it is at present beyond repair.

It is proposed to lay the new pipe line boxed in, in order to provide against the extreme cold weather in the winter. The cost would be approximately $1,200.00 and Indian labour will be employed under the supervision of the Indian Agent. I would ask your approval for this expenditure.

Dear Sir,

While at Norway House last week, I looked over in company with your agent Mr. Gordon and the principal, Mr. Blackford, the situation which has arisen in connection with the water supply. I am of the opinion that any attempt to repair the present pipe might prove disappointing. Personally I believe the frost reached it at various points during last winter, insomuch as one serious break is under the pathway where there is heavy tracking right at the front gate. It is to be noted that when this pipe was put in we had little hope of ever making it frost proof as the report of the Department's engineer from Portage la Prairie was that a large amount of blasting would have to be done to make a frost proof connection to any point at the lake. We followed what we believed to be a line as free as possible from rock in putting down the present piping, and consequently the line is not straight. I think Mr. Gordon's report on the best method to pursue is to put in a new connection rather than to try and repair the present one, and to make as straight a line as possible from the pump to the point where it has to turn to the lake. This is in the neighborhood of 1100 feet. He also proposes to box the pipe in a wooden case made of 2 inch plank. I believe this will make a permanent job and will probably prove the only satisfactory solution of the problem.

This ought to be done with all possible speed as the season is very short in that north land. The supply of water ought to be on hand when the school opens after the summer vacation. There are some other repairs necessary to the furnace and the plumbing system and as Mr. Yates of Brandon understands the situation thoroughly I would like if it could be arranged for him to do the work.

Yours sincerely,

The Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,

Sir,

At 12.20 p.m. today I received the following message:

"Agent Gordon reports credit wired you twenty-eighth August 'not received yet.' Have you sent funds and on what date."

On the 25th August I asked for $900.00 to be wired for Mr. Gordon to pay wages on the new pipe line work. I shipped all the necessary material for the work, and I figured that I had completed the arrangement fully.

When I got the wire today, I immediately went over to the Bank of Montreal and made inquiry. I was shown that $900.00 stood at the credit of "J.L. Bunn," and still stands there. Mr. Gordon did not ask me about this, and I presumed he had received from the bank direct. I do not understand why he should have allowed the matter to remain as it is, if he had inquired of me. In turn would certainly have asked the Department and I would have been put wise to the whole situation, and fixed it.

The first mail to Norway House goes on the 26th Nov., coming, I can send it out then safely I think.

I tried to get Norway House this afternoon by wireless but that is out for the season. I intended to ask the H.B.C. to hand Mr. Gordon $900.00 and I could have paid the same amount in here.

I think Mr. Gordon should make why he deferred asking about these funds which were for payment of wages.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Inspector of Indian Agencies

Sir,

I have the honor to report that the new waterline for the Norway House Boarding School has been completed, so far as can be done this fall, with the exception of a little work still to be done on the intake crib.

Next spring there will be some concrete floor and walk to be replaced, but it is better to leave that work until spring, as by that time the earth that has been replaced in the trench will have settled thoroughly.

By straightening the line, we have eliminated four elbows, which should reduce the friction in pumping considerably. There is now only one elbow between the building and the lake, and four within the building, to the pump. We have put in a tee for connection with the Hospital and Agency buildings, and a check valve just above this in each line. The minimum depth of the ditch is 7 feet, and the pipe is boxed with two inch planking, so that there should be no trouble from frost. Manholes and unions were put in at the Hospital connection and at the only outside elbow.

We met with some rock, which had to be blasted, and which added to the cost of the work considerably.

I have had to disconnect the Agency line from the main, as the only check valve I had of the proper size was found to leak. This, however, will be no hardship this winter, as the only pump I have is of little use. When the new Hospital is built, proper connection will require to be put in, and a good pump supplied.

The water now comes to the school quickly and satisfactorily, and I think this line should give good satisfaction for years to come.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Sir,

Referring to your letter No.123-5-5 of Aug.13th, in which you advised me to have the discharge line from the septic tank of the sewage system of the Norway House Indian Boarding School taken up and cleaned and replaced, I would say that while I thought the stoppage could be located without this amount of work and expense, I did as instructed, and found two stoppages in the pipe. This I did in connection with the work on the waterline, the work being done by the same men, and I did not keep the accounts separate. Unfortunately, the tile had been cemented together when placed in the trench, rather unnecessarily, I think in the outlet pipe, and it was impossible to take them out without breaking many of the tile. These I replaced with some of the same size, 6", which I had on hand for the purpose of putting in a separate sewer service for the Hospital.

From the surface of the second chamber we took some of the solid matter, but decided, since there was no evidence of the tank not discharging the contents steadily and as the odor was so offensive, this could better be done in colder weather. The presence of the solid matter in the second chamber was due to the stoppage in the outlet pipe, which caused the surface of the contents of the tank to rise above the dividing partition. For some reason, probably the presence of large quantities of soap and water, and possibly some disinfectants also in the sewage, the bacteria is not sufficiently active to keep the solid matter reduced.

The discharge pipe was replaced without cement, and the tank is working well, the contents remaining at the level of the discharge opening.

Your obedient servant

Sir,

I have to report that the new stable at the Norway House Indian Boarding School has been completed, with the exception of the painting of a portion of the roof, the cowlings of the ventilators, and some other touching up of parts recently finished. The additional paint was not received in time to do this work properly, as we were having frosts at night which kept the shingles damp for the greater part of the day. A portion of the track for the litter carrier was not put up, as we were some 25 feet short of track and brackets. I asked for 110 ft. of track, and received only 84 ft. I am writing Mr. Inspector Bunn re this as the balance may have been ordered and lost in transit. Tavetroughing also was not received. I trust this will be supplied, as it will protect the foundations from injury as otherwise the water will get under the wall, and the frosts will heave and disturb the building. The electric fixtures also did not arrive, but the school had some extra fixtures, for repair work, and these were used for a temporary system.

As the Department authorized the extension of the stable to enclose the silo, vide letter No. 123-5-5, of Apr. 26th last, which letter was not received here until June, when the building was too far advanced to make so great a change, I took the liberty of making a small addition to the east end of the barn. This addition is 9' x 19', with 14' wall, and lean-to roof to end of barn and silo. The foundation and floor is solid, and the ensilage cutter is fastened to the concrete. A wide door is left, so that the machine can be fed with no inconvenience. A trap in the roof permits the passage of the blower pipe, and a small doorway in the side makes way for the belt from the engine. This addition furnishes some storage room for small tools, etc., for the ensilage cutter, and protects the silo to some extent against frost. Almost all of the material used in this addition was surplus from the stable, the extra being cement, nails and labor.

A grain box was built in the hay loft above the horses, with a chute down into the horse stable. A large feed chute was built from the floor of the loft to nearly the roof to keep the hay away from the doors of the silo. A door opens from this to the hay loft. Good mangers were made for the horses, with a sloping bottom, and sufficient opening to permit all waste to slide out beneath the feet of the horses. Feed chutes were put in between the stalls, so that the horses eat from the sides of these. This should prevent considerable wastage of feed.

The stable was floored with concrete throughout, and has a deep base of stones and pebbles with some sand. There should be no shelling off or breaking of this floor for many years. Plank were put on top of the concrete for the horse stables. The water has been connected from the school system.

The Asst. Deputy & Secretary

Ottawa.
The ventilation system appears to work well; we will be better able to judge of this when colder weather comes. A cold air pipe comes from above the roof to about one foot above the floor, in the passage in front of the cattle. Just across the passage a warm air pipe for the foul air extends from the ceiling through the roof. Each has a cupola above the roof. The low walls of the feed passage, about 30 inches, protect the stock from getting the cold air too direct from the pipe. These pipes can be checked if necessary. The windows are also made to open inward at the top, so as to leave an opening of about four inches and the width of the window, and deflecting this entering air upward.

At one side of the silo is a good box stall, at the other a stall which will accommodate four calves or some young stock. Besides these, there is accommodation for sixteen head of cattle, and six horses.

I may say that this stable is a very fine structure, and a credit to the Department and a splendid addition to the working plant of the School. The Principal of the School has requested me to convey to the Department his appreciation of their kindness in building such an excellent barn for the school.

I may also say that the building reflects credit on the quality of education being given in the Schools, as the work was all done by Indian men who are graduates of the schools. The foreman on the work throughout, concrete, carpenter work, and painting, was Joe Keeper, a member of the Norway House Band and a graduate of some years ago of the Brandon School.

I also appreciate very highly the willingness of the Department to give us for our schools the very best possible in the way of plant, and I have personally given considerable time and thought to this building, to have the maximum of stability and convenience, with the minimum of expense. The contrast between the new stable and the old is very great. The Instructors will now be in a position to teach the boys how horses and cattle should be cared for.

The old buildings have been removed, and the material that could be used has been used in chicken house and hog pen, and hog shelters in the outdoor pen. The ground about the new stable has been graded and levelled, and the improvement in the appearance of the school property is very considerable.

I will endeavor to secure the balance of the accounts due for labor, and forward them as soon as possible.

EXTRACT FROM PRIVATE LETTER TO MR. SUTHERLAND FROM THE SUPERINTENDENT OF INDIAN EDUCATION.

I met Mr. Blackford of Norway House School in Inspector Bunn's office. He was requesting a good wire fence for the school. Inspector Bunn and I know the situation and we agree he should have it. Dogs are terrible on the Norway House Reserve. So please get the Deputy Minister's authority to spend approximately $450 to properly fence the property on which the school buildings are situated. See Mr. Paget re the purchase. If he will allow competitive prices in Winnipeg, send Inspector Bunn the authority right away. The specifications are very important and are as follows:

- 2550 Ft. 15 gauge, 2 Inch mesh, 60 inches high, fox wire (Est. cost $400),
- 2550 Ft. barbed wire (for top strand) (Est. cost $45),
- 1 Suitable front gate (Est. cost $5),
- 60 Lbs. staples (Est. cost $8).

Please note that if 15 gauge wire is not available it should be 14 not 16. This is the only fence that will keep dogs (huskies) out of property and will last many years. Mr. Blackford has the posts and will do all labour. There is an item of $900 in for Norway House repairs, etc.

I would have authorized Mr. Bunn to buy, but for the fact that the material is such that Mr. Paget might want manufacturers in East to quote. If they are, give them the fox wire only and let Mr. Bunn purchase gate, staples, and barb wire. If Mr. Paget decides on local purchase, Mr. Bunn should get the specifications and he will work fast as he knows it is advisable to have up the fence soon to protect flower beds, garden and other property.
Ottawa, June 21, 1924.

Sir:

Dear Sir,

During a recent visit to the Norway House Boarding School I made a particular inspection of the land they are clearing and bringing under cultivation at Hope Island. The principal has about fifty acres cleared and the greater part of it broken. In order to do this work he has found it necessary to build a house for the men to live in during the winter while engaged in cutting down the trees. At another point on the island he has also found it necessary to build another dwelling and a stable for the horses and cattle housed there during the winter. The first house is 18' x 20' and the other 24' x 26'. The stable is about the same size as the second dwelling. All the buildings are well constructed log buildings. The principal has spent about $800 in cash for flooring, ceiling, window frames, doors, windows and hardware. I would estimate the value of the buildings at about $2500.

As this is an improvement in connection with the land used for school property I would appreciate it very much if the Department would make a contribution of $800 towards the construction of these buildings.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, confirming a telegram which you sent to me on the same date with reference to the purchase of a "storage tank 36" x 8', capacity 420 gallons, heavy material to stand 150 lbs. pressure, with one top, two bottom and one end openings, manifold coil inside to heat water, manhole in shell and safety valve. Ship to Agent Gordon for Norway House Residential School.

You point out that it was necessary to telegraph in this connection as early shipment was advisable. I was in Winnipeg when I received this telegram and I got competitive prices from the Vulcan Iron Works and the Manitoba Bridge and Iron Works. The former's price was $205.00, with $15.00 extra for a safety valve; the latter's price was $201.00 and $8.50 for the safety valve. After reading the description of what was required to the two companies, they asked me at what particular position on the boiler these openings were to be placed. As your telegram did not make this quite clear, nor did it state what size the openings were to be, or whether the boiler was to be perpendicular or horizontal, I wired you at once from Winnipeg, hoping to get an answer so that I could take it up with the company before leaving.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
As your telegram did not reach me until after I arrived home, in fact only reached me on the 5th, I was compelled to phone long distance in to Winnipeg and give them the information. I may state, however, that it did not give me all the information asked for, as you stated that the position of the openings were indicated in your telegram to me. All your telegram said was that there were to be openings, "one top, two bottom and one in the end". I suppose the company wanted to know how many inches from the end and at what position on the boiler the openings were to be made. Sir,

I would call the attention of the Department to the large amount of work done and moneys expended by the management of the Norway House Indian Boarding School during the past year on plant. While much of this work was undertaken without the sanction of the Department, some of it was so far agreed to that the material was furnished.

I would enumerate some of this work:

(a) The whole of the labor in building the hen house.
(b) The labor of taking out and replacing the flues in one of the heating boilers.
(c) The installation of the boiler for heating water.
(d) Considerable fencing.
(e) Considerable work on the grounds about the building, levelling, etc.
(f) Building of a cottage and stable at Hope Island.
(g) Building of a kitchen addition to the engineer's house, and renovating the interior of the house.

For the latter two not only the labor, but the material was supplied by the School. I am assured by the Principal that the lumber cost him over $900.

As regards the cottage at Hope Island, I may say frankly that I would not have put so much money into this building until production from the Island warranted. There is a possibility that the overhead costs at this point may not be justified by returns.

I would, however, recommend, in view of the large expenditure on both labor and material, which went into the plant that, if it can be arranged, a substantial grant, say $800.00 be made to the School as compensation in part for this expenditure.

Your obedient servant

The Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Extract from Rev. T. Ferrier's letter of December 7th, in which he made the requests for 1926-27 for the Methodist Church Indian Residential Schools. The original is on 160-3.

NORWAY HOUSE:

Painting material sufficient to paint the building inside and outside, is required, also Alabaster for all plastered inside work. Have troughing is needed for barn, henhouse, cold storage and carpenter shop, also conductors from the eaves of the main building into the drain or cistern. These have never been provided.

A new Generator for the Electric Plant is required. The one now in use is worn out and was originally installed just for the main building. Now that all the outbuildings are connected, it would not do to attempt repairing it, as it is too small.

The Steam Plumbing is in need of general refitting inasmuch as the pipe is rusted out in many places.

Lumber is needed for the horse stalls and walls of cold storage plant.

The Principal has been clearing and breaking a lot of new land on the island, for which we have spent some hundreds of dollars and we would like a grant of $500 to assist in this work.

A considerable amount of cement is required to replace that which was broken around the building and in the basement for the laying of drain tile to drain the foundation of the building.

The total cost will be at least $5,000.

The present building is filled to its full capacity and we have a waiting list of some 25 or 30 pupils. It is very necessary that our accommodation be increased to at least 140 or 150 pupils. This can be done for an outlay of about $40,000.

You will remember, in an interview last June, I brought before you the scheme that was on foot to erect a monument to the memory of the Rev. James Evans, our first missionary at Norway House. You kindly assured me that $1000 would be granted by the Department towards a $10,000 proposition.
Sir,

I beg to ask for an accountable advance cheque to complete payment of labour in connection with Norway House School Bldgs. Three Hundred Dollars will be required.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:-

Mr. Paulin, the contractor who installed the furnace and plumbing in the residence of the doctor, had some extra fittings over when he completed his work. I had told him that I would take over some of these when the work would be completed, such as 4 inch soil pipes, some elbows etc., at Winnipeg prices. Unfortunately, I was not at home when the work was completed, and the plumber, I think, must have left everything he had over. I received the attached statement a few days ago.

It is very necessary that we have a supply of repairs for waterlines, plumbing, etc., on hand, both for the hospital and the Agency, and especially for the school, as the latter system was installed several years ago and is constantly requiring some repairs. The eave trough we can use to advantage, as we have several buildings which should be equipped with eave trough to protect the foundations. Repair parts cannot be secured here in winter.

The prices, so far as I can discover, are fair. A few items listed I have been unable to find, and I have made corrections in red ink. I have certified that the material has been received.

If you can authorize the payment of this account and require my signature to the vouchers, please have Paulin and Swayze send to me the account in quadruplicate, when I will complete them.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) Wm. Gordon
Indian Agent.

The Indian Commissioner,
Indian Office,
Regina.
Sir:-

I am enclosing herewith a copy of a letter that I received from Indian Agent Gordon; also a copy of an invoice for a lot of odds and ends that were left there by Messrs. Paulin & Swayze who did the plumbing work at the school last year.

Had it been anyone else but Mr. Gordon these men would have brought home their supplies, but as I have told you before, he is an easy mark, and as long as the Government is paying for it he will find an excuse to justify anything.

Would you advise having these supplies sent back, or paying for them? I cannot see that everything that is there will be used; certain piping may be required, and a few odd tees. The Agent had no authority whatever to instruct Messrs. Paulin and Swayze to leave their goods at Norway House.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary,
